description: Kali Linux is an advanced, versatile penetration testing platform and has dozens and dozens of tools complied into it, making it a very powerful, yet highly customizable platform. These episodes will teach you how to install Kali Linux, and how to use Kali Linux to test the security of a network. You will learn how to effectively perform a penetration test using the various tools found in Kali Linux.
name: Kali Linux
subtitle: Configuration of Kali Linux

episodes.description: Kali Linux is a powerful Linux based operating system specifically built for penetration testing. Viewers will hear a brief overview of the operating system and what kinds of things it can be useful for.
episodes.title: Kali Linux Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.287
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.287 --> 00:00:10.161
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:10.161 --> 00:00:13.370
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:13.370 --> 00:00:14.350
How are you doing Sean?

5
00:00:14.350 --> 00:00:15.910
>> I'm doing pretty good, how about you?

6
00:00:15.910 --> 00:00:17.110
>> I'm doing fantastic.

7
00:00:17.110 --> 00:00:21.430
I'm excited because we've got Mr Sean
Oriyano standing right next to me and

8
00:00:21.430 --> 00:00:24.850
we're getting ready to start
our series on Kali Linux.

9
00:00:24.850 --> 00:00:28.970
And Sean, Kali Linux is a very
popular version of Linux nowadays for

10
00:00:28.970 --> 00:00:30.070
several reasons.

11
00:00:30.070 --> 00:00:33.280
But, tell us why we want to
learn all about Kali Linux.

12
00:00:33.280 --> 00:00:34.710
What's so great about it?

13
00:00:34.710 --> 00:00:37.790
>> Well there's a lot of great
things about it, to be honest.

14
00:00:37.790 --> 00:00:42.440
It is, like you said a very powerful
operating system is definitely what it is.

15
00:00:42.440 --> 00:00:44.550
It's a Linux based operating system.

16
00:00:44.550 --> 00:00:49.210
It's highly customized so it's not
the generic type, like Ubuntu or Fedora or

17
00:00:49.210 --> 00:00:50.060
anything like that.

18
00:00:50.060 --> 00:00:53.640
It's specifically built for
penetration testing.

19
00:00:53.640 --> 00:00:57.100
And it also, quite interestingly,
has a role in forensics, too.

20
00:00:57.100 --> 00:00:58.440
It can do that.

21
00:00:58.440 --> 00:01:01.410
And it can do just
a whole range of things.

22
00:01:01.410 --> 00:01:06.160
If you have been through our CEH course, a
lot of the stuff we did in there, in fact,

23
00:01:06.160 --> 00:01:08.240
all of the stuff we did
in there was Windows.

24
00:01:08.240 --> 00:01:11.350
What we're gonna be doing in here is
showing a lot of the same stuff that we

25
00:01:11.350 --> 00:01:14.720
did in there, but showing you how
to do those same things on Kali.

26
00:01:14.720 --> 00:01:16.420
And the reason why you would do this,
saying, well,

27
00:01:16.420 --> 00:01:20.610
why would you do it on windows and and
then do the same thing on Kali is that,

28
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:23.320
there's different approaches, shows
you different approaches to something.

29
00:01:23.320 --> 00:01:26.620
And there's also quite frankly
more tools available and

30
00:01:26.620 --> 00:01:30.110
diverse tools available in the Linux side
than there just are on the Window side.

31
00:01:30.110 --> 00:01:33.050
You have more flexibility,
more power, more options.

32
00:01:33.050 --> 00:01:36.290
And so this is just to open
up a world even more for you.

33
00:01:36.290 --> 00:01:40.190
So this is something that you can use
to just really enhance your power and

34
00:01:40.190 --> 00:01:42.690
capabilities more than they already are.

35
00:01:42.690 --> 00:01:45.070
So if you've taken the CEH,

36
00:01:45.070 --> 00:01:47.850
you're gonna get to see
a different viewpoint on things.

37
00:01:47.850 --> 00:01:49.780
If you haven't, well that's fine.

38
00:01:49.780 --> 00:01:52.150
We're gonna show you how it fits in and
show you the process and

39
00:01:52.150 --> 00:01:54.610
show you the tools you use along the way.

40
00:01:54.610 --> 00:01:58.160
Talk about the differences and all that
good stuff to really kind of get you

41
00:01:58.160 --> 00:01:59.870
going, get you more comfortable with it.

42
00:01:59.870 --> 00:02:02.335
Then you can do more exploring
on your own afterwards.

43
00:02:02.335 --> 00:02:06.340
Cuz there's still plenty that we won't
even get to in here, there's just so

44
00:02:06.340 --> 00:02:07.510
much with this tool.

45
00:02:07.510 --> 00:02:10.090
But this is really just to
kind of get you going, and

46
00:02:10.090 --> 00:02:14.350
you'll definitely be able to after all is
said and done with this series of courses.

47
00:02:14.350 --> 00:02:18.510
You'll be able to say, oh, let me explore
some more here and try some stuff out.

48
00:02:18.510 --> 00:02:19.297
>> Fantastic.

49
00:02:19.297 --> 00:02:22.656
All right, well I hope that got
you as excited as it got me,

50
00:02:22.656 --> 00:02:25.780
I'm really dying to learn
a lot more about this.

51
00:02:25.780 --> 00:02:28.090
I'm a Windows guy by nature,

52
00:02:28.090 --> 00:02:30.290
I've played with a bunch of
different versions of Linux.

53
00:02:30.290 --> 00:02:32.390
This one just seems to have
everything built in to it.

54
00:02:32.390 --> 00:02:35.290
I don't have a lot of compiling,
or extra tools to do.

55
00:02:35.290 --> 00:02:36.900
We can do quite a lot with it.

56
00:02:36.900 --> 00:02:39.120
So hopefully everybody is ready.

57
00:02:39.120 --> 00:02:40.130
So stay tuned.

58
00:02:40.130 --> 00:02:41.972
We'll be back with more on Kali Linux.

59
00:02:41.972 --> 00:02:42.472
[SOUND]

episodes.description: There are a lot of ways to run and utilize the tools within Kali Linux, but before one gets into the advanced functionality of a platform, one must first understand the basics. Viewers will hear discussions on the origins of Kali Linux and briefly discuss some of the usable tools in the Kali Linux platform.
episodes.title: What is Kali Linux
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.653
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.653 --> 00:00:13.820
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.820 --> 00:00:16.050
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and
with me today is Mr.

4
00:00:16.050 --> 00:00:17.830
Sean Oriyano, how you doing Sean?

5
00:00:17.830 --> 00:00:21.230
>> Doing pretty good, how about you?r
>> I'm doing great because we are getting

6
00:00:21.230 --> 00:00:23.890
ready to kick off our Kali Linux series.

7
00:00:23.890 --> 00:00:27.030
I'm standing here next to Sean Oriyano,
that's good enough right?

8
00:00:27.030 --> 00:00:28.590
But we've got a great topic for

9
00:00:28.590 --> 00:00:31.450
you, we're going to be going
over can I say, Kaa-lee Linux?

10
00:00:31.450 --> 00:00:35.410
I know you've been saying Kay-lee Linux,
is there a reason for that?

11
00:00:35.410 --> 00:00:36.520
Or it is just-
>> Nah.

12
00:00:36.520 --> 00:00:38.760
>> I just like to be different, I guess.

13
00:00:38.760 --> 00:00:42.980
>> I apologize then, I don't know what
the proper pronunciation for that is,

14
00:00:42.980 --> 00:00:44.720
we'll go with Kay-lee Linux.

15
00:00:44.720 --> 00:00:49.556
But Kali Linux, Sean, is a distro
of Linux we can get free obviously.

16
00:00:49.556 --> 00:00:52.850
And we can download that and install it.

17
00:00:52.850 --> 00:00:54.460
It's got some pretty cool origins.

18
00:00:54.460 --> 00:00:58.940
It's a pretty cool distro when it comes
to our myriad of choices out there.

19
00:00:58.940 --> 00:01:02.750
But tell us a little bit about Kali Linux.

20
00:01:02.750 --> 00:01:06.450
>> It's funny, when I wanna say Kay-lee,
I wanna say Kaa-lee, and

21
00:01:06.450 --> 00:01:09.865
then I wanna think Kah-lee,
from Indiana Jones the second movie.

22
00:01:09.865 --> 00:01:10.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

23
00:01:10.730 --> 00:01:13.100
>> The head of the cult was Kali, so.

24
00:01:13.100 --> 00:01:15.855
>> I keep saying in my head, I'm going
back to Kaa-lee, I don't know why.

25
00:01:15.855 --> 00:01:19.029
>> Aw yeah.

26
00:01:19.029 --> 00:01:23.390
>> [LAUGH] It is a really good distro.

27
00:01:23.390 --> 00:01:26.430
I'm a Windows guy,
I've done a lot with Windows.

28
00:01:26.430 --> 00:01:30.080
Kinda dabbled in Linux, and I remember
playing with one called BackTracks

29
00:01:30.080 --> 00:01:33.920
because it was one that had a lot of
the tools already combined into it, and

30
00:01:33.920 --> 00:01:36.210
it was good for doing certain testing and
things like that.

31
00:01:36.210 --> 00:01:38.950
And that really where Kali gets
its history, where it's from.

32
00:01:38.950 --> 00:01:39.730
Right?
>> Yeah.

33
00:01:39.730 --> 00:01:43.650
That's its roots is we had BackTrack for
so many years.

34
00:01:43.650 --> 00:01:45.700
It went through several iterations.

35
00:01:45.700 --> 00:01:52.370
You saw that brought up in several
different places as one of the tools or

36
00:01:52.370 --> 00:01:56.630
the tool to use on the Linux side that
brought everything together for you.

37
00:01:56.630 --> 00:02:00.930
It actually did a good job,
we saw a lot of

38
00:02:00.930 --> 00:02:05.150
people using that tool over the years and
a lot of discussion on it.

39
00:02:05.150 --> 00:02:10.170
And you can tell how popular it was by the
amount of people that still refer to it.

40
00:02:10.170 --> 00:02:13.780
You know you still hear people,
like oh well you've got Kali and

41
00:02:13.780 --> 00:02:17.140
then you've got BackTrack.

42
00:02:17.140 --> 00:02:20.160
It's like there's a little
more to the story there.

43
00:02:20.160 --> 00:02:24.935
Oh well okay, I haven't seen Kali but I've
used BackTrack, well, you kind of have.

44
00:02:24.935 --> 00:02:29.775
Well, you know what happened is BackTrack
was around for a number of years.

45
00:02:30.805 --> 00:02:32.055
Like I said it did a great job.

46
00:02:32.055 --> 00:02:36.165
It shares a lot in common, or
Kali shares a lot in common with it,

47
00:02:36.165 --> 00:02:38.685
but there definitely are some differences.

48
00:02:38.685 --> 00:02:43.345
Basically what happened is that
as the whole thing went on and

49
00:02:43.345 --> 00:02:47.870
they kept upgrading and
doing stuff to BackTrack.

50
00:02:47.870 --> 00:02:51.920
Really what it amounted to is
they took a version of Linux and

51
00:02:51.920 --> 00:02:55.290
then just started putting
tools on top of it.

52
00:02:55.290 --> 00:03:00.230
That's what it really was, and so they
just initially started putting that stuff

53
00:03:00.230 --> 00:03:03.390
on top of it, and
then just putting more stuff on top of it.

54
00:03:03.390 --> 00:03:05.090
And people liked it, it was great.

55
00:03:05.090 --> 00:03:06.520
It was like one-stop shopping.

56
00:03:06.520 --> 00:03:09.690
You had everything there
right in that one bundle.

57
00:03:09.690 --> 00:03:14.780
However, at one point, they decided when
they were going from the last version of

58
00:03:14.780 --> 00:03:21.920
BackTrack, which was, I think was 5 R3,
as I think Ben's put up here.

59
00:03:21.920 --> 00:03:24.460
5 R3 was the last version of that, and

60
00:03:24.460 --> 00:03:29.700
they were deciding what they
wanted to do after that version.

61
00:03:29.700 --> 00:03:34.140
And what they said was,
let's just redo the whole thing.

62
00:03:34.140 --> 00:03:36.590
As they started evaluating how
the upgrader was gonna work,

63
00:03:36.590 --> 00:03:40.690
they really started looking at it and
said, we can do a lot better than this if

64
00:03:40.690 --> 00:03:46.030
we really decide just to strip the whole
thing down and do it from the ground up.

65
00:03:46.030 --> 00:03:49.660
So what they did is
they got distrub Linux.

66
00:03:49.660 --> 00:03:53.750
I just had a brain thing in there.

67
00:03:53.750 --> 00:03:55.600
But yeah, debian is what I'm looking for.

68
00:03:55.600 --> 00:04:02.206
So they took Debian and what they did
was they talked to the companies that

69
00:04:02.206 --> 00:04:07.316
made a lot of the tools that
were included in BackTrack.

70
00:04:07.316 --> 00:04:11.225
And they said, well, we're redoing
things from the ground up, you know, so,

71
00:04:11.225 --> 00:04:15.310
when we do this, we'd like to talk to you
about having much tighter integration with

72
00:04:15.310 --> 00:04:18.840
the product than you have in just
installing it in top before.

73
00:04:18.840 --> 00:04:19.830
>> Huh.
>> And so,

74
00:04:19.830 --> 00:04:23.770
that made a lot of these
tools work a lot better and

75
00:04:23.770 --> 00:04:27.220
had substantially more power than
they had in previous versions.

76
00:04:27.220 --> 00:04:30.260
And you also have them just natively
there instead of just kinda

77
00:04:30.260 --> 00:04:34.760
installed on top of it
>> And so that gives you a lot more power,

78
00:04:34.760 --> 00:04:38.900
a lot more efficiency and
the ability to do a lot more things.

79
00:04:38.900 --> 00:04:43.830
Overall, if you look at the two
they still are close enough and

80
00:04:43.830 --> 00:04:47.640
enough similarities that if
you were with BackTrack and

81
00:04:47.640 --> 00:04:52.760
you're moving over to Kali, you're not
going to have really that much problem.

82
00:04:52.760 --> 00:04:57.800
You may just come over and say okay, well,
there's a few new utilities in there.

83
00:04:57.800 --> 00:05:01.070
But for the most part it looks the same.

84
00:05:01.070 --> 00:05:03.160
If you haven't then heck no big deal.

85
00:05:03.160 --> 00:05:04.560
It's not even going to matter to you.

86
00:05:04.560 --> 00:05:09.720
I would tell you at this point you're not
going to be going with BackTrack anymore.

87
00:05:09.720 --> 00:05:11.120
You can still use it.

88
00:05:11.120 --> 00:05:15.390
But if you wanna be using the new
stuff you really be on Kali and

89
00:05:15.390 --> 00:05:18.070
not be messing with BackTrack.

90
00:05:18.070 --> 00:05:21.880
It already has started showing its age and
its end of life, and

91
00:05:21.880 --> 00:05:27.340
that's just gonna get more and
more dramatic as things go forward.

92
00:05:27.340 --> 00:05:29.720
So, Kali is where you wanna be.

93
00:05:29.720 --> 00:05:33.990
You see it referenced in all
sorts of different places now.

94
00:05:33.990 --> 00:05:38.470
They don't mention BackTrack
nearly as much as they used to.

95
00:05:38.470 --> 00:05:41.300
I was even last week, before I came here,

96
00:05:41.300 --> 00:05:47.075
I was attending a seminar and
BackTrack was never, ever even mentioned.

97
00:05:47.075 --> 00:05:49.805
And we had quite a few people
that were pen-testers, and

98
00:05:49.805 --> 00:05:54.145
had probably about 40 when all was
said and done in the same room,

99
00:05:54.145 --> 00:05:59.045
and none of them mentioned BackTrack
during that, it was all done on Kali.

100
00:05:59.045 --> 00:06:03.400
So it shows you just kind of right
there people at that point doing it.

101
00:06:03.400 --> 00:06:06.185
>> You know, like I said,
for a Windows guy like me,

102
00:06:06.185 --> 00:06:11.260
Kali is a fantastic distro because
it has everything, as you said,

103
00:06:11.260 --> 00:06:13.660
precompiled in there or
really designed in there.

104
00:06:13.660 --> 00:06:17.320
It's not like they just went,
downloaded it, added it to their ISO and

105
00:06:17.320 --> 00:06:18.410
put it out there.

106
00:06:18.410 --> 00:06:22.100
I mean from the ground up, this was
built with penetration testing in mind.

107
00:06:22.100 --> 00:06:24.420
It's got just dozens, and dozens, and

108
00:06:24.420 --> 00:06:28.310
dozens of tools already compiled in there,
ready to go.

109
00:06:28.310 --> 00:06:31.720
We've got so
many different ways we can run Kali Linux.

110
00:06:31.720 --> 00:06:36.870
So you guys are in for a real treat,
it's a very good distro to get used to.

111
00:06:36.870 --> 00:06:38.750
If you're gonna do any type
of penetration testing,

112
00:06:38.750 --> 00:06:41.280
as Sean says, this is the distro to use.

113
00:06:41.280 --> 00:06:44.150
If you just want a Linux
distros to keep handy.

114
00:06:44.150 --> 00:06:47.660
Like me as a Windows guy, I still like
to have a nice live thumb drive now and

115
00:06:47.660 --> 00:06:51.660
again, because Linux has some tools
that I can't port over to Windows.

116
00:06:51.660 --> 00:06:55.370
This is the one to have, cuz half of
them are precompiled right on there.

117
00:06:55.370 --> 00:06:59.292
It's a very well-thought
out distro of Linux.

118
00:06:59.292 --> 00:07:00.407
I really like it.

119
00:07:00.407 --> 00:07:03.180
>> Yeah, and there's so
much support for it.

120
00:07:03.180 --> 00:07:04.870
Like you said the tools are already there.

121
00:07:04.870 --> 00:07:10.790
And then there's even the repositories
that you have available in every version

122
00:07:10.790 --> 00:07:16.100
of Linux, that there's even more tools
up there that you can add to that.

123
00:07:16.100 --> 00:07:18.600
If you have something else that you

124
00:07:18.600 --> 00:07:21.120
developed yourself you
can add it into there.

125
00:07:21.120 --> 00:07:24.560
There's third party developers that
have their own stuff that can be

126
00:07:24.560 --> 00:07:25.270
added in to there.

127
00:07:25.270 --> 00:07:26.270
You know, so,

128
00:07:26.270 --> 00:07:31.310
it saves you the trouble of finding a lot
of that stuff right from the get go.

129
00:07:31.310 --> 00:07:34.300
But, I wouldn't just limit yourself
to what's in the interface.

130
00:07:34.300 --> 00:07:38.306
You know, we're gonna concentrate a lot
of the stuff that's in the interface

131
00:07:38.306 --> 00:07:40.610
over the course of our segments here.

132
00:07:40.610 --> 00:07:42.800
But don't limit yourself to just that.

133
00:07:42.800 --> 00:07:45.800
Don't be afraid to go out and
look at these other things because there

134
00:07:45.800 --> 00:07:50.340
are plenty of other things
you can put on top of this.

135
00:07:50.340 --> 00:07:52.244
Something to mention, by the way,
when you're doing this.

136
00:07:52.244 --> 00:07:55.619
This version of Linux,
you could, if you wanted to,

137
00:07:55.619 --> 00:08:00.344
install it right in your hard drive and
put your other applications on it and

138
00:08:00.344 --> 00:08:02.748
use it like a desktop OS if you wanted.

139
00:08:02.748 --> 00:08:04.583
I've seen people do that.

140
00:08:04.583 --> 00:08:08.571
It's not really meant for that but
heck, if that's the way you roll,

141
00:08:08.571 --> 00:08:10.810
who am I to go through and say anything?

142
00:08:10.810 --> 00:08:14.040
But it wasn't intended to
be that sort of thing.

143
00:08:14.040 --> 00:08:19.342
It's like, if you're using Linux and you
want to have a desktop version of Linux,

144
00:08:19.342 --> 00:08:24.310
Ubuntu would be good for that,
those ones would be totally acceptable.

145
00:08:24.310 --> 00:08:26.149
But yeah, you could do it with this but

146
00:08:26.149 --> 00:08:28.400
that's not what they
really intended it for.

147
00:08:28.400 --> 00:08:31.875
They already have quite a few
things in there going on that,

148
00:08:31.875 --> 00:08:35.100
it's just better to use something else for
it.

149
00:08:35.100 --> 00:08:38.630
You never know, there's always
somebody that wants to do it.

150
00:08:38.630 --> 00:08:42.320
I tried it just to see at one
point myself to see as well.

151
00:08:42.320 --> 00:08:43.690
>> See if you could use
it as a daily driver.

152
00:08:43.690 --> 00:08:46.160
>> And it's like, yeah, could I have both?

153
00:08:46.160 --> 00:08:51.920
Yeah, can I do both things with it and
it's like yeah, you can, but, it

154
00:08:51.920 --> 00:08:58.090
wasn't meant for that, so it's just better
just to leave that to something else.

155
00:08:59.410 --> 00:09:02.925
And just FYI,
something else l'd add on to this as

156
00:09:02.925 --> 00:09:07.630
far as kind of a prereqs thing sort
of we're talking about this is.

157
00:09:07.630 --> 00:09:10.213
And this is a prereqs as far as skills and

158
00:09:10.213 --> 00:09:14.989
expectations go is that when you talk

episodes.description: There are several different ways one can go about installing Kali Linux and working with it, so one should know how to properly install it in order that they may be able to properly use it. Viewers will hear discussions about the different options and benefits of different installs for Kali, and will see demonstrations on how to install Kali through both a virtual and live install.
episodes.title: Installing Kali Linux

So, we talked about the fact that you can

Typically if we look at one, like the live

They're doing that just so

You can use it for other reasons, too.

It doesn't mean, hey,
if you're running the live version.

You're just test drive it and that's it.

You might use it just because

I mean you can see how useful

using that machine's hardware but

And so you can run your tests and

Boot the thing back up,

It also has a practical advantage to.

00:02:43.340 --> 00:02:47.410
You can still do real world physical

So, for

You can do a live install from

Then you have the installation

It's easy.

All you have to do is just you

00:04:38.370 --> 00:04:40.920
No one's really looking at that.

00:04:40.920 --> 00:04:44.420
So you've got plenty of

And that that last one

93
00:04:57.555 --> 00:05:01.030
And like I was saying

it looks very similar look and feel wise.

To a live version of Kali

97

You can do analysis on it, but

98
00:05:17.085 --> 00:05:20.515
So it's almost like putting

99
00:05:20.515 --> 00:05:23.545

100
00:05:23.545 --> 00:05:26.465
If you didn't do that one, it's a DFI.

00:05:26.465 --> 00:05:31.850
The DFI class talked about
a write blocker which is

102
00:05:31.850 --> 00:05:36.560

the hard drive and the rest of the system.

103
00:05:36.560 --> 00:05:41.530
So, it blocks writes going to the device
so you don't alter it in any way.

104
00:05:41.530 --> 00:05:43.720
>> Right, cuz if we're doing
a forensic investigation,

105
00:05:43.720 --> 00:05:48.190
one of the keys is to make sure we don't
modify anything we're touching cuz that's

106
00:05:48.190 --> 00:05:50.280
gonna contaminate the evidence and

00:31:04.690 --> 00:31:08.190
It's just like, oh hey,
I'll keep track of them for you.

547
00:31:08.190 --> 00:31:11.380
But you're still gonna have
to go into the GUI and do it.

548
00:31:11.380 --> 00:31:18.060
You're gonna spending a considerable
amount of time doing stuff at the GUI.

549
00:31:18.060 --> 00:31:22.820
I would tell you right now,
if you're not a Linux person or

00:31:22.820 --> 00:31:27.115
you're not familiar with all these
commands, get used to command name, space,

551
00:31:27.115 --> 00:31:30.115
--help, get used to it.

552
00:31:30.115 --> 00:31:34.790
[LAUGH] That's going to be a very
important, friendly thing for you.

553
00:31:34.790 --> 00:31:37.010
And, hey, nothing wrong with that.

554
00:31:37.010 --> 00:31:39.782
I don't remember every little switch,
everything in there.

555
00:31:39.782 --> 00:31:43.310
It's impossible to really do that.

556
00:31:43.310 --> 00:31:47.307
So I just make it easier on myself, some
of them I know off the top of my head and

557
00:31:47.307 --> 00:31:50.866
other ones I'll just go through yep
I want that, that, and that and

558
00:31:50.866 --> 00:31:53.410
boom put it together and go on with it.

559
00:31:53.410 --> 00:31:58.850
Just if you remember the --help that's
gonna be a big, big assistance to you.

560
00:32:00.070 --> 00:32:02.470
>> All right,
well Sean a lot of good information there.

561
00:32:02.470 --> 00:32:06.100
We've got Kali installed in
this episode we saw how to.

562
00:32:06.100 --> 00:32:09.720
One, do our updates to make sure you know
because who knows when that distro was

00:32:09.720 --> 00:32:14.340
compiled so we downloaded that ISO, got
it installed, but the first thing we need

564
00:32:14.340 --> 00:32:18.140
to do is check and see if we've got

00:32:18.140 --> 00:32:21.840
even upgrades to certain programs or
other things that are compiled in there.

566
00:32:21.840 --> 00:32:26.040
So we did our app get update,
we did our app get upgrade,

we also saw how to configure
that network adapter.

00:32:28.790 --> 00:32:31.770
Gonna be very important to make sure
our machine is on the right network so

569

that we can communicate with the rest of
the network, and have some fun with Kali.

570
00:32:35.810 --> 00:32:37.340
So a lot of good info there.

571
00:32:37.340 --> 00:32:39.780
At this point, we've got a machine

it's on the network and

00:32:43.660 --> 00:32:45.320
start playing with a lot
of those different tools.

574
00:32:45.320 --> 00:32:47.510
Well, I kid,
there's some more stuff we gotta go over.

575
00:32:47.510 --> 00:32:51.370
But looking at the clock, Sean,

576
00:32:51.370 --> 00:32:55.040
So anything else we want to throw

577
00:32:55.040 --> 00:32:58.110
>> Well,
I think we're off to a good start here.

578
00:32:58.110 --> 00:32:59.160
We saw a lot of good stuff.

579
00:33:00.330 --> 00:33:05.050
And just a little old thing to add to
the end of this is one of the cool

580
00:33:05.050 --> 00:33:09.980
things about Kali is that, yeah, you can
configure these network adapters, and

581
00:33:09.980 --> 00:33:12.480
configure hardware and stuff like that.

582
00:33:12.480 --> 00:33:17.240
Typically, if you've got pretty normal
hardware, I guess I should say,

00:33:17.240 --> 00:33:21.290
I mean, stuff that's not exotic

Or legacy even, it's probably just

not need much in the way of tweaking.

But with that being said,

And search out the resources online for

Every notebook I have is a ThinkPad.

ThinkPads have their own thing called a

00:33:46.700 --> 00:33:51.210
That will tell you it's got specs

And it tells you how the different
versions of Linux will act on it.

592
00:33:54.630 --> 00:33:56.850
And what you're gonna need
to do post installation.

593
00:33:56.850 --> 00:34:01.300
And activate touchpads, activate the multi
touch on a touchscreen, stuff like that.

594
00:34:01.300 --> 00:34:02.260
It'll tell you that.

595
00:34:02.260 --> 00:34:05.830
And they have those types of things for
every piece of hardware out there.

596
00:34:05.830 --> 00:34:10.050
So if something doesn't work the right
way, like your bluetooth or wireless or

597
00:34:10.050 --> 00:34:14.320
something else, don't lose heart,
don't get upset or anything else.

598
00:34:14.320 --> 00:34:19.060
Go search those resources out to see
if it's something that you can solve.

599
00:34:19.060 --> 00:34:21.670
Because again, in most cases one
of the cool things about the Linux

600
00:34:21.670 --> 00:34:24.670
community is if you ask,
they're gonna help you.

601
00:34:24.670 --> 00:34:25.690
>> That's exactly what I was gonna say.

602
00:34:25.690 --> 00:34:31.820
One of the great things about Linux is
a very community driven operating system,

603
00:34:31.820 --> 00:34:32.980
and Kali's no exception.

604
00:34:32.980 --> 00:34:36.155
They've got great documentation,
they've got great forums, and

605
00:34:36.155 --> 00:34:38.845
there's always somebody you can
ask if you run into trouble,

606
00:34:38.845 --> 00:34:43.025
or have something that's not working
the way you want it to work.

607
00:34:43.025 --> 00:34:46.395
All right, Sean, well that's about it for
this episode, so we're gonna call it,

608
00:34:46.395 --> 00:34:49.967
and I hope you guys enjoyed the show but
signing off for

00:34:49.967 --> 00:34:52.757
ITProTV I'm Mike Rodrick
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano

610
00:34:52.757 --> 00:34:53.917

00:34:53.917 --> 00:35:00.130

episodes.description: Creating a virtual lab environment is useful for getting to practice the tools within Kali Linux to see what the tools are supposed to produce and what the different results look like. Viewers will hear about creating virtual machines like Metasploitable 2 and Kali Linux and also hear about the practicality and benefits of using them.
episodes.title: Creating a Lab Environment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.079 --> 00:00:10.551
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.551 --> 00:00:13.040
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.040 --> 00:00:16.950
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:16.950 --> 00:00:17.500
How are you Sean?

5
00:00:17.500 --> 00:00:18.730
>> I'm doing awesome.

6
00:00:18.730 --> 00:00:19.380
How you doing?

7
00:00:19.380 --> 00:00:20.750
>> I'm doing fantastic.

8
00:00:20.750 --> 00:00:25.340
We are continuing on with our Kali Linux
series and in this episode we're gonna

9
00:00:25.340 --> 00:00:30.910
take a look at setting up maybe
a little sandbox or an environment

10
00:00:30.910 --> 00:00:35.140
that we can play and use all the cool
things that come with Kali Linux.

11
00:00:35.140 --> 00:00:38.160
So, Sean,
what do you have in store for us here?

12
00:00:38.160 --> 00:00:42.390
>> Well, what we're gonna do here is we're
gonna take a look at setting up a lab so

13
00:00:42.390 --> 00:00:44.030
you can practice your skills.

14
00:00:44.030 --> 00:00:51.300
And so we here have something to demo
against why we are doing our thing.

15
00:00:51.300 --> 00:00:54.580
And anything we're gonna do here
as far as setting up our lab

16
00:00:54.580 --> 00:00:59.290
is gonna be the same type of stuff that
you can do on your own home environment.

17
00:00:59.290 --> 00:01:04.590
Now, you have a choice, you can set up
in a virtual environment like we are or

18
00:01:04.590 --> 00:01:08.560
you can, if you wanna do it that way, you
can set up a bunch of physical machines.

19
00:01:08.560 --> 00:01:11.230
It's really kind of your call.

20
00:01:11.230 --> 00:01:14.630
I just chose to do virtual machines
here because it works, it's easy,

21
00:01:14.630 --> 00:01:18.900
it does everything I need it to for
here, and I'm cool with that.

22
00:01:18.900 --> 00:01:20.070
That's the extent of it.

23
00:01:20.070 --> 00:01:23.740
But I could have taken it further,
but I said, don't need to here.

24
00:01:23.740 --> 00:01:25.010
>> Kind of a pain right?

25
00:01:25.010 --> 00:01:27.640
I mean that's one of the great things
about virtualization nowadays,

26
00:01:27.640 --> 00:01:32.748
most of our machines can handle
running several virtual machines.

27
00:01:32.748 --> 00:01:37.010
I remember way back when, Sean, when I
was going to, that was back in 2003,

28
00:01:37.010 --> 00:01:41.180
I set up a whole test lab,
I had to go out and buy old machines.

29
00:01:41.180 --> 00:01:45.130
So you had four, five, six machines
sitting there, all sucking power,

30
00:01:45.130 --> 00:01:49.540
all generating heat,
KVMs between them, things like that.

31
00:01:49.540 --> 00:01:50.990
Nowadays, virtualize.

32
00:01:50.990 --> 00:01:53.624
My laptop, I can run four or
five different virtual machines and

33
00:01:53.624 --> 00:01:56.670
we can have our entire sandbox
right here on our laptop.

34
00:01:56.670 --> 00:01:58.360
So I think it's really, really good.

35
00:01:58.360 --> 00:02:00.580
But as you said, either way will work.

36
00:02:00.580 --> 00:02:02.050
>> Yeah, it's your call.

37
00:02:02.050 --> 00:02:07.230
And to be honest,
you're gonna find some situations where

38
00:02:07.230 --> 00:02:11.240
having a physical box is really gonna have
to be the way you go to test against, but

39
00:02:11.240 --> 00:02:14.060
it's not gonna be those labs.

40
00:02:14.060 --> 00:02:17.050
I had to do the same thing, you know,
where you had to have that whole,

41
00:02:17.050 --> 00:02:20.015
you felt like you were sitting in
the middle of a server room, you know?

42
00:02:20.015 --> 00:02:21.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> Big wrap around stuff.

43
00:02:21.780 --> 00:02:24.690
I swear my cubicle at my old work looked
like the bridge of the Enterprise with

44
00:02:24.690 --> 00:02:25.810
the way it's wrapped around.

45
00:02:25.810 --> 00:02:29.150
There's so many stuff happening there.

46
00:02:29.150 --> 00:02:30.280
You don't need to do that.

47
00:02:30.280 --> 00:02:33.670
But if you do have a specific
hardware environment or

48
00:02:33.670 --> 00:02:36.420
something unique that you need to
test against that you just can't

49
00:02:36.420 --> 00:02:41.220
emulate properly in a virtual environment,
then yeah, you're gonna need the hardware.

50
00:02:41.220 --> 00:02:43.170
You just have to have it.

51
00:02:43.170 --> 00:02:47.140
If you're going to be doing tests
against maybe wireless access points,

52
00:02:47.140 --> 00:02:50.350
using the stuff here,
you don't necessarily have an effective

53
00:02:50.350 --> 00:02:54.020
way to really emulate that
within a virtual environment.

54
00:02:54.020 --> 00:02:56.930
And I know someone might say,
well you could do this, this, or this.

55
00:02:56.930 --> 00:02:59.150
And you have all these workarounds.

56
00:02:59.150 --> 00:03:02.260
Well I don't wanna have workarounds
in some of these cases.

57
00:03:02.260 --> 00:03:06.890
I wanna actually have the real thing
because that workaround may not

58
00:03:06.890 --> 00:03:09.020
simulate the real environment good enough.

59
00:03:09.020 --> 00:03:10.140
>> It kinda skews your results.

60
00:03:10.140 --> 00:03:11.620
All of a sudden you don't
have the results, or

61
00:03:11.620 --> 00:03:15.481
you're not getting results because
of the actual test not working, or

62
00:03:15.481 --> 00:03:18.250
if it's because of a limitation
of the virtualization.

63
00:03:18.250 --> 00:03:21.250
So there are some times when you do
have to step outside that virtual world.

64
00:03:21.250 --> 00:03:23.880
>> Yeah.
So do absolutely consider that, if that's

65
00:03:23.880 --> 00:03:27.140
gonna be the, if virtualization's
always is gonna be appropriate.

66
00:03:27.140 --> 00:03:31.140
You're gonna find probably as the saying
goes nine times out of ten that it's

67
00:03:31.140 --> 00:03:35.000
probably perfectly fine and
no issues whatsoever, but

68
00:03:35.000 --> 00:03:39.130
there's always going to be those little
things that could very well be a problem.

69
00:03:39.130 --> 00:03:42.830
Some of the wireless stuff
we have doesn't work well or

70
00:03:42.830 --> 00:03:46.720
is very tough to get working in a virtual
environment, so the network interfaces

71
00:03:46.720 --> 00:03:49.820
period can be trouble to get
work in the virtual environment.

72
00:03:49.820 --> 00:03:53.290
Usually, we can get them working but
sometimes little glitches pop up.

73
00:03:53.290 --> 00:03:55.930
And then as far as testing
against other stuff,

74
00:03:55.930 --> 00:04:00.810
it just may not work the way you want
it to and give you the desired results.

75
00:04:00.810 --> 00:04:05.590
So you may have to, occasionally, step
outside of that virtual environment and

76
00:04:05.590 --> 00:04:07.990
get a physical box there.

77
00:04:07.990 --> 00:04:12.450
So just so you know and
we're playing by the rules and all that.

78
00:04:12.450 --> 00:04:16.425
So, once we've addressed that, whether or
not we're going to go physical or virtual,

79
00:04:16.425 --> 00:04:18.598
and we're gonna assume
it's gonna be virtual,

80
00:04:18.598 --> 00:04:20.787
the question is how do you
start setting that up?

81
00:04:20.787 --> 00:04:23.410
Well, you've got a lot of options.

82
00:04:23.410 --> 00:04:25.453
Lots and lots of options.

83
00:04:25.453 --> 00:04:30.412
If one of the things you're gonna be
testing against most of the time is

84
00:04:30.412 --> 00:04:35.287
a system that is configured with
one of the major operating systems,

85
00:04:35.287 --> 00:04:38.227
and is set up so
you can test these tools and

86
00:04:38.227 --> 00:04:42.840
get results from them to see
what those results look like.

87
00:04:42.840 --> 00:04:46.290
It's all well and
good to use something like Kali to target

88
00:04:46.290 --> 00:04:51.650
just our system at random, but if you
target a system at random that tool you

89
00:04:51.650 --> 00:04:56.020
have may not reveal anything because
that vulnerability may not exist there.

90
00:04:56.020 --> 00:04:59.420
So, if you really need to
learn how to use that tool and

91
00:04:59.420 --> 00:05:03.380
see what the results look like when there
is a vulnerability or issue there and

92
00:05:03.380 --> 00:05:06.310
when there isn't,
you don't have that situation.

93
00:05:06.310 --> 00:05:10.169
The other thing is that some of
these environments that you can get,

94
00:05:10.169 --> 00:05:11.262
you can download,

95
00:05:11.262 --> 00:05:14.140
they already have the vulnerabilities
they already have in there,

96
00:05:14.140 --> 00:05:16.850
they document them and tell you, these
are the vulnerabilities that are there.

97
00:05:16.850 --> 00:05:21.080
So if you scan a certain tool and
you get a certain result,

98
00:05:21.080 --> 00:05:23.820
you can compare it to what
they've documented and

99
00:05:23.820 --> 00:05:28.700
see, oh yeah, that's what I should be
getting based on what they've reported.

100
00:05:28.700 --> 00:05:32.110
So it helps you out in
a number of different ways.

101
00:05:32.110 --> 00:05:36.530
Now you don't need to download
one of the pre-made ones,

102
00:05:36.530 --> 00:05:38.320
you could make them yourself.

103
00:05:38.320 --> 00:05:41.000
And some cases that may
be the only way to go.

104
00:05:41.000 --> 00:05:44.920
You may have some unique application
you're gonna be testing against.

105
00:05:44.920 --> 00:05:48.800
You don't have another way to do it
except to create it on your own.

106
00:05:48.800 --> 00:05:51.910
And so you'll need to address that.

107
00:05:51.910 --> 00:05:55.270
And hopefully you can
accomplish it the right way.

108
00:05:55.270 --> 00:05:59.070
But fortunately for the stuff we're gonna
do in here to test the different scanners

109
00:05:59.070 --> 00:06:03.810
and things like that, we're gonna be going
ahead and just using off the shelf, so

110
00:06:03.810 --> 00:06:07.190
to speak, virtual machines and
there's so many of them.

111
00:06:07.190 --> 00:06:11.520
All you've got to do with them is just
drop them in and they're ready to go.

112
00:06:11.520 --> 00:06:16.670
Okay so,
what I've done to help this process

113
00:06:16.670 --> 00:06:22.070
is I already have downloaded one of
the virtual machines that are out there.

114
00:06:22.070 --> 00:06:25.370
I'm gonna tell you which one you
download and that's your call,

115
00:06:25.370 --> 00:06:27.690
which one you choose to download.

116
00:06:27.690 --> 00:06:31.720
I just chose one to download and
put it in here,

117
00:06:31.720 --> 00:06:34.230
just one of the ones we're gonna use.

118
00:06:34.230 --> 00:06:39.410
Something also I'd point out here
too is don't go crazy with these.

119
00:06:39.410 --> 00:06:41.690
I mean you can download
them all no problem, but

120
00:06:41.690 --> 00:06:43.570
don't expect to be running
them all at the same time.

121
00:06:43.570 --> 00:06:46.210
Because unless you've got a ton of memory.

122
00:06:46.210 --> 00:06:48.470
I know there are some people out there,

123
00:06:48.470 --> 00:06:52.850
I heard someone literally last week that
said I've got 64 gigs in my notebook.

124
00:06:52.850 --> 00:06:57.972
When you're like, all right, whatever,
there's always somebody that's got it, so.

125
00:06:57.972 --> 00:06:58.951
[LAUGH]
>> Right.

126
00:06:58.951 --> 00:07:00.355
>> But that's not the norm.

127
00:07:00.355 --> 00:07:01.546
>> That's Ronnie Wong.

128
00:07:01.546 --> 00:07:04.530
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, was that Ronnie over there?

129
00:07:04.530 --> 00:07:05.570
>> Probably.

130
00:07:05.570 --> 00:07:11.840
>> So anyway, so what I'm gonna
do is I have in an VMware player,

131
00:07:11.840 --> 00:07:15.918
I have two virtual machines, which I'm
gonna open them up both on my screen

132
00:07:15.918 --> 00:07:20.460
>> I've got my Metasploitable

133
00:07:20.460 --> 00:07:21.440
sitting up here.

134
00:07:21.440 --> 00:07:26.050
This is a virtual machine
that you can get for free.

135
00:07:26.050 --> 00:07:31.310
You can just Google Metasploitable,
actually Metasploitable 2.

136
00:07:31.310 --> 00:07:36.200
I will show you the link for
it here in just a bit.

137
00:07:36.200 --> 00:07:39.610
But you can download
that just by Googling it.

138
00:07:39.610 --> 00:07:45.380
And then I have my Kali Linux sitting
over here in my virtual machine as well.

139
00:07:45.380 --> 00:07:49.801
So I've got two virtual machines
running in VMWare Player.

140
00:07:49.801 --> 00:07:55.185
So I've got the two out there,
I can see that they're

141
00:07:55.185 --> 00:08:00.100
doing their thing, and
everything looks good.

142
00:08:00.100 --> 00:08:04.579
Well what I can do is,
let me go over here to Metasploitable and

143
00:08:04.579 --> 00:08:10.094
what I'm going to do is in Metasploitable
I'm going to just double check and

144
00:08:10.094 --> 00:08:15.800
I'm gonna see what my IP address is, so
I'm gonna use IF config stuff in here.

145
00:08:15.800 --> 00:08:19.950
And, I'm just gonna do a simple test,
I wanna see if the two can actually talk.

146
00:08:19.950 --> 00:08:21.080
So, that one.

147
00:08:21.080 --> 00:08:24.850
>> It'll make the future tests and
labs a little bit easier to do, right.

148
00:08:24.850 --> 00:08:25.710
>> Yeah.
>> As long as they,

149
00:08:25.710 --> 00:08:26.680
if they can talk to each other.

150
00:08:26.680 --> 00:08:29.260
>> Yeah, they don't talk,
the test become really easy at that point.

151
00:08:29.260 --> 00:08:30.235
So.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

152
00:08:30.235 --> 00:08:34.990
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, so what I'm gonna do is I have,

153
00:08:34.990 --> 00:08:37.530

300
00:16:40.338 --> 00:16:42.798
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

301
00:16:42.798 --> 00:16:44.570
>> I'm not a paid endorser,

302
00:16:44.570 --> 00:16:46.810
as far as you guys know.

303
00:16:46.810 --> 00:16:52.240
I think the free one did, what, Twitter,
and Instagram, or something like that.

304
00:16:52.240 --> 00:16:53.320
This one will pull Facebook.

305
00:16:53.320 --> 00:16:54.770
That one is doing Facebook.

306
00:16:56.440 --> 00:17:00.930
>> So what you're seeing here,
and before I scroll down,

307
00:17:00.930 --> 00:17:04.710
I just always make the disclaimer here,
this is live data.

308
00:17:04.710 --> 00:17:08.260
I have no idea what people post up there.

309
00:17:08.260 --> 00:17:11.633
So I apologize if there's
anything a little questionable.

310
00:17:11.633 --> 00:17:13.897
>> [LAUGH] Right?

311
00:17:13.897 --> 00:17:16.330
>> Anyway, great, someone posted a donut.

312
00:17:16.330 --> 00:17:17.189
Filthy.

313
00:17:17.189 --> 00:17:19.580
>> [LAUGH] Oh,
we're gonna have to delete that one out.

314
00:17:22.100 --> 00:17:23.820
Yeah, there you go.

315
00:17:23.820 --> 00:17:25.280
You've got different things.

316
00:17:25.280 --> 00:17:27.883
I mean, nothing here is really exciting.

317
00:17:27.883 --> 00:17:32.860
Okay, there's people sitting around
a pool out there and and various things,

318
00:17:32.860 --> 00:17:36.200
but you can see the data
is actually pretty current.

319
00:17:36.200 --> 00:17:37.870
I mean, this stuff is today.

320
00:17:37.870 --> 00:17:41.254
I mean, this was put up here so
probably taken, because I

321
00:17:41.254 --> 00:17:45.837
was told from the company that actually
reads the metadata out of the stuff and

322
00:17:45.837 --> 00:17:48.113
that's where it's getting it from.

323
00:17:48.113 --> 00:17:51.668
So you can see in here,
well back on the West Coast,

324
00:17:51.668 --> 00:17:55.475
of course,
it's 2:33 back in California so, and

325
00:17:55.475 --> 00:17:59.810
Nevada's in the same time zone,
so this was ten minutes ago.

326
00:18:00.860 --> 00:18:06.500
So you're getting some pretty
current stuff off of this and

327
00:18:06.500 --> 00:18:08.620
you can filter this stuff down.

328
00:18:08.620 --> 00:18:12.275
I mean, you can take a look, here's where
people checked in using FourSquare.

329
00:18:12.275 --> 00:18:13.830
And we've got that on here so

330
00:18:13.830 --> 00:18:16.330
I've got, and
this is only from the last 7 days, too.

331
00:18:16.330 --> 00:18:23.484
This is some Russian deal and ships, if
they had a ship going down in the middle.

332
00:18:23.484 --> 00:18:24.040
It is Vegas.

333
00:18:24.040 --> 00:18:25.829
So Vegas, if any place could do it.

334
00:18:25.829 --> 00:18:29.158
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

335
00:18:29.158 --> 00:18:31.133
you can gather quite a bit of information.

336
00:18:31.133 --> 00:18:36.770
Now, if I was to pull this part of it out,
let's go some place else

337
00:18:36.770 --> 00:18:41.830
just to see if I can get some more
information, I'll do Waikiki in Hawaii.

338
00:18:44.010 --> 00:18:46.290
Just because I'm going to Hawaii Monday.

339
00:18:46.290 --> 00:18:50.590
I'm using this as an excuse to check
out where I'm going to be staying.

340
00:18:50.590 --> 00:18:54.350
And I'm making you guys think
it's actually, well, hey,

341
00:18:54.350 --> 00:18:55.835
he's showing us a lot.

342
00:18:55.835 --> 00:18:59.940
But what's happening here is so
it reveals information.

343
00:18:59.940 --> 00:19:04.730
I was actually trying to get it to pop up
some Facebook stuff, but it's not doing so

344
00:19:04.730 --> 00:19:05.280
right now.

345
00:19:05.280 --> 00:19:09.510
It's still bringing some things up, I can
see some YouTube information up there.

346
00:19:09.510 --> 00:19:12.440
But you will see, in some situations,

347
00:19:12.440 --> 00:19:15.880
you will see Facebook
stuff pop up on the list.

348
00:19:15.880 --> 00:19:22.901
And so here again, I'm seeing
stuff that is relatively current.

349
00:19:22.901 --> 00:19:29.355
So there you go, this type of
stuff is the stuff that Ecosec

350
00:19:29.355 --> 00:19:35.230
doesn't have a tool or sorry, Kali doesn't
have a tool built in directly for it.

351
00:19:35.230 --> 00:19:38.000
But, you can get access to it.

352
00:19:38.000 --> 00:19:40.290
So, yeah, you've got a browser,

353
00:19:40.290 --> 00:19:44.820
you can install the browsers
that you want in there.

354
00:19:44.820 --> 00:19:51.130
So, you can get quite a bit of stuff
out of this if you really wanted to.

355
00:19:51.130 --> 00:19:56.250
So, this is just another tool
that's helpful for that.

356
00:19:56.250 --> 00:19:58.320
>> So a lot to the reconnaissance phase.

357
00:19:58.320 --> 00:20:00.050
That's when we're gathering information.

358
00:20:00.050 --> 00:20:01.469
If we're doing that pentest.

359
00:20:01.469 --> 00:20:05.023
We're being a bad guy, well,
depending if you're doing a white hat or

360
00:20:05.023 --> 00:20:07.250
a black hat type test or what have you.

361
00:20:07.250 --> 00:20:10.042
But you're gathering
information about your target,

362
00:20:10.042 --> 00:20:12.550
about your victim, if you will.

363
00:20:12.550 --> 00:20:15.715
Bunch of tools built right in
to Kali that let me do that.

364
00:20:15.715 --> 00:20:18.665
You've got tools outside of
Kali that I can access as well,

365
00:20:18.665 --> 00:20:22.810
so it really makes it pretty easy to
start gathering that information.

366
00:20:22.810 --> 00:20:28.575
>> Yeah, you're just, again, the process
that you're looking at, I mean, some

367
00:20:28.575 --> 00:20:33.107
of you probably out there are probably
like, oh, yeah, I remember Ecosec.

368
00:20:33.107 --> 00:20:39.165
It was done for really a good number of
reasons, the big ones being that, first

369
00:20:39.165 --> 00:20:43.117
of all, I know some of you hadn't seen
that, because there's new names in there.

370
00:20:43.117 --> 00:20:46.355
And that made, that went with us live last
time, maybe you watched the recordings for

371
00:20:46.355 --> 00:20:50.150
the CEH, I don't know,
>> But if you hadn't seen it, okay,

372
00:20:50.150 --> 00:20:51.070
now you've seen it.

373
00:20:51.070 --> 00:20:55.030
But that's something that you have
available through reconnaissance.

374
00:20:55.030 --> 00:20:58.540
But you also can see that that's stuff

375
00:20:58.540 --> 00:21:01.430
that you can access from
right inside of Kali.

376
00:21:01.430 --> 00:21:03.500
It's just gonna go ahead and enhance it.

377
00:21:03.500 --> 00:21:07.590
And then another one that fits in
there is the process hasn't changed.

378
00:21:07.590 --> 00:21:11.390
The stuff that we taught you over in CEH,
or stuff that you

379
00:21:11.390 --> 00:21:16.370
may already do from pentesting,
the process is close enough that you

380
00:21:16.370 --> 00:21:20.800
should know the types of things you can
be looking for at any specific spot.

381
00:21:20.800 --> 00:21:22.890
It's just what tools
are you using to do that?

382
00:21:22.890 --> 00:21:24.510
You may use different tools, but

383
00:21:24.510 --> 00:21:28.080
you're trying to gather the same types
of information at a certain spot.

384
00:21:28.080 --> 00:21:32.480
So when I say you are doing
reconnaissance on a target,

385
00:21:33.560 --> 00:21:38.530
you should know what you can reasonably
expect to be gathering at that point.

386
00:21:38.530 --> 00:21:43.310
So that's where that fits in is that yeah,
things have changed into a different

387
00:21:43.310 --> 00:21:48.510
environment, but it's not oh, well,
hey, I've gotta relearn everything.

388
00:21:48.510 --> 00:21:51.030
No, you can still use
a lot of these things.

389
00:21:51.030 --> 00:21:52.770
>> Very good, very good.

390
00:21:52.770 --> 00:21:53.400
All right, well, Sean,

391
00:21:53.400 --> 00:21:56.370
looking at the clock it's about
time to wrap up this episode.

392
00:21:56.370 --> 00:22:00.690
I know we talked a lot about that first
phase, we've got several phases to go.

393
00:22:00.690 --> 00:22:04.925
Anything else you wanna throw in on
reconnaissance before we wrap it up?

394
00:22:04.925 --> 00:22:08.735
>> I'd say this was just a quick
thing on reconnaissance.

395
00:22:08.735 --> 00:22:13.785
We'll talk more about the flushing
out of the reconnaissance process and

396
00:22:13.785 --> 00:22:16.280
look at these tools for all these phases.

397
00:22:16.280 --> 00:22:19.199
We'll look more in depth at these tools,
so don't think we're just glossing over it

398
00:22:19.199 --> 00:22:22.197
and saying, oh, well, we're not gonna
cover anything except yeah, here's a tool,

399
00:22:22.197 --> 00:22:24.087
here's a tool, here's a tool,
hey, see you later.

400
00:22:24.087 --> 00:22:27.030
Go look at CH,
it's not gonna be like that.

401
00:22:27.030 --> 00:22:29.726
If I can get paid the same amount,
I'd be out of here, right, so.

402
00:22:29.726 --> 00:22:34.780
>> [LAUGH] Right, yeah, first, so we got
that high level of review going on, and

403
00:22:34.780 --> 00:22:39.160
then we're gonna break them down a little
bit more in depth, as the episodes go on.

404
00:22:39.160 --> 00:22:42.390
So make sure you're sticking with us for
future episodes, but

405
00:22:42.390 --> 00:22:45.570
for now, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

406
00:22:45.570 --> 00:22:46.310
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

407
00:22:46.310 --> 00:22:47.821
>> And we'll see you soon.

408
00:22:47.821 --> 00:22:53.690
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: After one has gathered information on a target to perform a penetration test on, one can then begin to act upon that information. Viewers will hear a high level overview on the rest of the phases involved in performing a penetration test, which include the scanning, exploitation/gaining access, maintaining access, and reporting phases.
episodes.title: Penetration Testing Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.531 --> 00:00:15.730
Hello and welcome,
to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.730 --> 00:00:18.450
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:18.450 --> 00:00:19.770
How are you, Sean?

5
00:00:19.770 --> 00:00:20.690
>> I am doing pretty good.

6
00:00:20.690 --> 00:00:21.550
How about you?

7
00:00:21.550 --> 00:00:22.670
>> I'm doing fantastic.

8
00:00:22.670 --> 00:00:24.670
We got another exciting
episode coming your way,

9
00:00:24.670 --> 00:00:27.990
continuing on with our Kali Linux series.

10
00:00:27.990 --> 00:00:32.810
And we left off, Sean, a previous episode
talking about some of the phases involved

11
00:00:32.810 --> 00:00:35.650
in doing a penetration test,
and doing a little compare and

12
00:00:35.650 --> 00:00:38.460
contrast between what we've got here and

13
00:00:38.460 --> 00:00:43.400
maybe some of the other vendor specific
penetration models, if you will.

14
00:00:43.400 --> 00:00:49.090
>> Yeah, and that's the thing we're
trying to emphasize in the previous

15
00:00:49.090 --> 00:00:52.990
section was that, when we talked about
doing that reconnaissance is that yeah,

16
00:00:52.990 --> 00:00:58.170
there's this whole process is broken
up into steps, and each step you,

17
00:00:58.170 --> 00:01:02.450
or phase, you have something specific that
you're trying to accomplish before you

18
00:01:02.450 --> 00:01:06.920
move on to the next phase of the process.

19
00:01:06.920 --> 00:01:10.809
The question is, which tools are you going
to use, and how are you gonna approach it?

20
00:01:11.870 --> 00:01:13.770
And why every vendor calls
it something different.

21
00:01:13.770 --> 00:01:17.473
Some vendors actually throw
some additional things into it,

22
00:01:17.473 --> 00:01:19.170
that others don't.

23
00:01:19.170 --> 00:01:23.390
Some vendors you might see five steps.

24
00:01:23.390 --> 00:01:25.430
The other one might have seven steps.

25
00:01:25.430 --> 00:01:29.065
The other one have 12 steps,
no 12 steps is something else.

26
00:01:29.065 --> 00:01:29.934
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

27
00:01:29.934 --> 00:01:32.996
they'll have all different
series of steps in it.

28
00:01:32.996 --> 00:01:37.250
So like I said, I said before, and

29
00:01:37.250 --> 00:01:41.310
I'll say it again, is just try to remember
what you need to be accomplishing,

30
00:01:41.310 --> 00:01:43.220
the sequence that you go through.

31
00:01:43.220 --> 00:01:47.830
If you wanna break it into more
steps than that, I don't care.

32
00:01:47.830 --> 00:01:51.480
If it's your gig, go for it.

33
00:01:51.480 --> 00:01:54.317
If you wanna do it that way,
not a problem.

34
00:01:54.317 --> 00:01:58.803
Well, going through with that,
with that thinking,

35
00:01:58.803 --> 00:02:03.777
we did reconnaissance, so
we've gotten information about

36
00:02:03.777 --> 00:02:08.751
what our target looks like,
where they might be employees,

37
00:02:08.751 --> 00:02:11.703
things like that- [CROSSTALK]
>> DNS names,

38
00:02:11.703 --> 00:02:15.100
all kinds of good stuff like that, so
we got a lot of information about them.

39
00:02:15.100 --> 00:02:16.950
>> Yeah, you could have gathered,

40
00:02:16.950 --> 00:02:21.350
just a tremendous amount,
about that specific target.

41
00:02:21.350 --> 00:02:23.250
The next question that comes in,

42
00:02:23.250 --> 00:02:26.800
is how do you act on it, and
that's the scanning phase.

43
00:02:26.800 --> 00:02:32.650
Where we start really seeing what that
information translates over into,

44
00:02:32.650 --> 00:02:34.010
if you will.

45
00:02:34.010 --> 00:02:36.110
When you go into your reconnaissance,

46
00:02:36.110 --> 00:02:40.620
you found ranges of IPs,
DNS information, stuff like that.

47
00:02:40.620 --> 00:02:44.020
Now you're going over and saying, okay
well let me start scanning some of those

48
00:02:44.020 --> 00:02:48.410
things that I found to see what's really
there, maybe narrow down the target and

49
00:02:48.410 --> 00:02:53.200
kinda firm things up for the point where
I'm gonna actually strike at that target.

50
00:02:53.200 --> 00:02:58.920
So some really, really important stuff to
do here, and remember there's not just

51
00:02:58.920 --> 00:03:04.610
one way of scanning either, there's
a myriad of ways of scanning a system.

52
00:03:04.610 --> 00:03:09.440
You can do port scanning,
you can do ping sweeps,

53
00:03:09.440 --> 00:03:13.230
you can do vulnerability scanning
if you want, just to name a few.

54
00:03:13.230 --> 00:03:14.650
You have options.

55
00:03:15.920 --> 00:03:19.020
>> Yeah, and so we're just basically
taking that information that we gather in

56
00:03:19.020 --> 00:03:23.000
the reconnaissance phase,
that becomes the deliverable if you will,

57
00:03:23.000 --> 00:03:26.220
for that next phase, and
now we go into our scanning.

58
00:03:26.220 --> 00:03:28.770
Like you said that's a great example,
take that IP address range.

59
00:03:28.770 --> 00:03:32.600
I discovered the range doing my
reconnaissance, maybe I found out what

60
00:03:32.600 --> 00:03:34.975
block they had registered with the IANA,
or something like that.

61
00:03:34.975 --> 00:03:37.705
But now how many do they actually use,
right?

62
00:03:37.705 --> 00:03:38.795
Which ones are alive.

63
00:03:38.795 --> 00:03:41.405
Which ones am I actually
gonna find on that system?

64
00:03:41.405 --> 00:03:42.865
So that's where the scanning
phase comes in.

65
00:03:42.865 --> 00:03:46.125
This is where we start taking
that information we gathered, and

66
00:03:46.125 --> 00:03:48.635
start seeing what part of it's useful.

67
00:03:48.635 --> 00:03:50.995
What can I get from that information.

68
00:03:50.995 --> 00:03:53.200
>> Yeah, that's the name of the game.

69
00:03:53.200 --> 00:03:57.260
Where we've gotten to the point where
we're more actively engaging the system,

70
00:03:57.260 --> 00:04:00.120
and we're seeing really
what's behind there.

71
00:04:00.120 --> 00:04:01.730
We don't just have a pile of information.

72
00:04:01.730 --> 00:04:07.290
Now we gotta sort through it, and really
start figuring out what that really means,

73
00:04:07.290 --> 00:04:11.280
what do they have, so
I can take it a step further.

74
00:04:11.280 --> 00:04:14.840
You don't just wanna go through and carpet
bomb, cuz that's really all you could do

75
00:04:14.840 --> 00:04:19.030
with what you have in the reconnaissance
phase, is you carpet bomb.

76
00:04:19.030 --> 00:04:22.590
Or it'd be the equivalent of just
stumbling around in a dark room.

77
00:04:23.640 --> 00:04:25.510
Looking for a penny or
something on the floor,

78
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:27.278
you're gonna find it eventually, but.

79
00:04:27.278 --> 00:04:29.530
>> [LAUGH]
>> Someone's gonna go in there and go,

80
00:04:29.530 --> 00:04:31.220
what the heck are you doing?

81
00:04:31.220 --> 00:04:32.930
So you don't want that.

82
00:04:32.930 --> 00:04:36.040
So you want to be much more precise and
really know what you're dealing with, so

83
00:04:36.040 --> 00:04:38.430
scanning's going to
help you out with that.

84
00:04:38.430 --> 00:04:45.050
Fortunately, Kali has a lot
of stuff up it's sleeve.

85
00:04:45.050 --> 00:04:48.290
To help us with that scanning process,
kinda like what you'd expect.

86
00:04:48.290 --> 00:04:53.100
It has just a bunch of
different tools to help us out.

87
00:04:53.100 --> 00:04:57.530
So we can just quickly take a look at
some of the things that we're gonna see,

88
00:04:57.530 --> 00:05:01.950
some of which we're gonna see and
work with in a later section.

89
00:05:01.950 --> 00:05:03.220
But just to kind of give you an idea,

90
00:05:03.220 --> 00:05:06.340
the types of stuff that we have
to address this specific need,

91
00:05:06.340 --> 00:05:09.810
some of the ones you've seen before,
at least you know what they do.

92
00:05:09.810 --> 00:05:13.370
They just go under a different name,
or do things a little differently, but

93
00:05:13.370 --> 00:05:17.130
the process overall is
accomplishing the same task.

94
00:05:17.130 --> 00:05:21.510
If you go under information gathering, cuz
scanning really is the same type of thing.

95
00:05:21.510 --> 00:05:26.200
It's information gathering, it's just a
more active form of information gathering.

96
00:05:26.200 --> 00:05:29.150
So as far as Kali's concerned,
what do we have?

97
00:05:29.150 --> 00:05:33.620
Well we've got, first of all
this live host identification.

98
00:05:33.620 --> 00:05:38.580
Well you know what that is, that's where
we're doing, we have a range of IPs and

99
00:05:38.580 --> 00:05:42.570
we're just saying, okay, which ones of
those actually have something living

100
00:05:42.570 --> 00:05:47.710
behind it, so we have lots of
tools that can do that for us.

101
00:05:47.710 --> 00:05:52.820
And if you really look through it,
we've got one that we used all the time.

102
00:05:52.820 --> 00:05:58.101
Right on down the list we have
nmap's sitting right there.

103
00:05:58.101 --> 00:06:03.250
I told you in the CEH, told you, you are
not getting away from nmap at this point,

104
00:06:03.250 --> 00:06:06.700
if you don't have it in
your suite of tools,

105
00:06:06.700 --> 00:06:09.460
it's gonna have to get there really quick.

106
00:06:09.460 --> 00:06:12.115
>> It's kind of impressive they actually
have the GUI version on there too.

107
00:06:12.115 --> 00:06:13.320
They got Zenmap as well [LAUGH].

108
00:06:13.320 --> 00:06:16.860
>> Yeah, I was gonna mention that, they
have Zenmap right there at the bottom too.

109
00:06:16.860 --> 00:06:19.460
I scrolled the menu down,
it's right there.

110
00:06:20.530 --> 00:06:22.770
Zenmap, so you do have that.

111
00:06:22.770 --> 00:06:24.910
But remember the limitation with Zenmap.

112
00:06:24.910 --> 00:06:27.200
You can't do everything through Zenmap.

113
00:06:28.460 --> 00:06:31.410
So that would be kind
of a deal breaker on-

00:31:21.540 --> 00:31:25.780
Well anyway, hope you guys enjoyed

572
00:31:25.780 --> 00:31:26.980

00:31:26.980 --> 00:31:27.940

575
00:31:28.670 --> 00:31:31.870
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: Some information that can be pulled from a target during the reconnaissance phase of a penetration test can include IP addresses, DNS information, operating system information, and much more. Viewers will hear a more in-depth explanation on the reconnaissance phase and some of the tools that can be used in the process.
episodes.title: What is Recon

Open source,

But just keep that in mind.

163

So, as far as the Open Source stuff goes,

Recall that was your stuff like your

00:08:51.670 --> 00:08:55.690
Looking through all those types of things,

Well, there's a lot of other stuff that we

One of the things we're gonna look at for

We're gonna look at tools that can

00:09:30.790 --> 00:09:35.560
We know about meta data from our CEH and

now we're gonna see yet another way

cuz we looked at the CEH off

>> Right.
>> We're gonna look at it in the case

of PDFs and Words and

181
00:09:49.850 --> 00:09:55.510
So we can start getting information, maybe

182

Because they publish it out there and,

183
00:09:58.570 --> 00:10:02.060
>> It is amazing how much information
is available if you know where to look.

184
00:10:02.060 --> 00:10:05.040
It's not like you're breaking into
anything, you're not hacking anything.

185
00:10:05.040 --> 00:10:08.970
It's just there and if you know where
to look, you can get that information.

186
00:10:08.970 --> 00:10:11.900
And one of the problems, if people
don't realize that when they publish

information is going along with it.

188
00:10:14.730 --> 00:10:16.690
Most of them don't anyway.

189
00:10:16.690 --> 00:10:20.060
And like you said, we're not really
breaking the law or doing anything.

190
00:10:20.060 --> 00:10:22.880
We're just gathering
information at this point.

191
00:10:22.880 --> 00:10:29.390
>> Yeah, all of this stuff is 100% legal,

192

00:10:31.570 --> 00:10:33.030
It's kind of funny that

00:10:33.030 --> 00:10:36.870
People always ask that because they're
stunned about the amount of information

00:10:36.870 --> 00:10:41.010

197
00:10:44.170 --> 00:10:50.180
Whenever I actually do that course live in

198
00:10:50.180 --> 00:10:52.890
The people that have seen that for

199
00:10:52.890 --> 00:10:59.290
So for the Open Source stuff, it's stuff

200

00:11:05.610 --> 00:11:08.910
So that's the Open Source stuff.

We also have technical stuff we can get,

That's all your tools for

One thing you're gonna see in Kali

00:12:00.120 --> 00:12:01.610

218
00:12:01.610 --> 00:12:04.310
And it's another area to
