00:24:05.853 --> 00:24:10.420
very good product, and how it gains
information, how quickly it does it.

444
00:24:10.420 --> 00:24:15.160
But the most valuable aspect of that is
not only can it get that information, but

445
00:24:15.160 --> 00:24:16.670
it can bring everything together and

446
00:24:16.670 --> 00:24:20.110
show you the linkages and show you this
relates to this and this and this.

447
00:24:20.110 --> 00:24:25.930
And you can even use that to
fill in those missing pieces.

448
00:24:25.930 --> 00:24:28.620
So you're gonna have to learn how
to do an inference on this and

449
00:24:28.620 --> 00:24:30.060
bring all this information together.

450
00:24:30.060 --> 00:24:32.250
None of the stuff lives on its own.

451
00:24:32.250 --> 00:24:35.260
And so that's what we're gonna be doing.

452
00:24:35.260 --> 00:24:38.300
So we go through these tools and
we're going through different sections and

453
00:24:38.300 --> 00:24:41.360
they were kind of doing a little bit
overview here of what the spec of

454
00:24:41.360 --> 00:24:44.630
the reconnaissance process and
some things to be aware of.

455
00:24:44.630 --> 00:24:47.430
When we go through these different
sections we're gonna take a look at how to

456
00:24:47.430 --> 00:24:52.930
uncover network information, and then
we're gonna look at doing website stuff,

457
00:24:52.930 --> 00:24:56.560
and how to interact with that, and
extract information from those.

458
00:24:56.560 --> 00:25:00.700
Remember even though those are being
done in different segments,

459
00:25:00.700 --> 00:25:03.350
those things do relate to one another.

460
00:25:03.350 --> 00:25:05.280
And you're gonna have to bring them and
tie them all together and

461
00:25:05.280 --> 00:25:08.200
say okay yeah I can see how they fit and
work.

462
00:25:08.200 --> 00:25:12.500
>> And when you talk about inference,
sometimes what you're looking for

463
00:25:12.500 --> 00:25:15.980
you might not actually have, but
from the other data that I've gathered,

464
00:25:15.980 --> 00:25:18.830
I might be able to figure
out what I'm missing there.

465
00:25:18.830 --> 00:25:20.970
Kind of fill in those blanks then.

466
00:25:20.970 --> 00:25:25.480
>> Yeah, but if you get enough
information, even though you're missing

467
00:25:25.480 --> 00:25:32.110
something you can kind of see what's
missing and make a pretty good guess.

468
00:25:32.110 --> 00:25:36.930
Way I'd look at it is that
if you got a puzzle that

469
00:25:36.930 --> 00:25:41.930
you're putting together, if you want
to have all the pieces, but, if I

470
00:25:41.930 --> 00:25:46.930
pull out one of those pieces from that
box and hide it and you put it together,

471
00:25:46.930 --> 00:25:51.300
even thought that piece is gone you
can see what the hole looks like.

472
00:25:51.300 --> 00:25:54.010
And you can make a guess
from the colors and

473
00:25:54.010 --> 00:25:58.985
patterns in the pieces around it kinda
sorta what's on that missing piece.

474
00:25:58.985 --> 00:26:05.348
That's a way to visualize this whole
thing, it's developing that skill.

475
00:26:05.348 --> 00:26:09.798
Now the thing is, is that if I, with that
same puzzle analogy if I take five or

476
00:26:09.798 --> 00:26:12.305
six pieces or
ten pieces out of the puzzle,

477
00:26:12.305 --> 00:26:15.383
depending on how many pieces
are in there of course.

478
00:26:15.383 --> 00:26:19.607
If I take a good number of them out of
there and hide them we'll now you've got

479
00:26:19.607 --> 00:26:22.577
a big chunk and
you can't really get sort of an idea but

480
00:26:22.577 --> 00:26:27.575
not as clear because you got a big thing
instead of something like this missing.

481
00:26:27.575 --> 00:26:32.855
>> The more information I gather makes it
easier to infer what the missing stuff is.

482
00:26:32.855 --> 00:26:34.265
>> Yeah exactly.

483
00:26:34.265 --> 00:26:38.275
The thing here is that we have so
many tools in Kali that can

484
00:26:38.275 --> 00:26:41.435
dig through things and
investigate things in so many ways.

485
00:26:41.435 --> 00:26:45.450
In fact,
I saw the number in there last night,

486
00:26:45.450 --> 00:26:49.910
there's over 300 tools in Kali and
I don't even think that's really fair.

487
00:26:49.910 --> 00:26:51.260
I'm like, that seems kind of low.

488
00:26:51.260 --> 00:26:57.580
Cuz, and believe it or not, there's tools
in Kali that aren't even on the menu.

489
00:26:57.580 --> 00:27:00.360
They couldn't even get them all
in the menus they're just like

490
00:27:00.360 --> 00:27:01.680
just throw them in there we're done.

491
00:27:01.680 --> 00:27:04.580
You picture the guy hasn't
seen his wife in three months,

492
00:27:04.580 --> 00:27:08.580
his family, just put it in there
they'll find it, I'm going home.

493
00:27:08.580 --> 00:27:10.959
There are other things in there.

494
00:27:10.959 --> 00:27:15.448
The challenge for you is going to be with
all these tools is which ones are going to

495
00:27:15.448 --> 00:27:18.664
get you the most value because
you can spend a lot of time,

496
00:27:18.664 --> 00:27:21.953
waste a lot of time going
through all of this information.

497
00:27:21.953 --> 00:27:27.673
And getting stuff that either is not
really have immediate value to you or

498
00:27:27.673 --> 00:27:30.270
really any value at all.

499
00:27:30.270 --> 00:27:31.420
That does happen.

500
00:27:31.420 --> 00:27:35.060
Expect to get some information that,
at the end of the day

501
00:27:35.060 --> 00:27:39.450
means nothing as far as helping you
through the penetration process.

502
00:27:39.450 --> 00:27:42.130
So, you're gonna have to kind
of do that with experience.

503
00:27:42.130 --> 00:27:46.110
But Kali has so many tools that's easy
to say let me try this, let me do this,

504
00:27:46.110 --> 00:27:46.729
let me do this.

505
00:27:48.640 --> 00:27:49.800
>> Experiment.
>> You're gonna have to, yeah.

506
00:27:49.800 --> 00:27:53.410
You're gonna want to experiment,
try this out, a lot of these ones out.

507
00:27:53.410 --> 00:27:55.510
But ultimately you're going to find,

508
00:27:55.510 --> 00:27:59.700
there's a small number of ones you use,
and you know what to expect, and

509
00:27:59.700 --> 00:28:02.910
you have those other ones
as back ups if you need to.

510
00:28:02.910 --> 00:28:07.210
And by the way, one of the things you've
got with Kali like you do with all

511
00:28:07.210 --> 00:28:10.670
versions of Linux, there's nothing saying
you couldn't script this stuff to.

512
00:28:10.670 --> 00:28:14.397
So if you wanted to run several of
them at a time, you couldn't do that.

513
00:28:14.397 --> 00:28:17.105
So, that we're not gonna worry
about showing that here.

514
00:28:17.105 --> 00:28:20.155
That's something else we'll
talk at a later date.

515
00:28:20.155 --> 00:28:23.105
But you could do that sort of thing,
but still you're only gonna run

516
00:28:23.105 --> 00:28:27.585
a selected amount of tools to
get the information you need.

517
00:28:27.585 --> 00:28:30.865
And remember, if you go back to our CDH,
we said about setting goals.

518
00:28:30.865 --> 00:28:36.060
Once you set the goals and met those
goals, just go ahead and push on.

519
00:28:36.060 --> 00:28:39.440
So, that's what
the reconnaissance process is,

520
00:28:39.440 --> 00:28:44.720
just to kind of get you
oriented where Kali fits in and

521
00:28:44.720 --> 00:28:48.275
to kind of do a refresher on
what we're going to be doing.

522
00:28:48.275 --> 00:28:49.860
>> Good deal, all right.

523
00:28:49.860 --> 00:28:51.720
Well, ladies and gentlemen,
I'll tell you what looking at the clock,

524
00:28:51.720 --> 00:28:52.620
we are about out of time.

525
00:28:52.620 --> 00:28:56.520
I feel like we gotta a good idea about
what reconnaissance is all about.

526
00:28:56.520 --> 00:28:59.200
In episodes coming up, we are going
to dive into reconnaissance and

527
00:28:59.200 --> 00:29:01.460
take a look at a few of those tools.

528
00:29:01.460 --> 00:29:04.160
Both for now,
we're gonna sign off from ITProTV.

529
00:29:04.160 --> 00:29:06.248
So I'm Mike Roderick and I'm Sean Oriyano.

530
00:29:06.248 --> 00:29:07.862
And we'll see you next time.

531
00:29:07.862 --> 00:29:13.320
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: A big part of the reconnaissance phase is gathering information on one's targets, so gaining information about the network that one's targets run on is going to be a part of that. Viewers will see demonstrations on using the Whois and NsLookup tools and hear about some of the information one can discover during the reconnaissance phase like IP ranges and subnet ranges, which are good to have when proceeding to the scanning phase.
episodes.title: Uncovering Network Info
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.840
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.840 --> 00:00:13.720
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.720 --> 00:00:17.350
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and with me
today is none other than Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:17.350 --> 00:00:18.370
How you doing Sean?

5
00:00:18.370 --> 00:00:19.120
>> Doing pretty good.

6
00:00:19.120 --> 00:00:20.010
How are you doing today?

7
00:00:20.010 --> 00:00:21.090
>> I'm doing fantastic.

8
00:00:21.090 --> 00:00:24.010
We are continuing with
our Kali Linux series.

9
00:00:24.010 --> 00:00:27.210
In this episode we're gonna take
a look at some of the information

10
00:00:27.210 --> 00:00:29.600
that we can uncover or discover.

11
00:00:29.600 --> 00:00:31.580
During our recognizance phase and

12
00:00:31.580 --> 00:00:35.260
in particular we're going to be looking at
network information that we can discover.

13
00:00:35.260 --> 00:00:37.740
One of the big parts of
the recognizance phase,

14
00:00:37.740 --> 00:00:40.550
is gathering information on our
targets and that's going to

15
00:00:40.550 --> 00:00:43.780
include information about the network
that our targets running on, right Sean?

16
00:00:43.780 --> 00:00:47.140
>> Yeah, that's exactly it is
that we're going to get in and

17
00:00:47.140 --> 00:00:51.505
start looking at what the network looks
like, seeing what we can discover

18
00:00:51.505 --> 00:00:56.520
about it because we really don't
know anything at this point.

19
00:00:56.520 --> 00:01:00.890
Remember, well we could, and I guess
it's fair to back up just a bit and

20
00:01:00.890 --> 00:01:04.560
give a brief explanation here
before we start doing this.

21
00:01:04.560 --> 00:01:08.630
Remember, the client could be
giving you a black box, grey box or

22
00:01:08.630 --> 00:01:13.270
white box test,
If they give you a white box test and

23
00:01:13.270 --> 00:01:16.430
you've got a lot of this
information as it is.

24
00:01:16.430 --> 00:01:22.430
The gray box, limited information, black
box by definition you don't get anything.

25
00:01:22.430 --> 00:01:27.220
So, depending on where you're starting
you may already have some of this.

26
00:01:27.220 --> 00:01:29.630
Now what we're gonna kinda assume here,

27
00:01:29.630 --> 00:01:35.270
is we're just kinda gonna assume we're in
sort of a semi-quasi black box environment

28
00:01:35.270 --> 00:01:40.290
when we are running these things,
and just leave it at that.

29
00:01:40.290 --> 00:01:43.830
But you could have one of these other
situations where they've given you

30
00:01:43.830 --> 00:01:47.670
other bits of information along
the way and said yeah, here you go.

31
00:01:47.670 --> 00:01:52.710
But, when you encounter that you know-
>> Just

32
00:01:52.710 --> 00:01:54.040
consider yourself lucky and go whoa!

33
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:55.650
There's a few things I
don't have to figure out,

34
00:01:55.650 --> 00:01:58.110
they've already given
me some of the answers.

35
00:01:58.110 --> 00:01:59.220
It's good to know how to find it.

36
00:01:59.220 --> 00:02:00.630
What if they don't give
you anything right?

37
00:02:00.630 --> 00:02:04.000
You've gotta start from scratch as you're
saying, the good 'ole black box test.

38
00:02:04.000 --> 00:02:08.050
You don't know anything about, hey,
they might give you the domain name and

39
00:02:08.050 --> 00:02:09.570
that might be it.

40
00:02:09.570 --> 00:02:13.100
>> Yep, it's something to really think
about is what information might they

41
00:02:13.100 --> 00:02:17.040
really be giving you from the get-go.

42
00:02:17.040 --> 00:02:20.400
And I would also kind of caution you,
by the way.

43
00:02:20.400 --> 00:02:23.830
Don't think, just because you
have a white box, or gray box,

44
00:02:23.830 --> 00:02:29.020
you're completely off the hook for doing
a lot of the stuff that we have here.

45
00:02:29.020 --> 00:02:31.400
They may give you print outs of that or

46
00:02:31.400 --> 00:02:35.520
give you whatever that tells
you what things look like.

47
00:02:35.520 --> 00:02:40.170
You may still want to run these things
just because you want to see what someone

48
00:02:40.170 --> 00:02:42.760
that isn't in your situation
is going to be able to see.

49
00:02:42.760 --> 00:02:46.030
You know,
because you're still responsible for that.

50
00:02:46.030 --> 00:02:51.480
If they give you a muti page Word document
saying this is how everything is set up,

51
00:02:51.480 --> 00:02:52.330
hey, that's great.

52
00:02:52.330 --> 00:02:54.250
You have got the whole
layout of everything.

53
00:02:54.250 --> 00:02:56.910
That should make your job easier, but

54
00:02:56.910 --> 00:02:59.340
you still are going to have to run
some of these things to see well,

55
00:02:59.340 --> 00:03:02.940
this is what is behind the scenes
that the public doesn't see.

56
00:03:02.940 --> 00:03:06.540
If someone uses these tools, how much
of this information could they get.

57
00:03:06.540 --> 00:03:08.810
So you still need to do that.

58
00:03:08.810 --> 00:03:13.140
But just FYI,
that we do have different situations.

59
00:03:13.140 --> 00:03:16.380
We're kinda sorta in a black
box environment right now.

60
00:03:16.380 --> 00:03:21.250
Even though we're gonna
break the rules on that and

61
00:03:21.250 --> 00:03:23.210
jump back and forth when we're talking.

62
00:03:23.210 --> 00:03:27.427
In the real world what we're doing
here would kind of fit in with

63
00:03:27.427 --> 00:03:29.345
a black box type situation.

64
00:03:29.345 --> 00:03:30.715
>> All right.

65
00:03:30.715 --> 00:03:34.914
Yeah, so they might not give you, or
even if they give you the information, but

66
00:03:34.914 --> 00:03:38.611
as you said, just because they gave
it to you, they still wanna know,

67
00:03:38.611 --> 00:03:41.450
could somebody get this if
we didn't give it to them?

68
00:03:41.450 --> 00:03:43.200
There's the idea there.

69
00:03:43.200 --> 00:03:44.000
>> Exactly.
>> All right, so

70
00:03:44.000 --> 00:03:45.810
we start off with nothing again.

71
00:03:45.810 --> 00:03:48.760
Because we're doing this as a lab
environment we're gonna actually see

72
00:03:48.760 --> 00:03:50.570
both sides of things, but remember,

73
00:03:50.570 --> 00:03:54.450
out there in the real world doing your
pen test, you might not have that luxury.

74
00:03:54.450 --> 00:03:58.400
You might be on the outside looking in and
you've gotta find your way,

75
00:03:58.400 --> 00:04:01.850
fumble through the dark, and
figure out what the heck's going on.

76
00:04:01.850 --> 00:04:04.890
>> Yeah, so we've gotta start
letting the rubber hit the road and

77
00:04:04.890 --> 00:04:06.860
start gathering this information.

78
00:04:06.860 --> 00:04:15.000
Now, we'll assume that you've already
done your Open Source Reconnaissance.

79
00:04:15.000 --> 00:04:18.900
If you recall, when we're doing
reconnaissance phase there is

80
00:04:18.900 --> 00:04:22.800
a passive phase and
then there's an active phase.

81
00:04:22.800 --> 00:04:26.780
We're starting to kind of move more
into the active side of things and

82
00:04:26.780 --> 00:04:29.800
moving away from just
the purely passive stuff.

83
00:04:29.800 --> 00:04:32.130
It doesn't mean you're not
going to see any of that.

84
00:04:32.130 --> 00:04:37.850
There are tools I'm going to demo here
that are still scraping things out

85
00:04:37.850 --> 00:04:41.790
of open source places.

86
00:04:41.790 --> 00:04:45.380
But you're going to see some of both.

87
00:04:45.380 --> 00:04:50.710
But we're setting the expectation here
that you've already gone through and

88
00:04:50.710 --> 00:04:54.400
done your going through job postings and
stuff like that.

89
00:04:54.400 --> 00:04:56.800
You've already investigated
those sorts of things.

90
00:04:56.800 --> 00:04:59.985
So now you're moving into
something that's a little more

91
00:04:59.985 --> 00:05:05.145
aggressively engaging the target
to gather more information, or

92
00:05:05.145 --> 00:05:11.052
to confirm what you got from
your previous piece of this.

93
00:05:11.052 --> 00:05:16.932
Remember, just because you got something
from whatever source you got it from,

94
00:05:16.932 --> 00:05:18.172
doesn't mean that it's correct.

95
00:05:18.172 --> 00:05:20.622
That could be stale data.

96
00:05:20.622 --> 00:05:24.032
That could be data that's
completely incorrect.

97
00:05:24.032 --> 00:05:24.632
I mean,

98
00:05:24.632 --> 00:05:29.152
some of these things that happens, which I
shouldn't say some of these things, every,

99
00:05:29.152 --> 00:05:35.180
every place you get out there has
information in it that's not correct.

100
00:05:35.180 --> 00:05:39.200
Either it's completely incorrect or
there are little pieces of it.

101
00:05:39.200 --> 00:05:43.790
So, you really wanna make sure that
you're double checking everything you do.

102
00:05:43.790 --> 00:05:47.700
That whole idea of measure twice,
cut once, that's what we're gonna do.

103
00:05:47.700 --> 00:05:52.280
And so we may be double checking these
things that we had just to really

104
00:05:52.280 --> 00:05:57.000
confirm that yes we really have what
we expected to have at this point.

105
00:05:57.000 --> 00:06:01.990
So remember we did stuff in our CEH,
stuff like net craft, and

106
00:06:01.990 --> 00:06:05.270
we did a lot of these online
browser-based tools to check stuff.

107
00:06:05.270 --> 00:06:07.430
Some of those things just pull out so

108
00:06:07.430 --> 00:06:10.970
much information,
it'd be tough to go through all that so

109
00:06:10.970 --> 00:06:14.150
you might have to rely on these to
confirm it and narrow it down a bit more.

110
00:06:14.150 --> 00:06:16.110
All those things are gonna work together.

111
00:06:16.110 --> 00:06:20.370
And you really gotta be able to see
that big picture to make it all work and

112
00:06:20.370 --> 00:06:21.700
get what you need to see.

113
00:06:21.700 --> 00:06:23.240
>> Trust but verify, right?

114
00:06:23.240 --> 00:06:24.500
>> Absolutely.
>> Look at information and

115
00:06:24.500 --> 00:06:26.870
then verify that that
information is accurate.

116
00:06:26.870 --> 00:06:31.670
>> Yeah, don't ever just
assume that it's 100% correct.

117
00:06:32.770 --> 00:06:34.260
It's funny thing.

118
00:06:34.260 --> 00:06:41.680
One of the things I mentioned in the the
CEH course, was a situation where someone

119
00:06:42.900 --> 00:06:46.610
gave their pen tester,
they gave them information ahead of time.

120
00:06:46.610 --> 00:06:50.519
They gave them almost like a gray-box
situation where they gave the guy IP

121
00:06:50.519 --> 00:06:52.051
addresses.

122
00:06:52.051 --> 00:06:56.725
And, the pen tester called the lady
up that was in charge of this and

123
00:06:56.725 --> 00:06:58.485
said well I need an IP address.

124
00:06:58.485 --> 00:07:05.890
Well she was half asleep and
she was going to bed.

125
00:07:05.890 --> 00:07:10.660
And heck, to show her state of mind,
I remember her telling me yeah I

126
00:07:10.660 --> 00:07:14.380
just had some medical thing done.

127
00:07:14.380 --> 00:07:16.880
I'm on pain killers too.

128
00:07:16.880 --> 00:07:18.570
I'm going down for the night.

129
00:07:18.570 --> 00:07:19.570
I'm just popping one in.

130
00:07:19.570 --> 00:07:22.450
This guy calls and
says I gave him an IP address.

131
00:07:22.450 --> 00:07:27.140
And she gave the thing to him and
was like okay, whatever and hung up.

132
00:07:27.140 --> 00:07:30.350
She gave the guy an IP
address that was incorrect.

133
00:07:30.350 --> 00:07:33.700
You know,

episodes.description: Kali Linux comes with a vast amount of tools, which can help do a number of things including checking to see if systems are live or not. Viewers will hear how to utilize some of the command-line tools within Kali to conduct network ping sweeps, perform zone transfers, and do other functions to help gather information on a target network.

00:16:45.625 --> 00:16:50.785

DNS server gives a copy of

285
00:16:50.785 --> 00:16:56.755
it's database or what it's got in there
to another one to keep it up to date.

286
00:16:56.755 --> 00:17:02.690
So in that zone file is the IP or
named IP mappings and vice versa.

287
00:17:02.690 --> 00:17:07.960
So zone transfers are normal
part of DNS that just happens.

00:17:07.960 --> 00:17:11.750

to see a zone transfer happening to just

289
00:17:11.750 --> 00:17:12.940
anybody that requests it.

290
00:17:12.940 --> 00:17:17.200
It should only go from one DNS
server to another DNS server that is

291
00:17:17.200 --> 00:17:18.570
authorized to have it.

292
00:17:18.570 --> 00:17:21.740
It shouldn't be to anyone
else just as they see fit.

293
00:17:21.740 --> 00:17:26.600
If you have that situation where
it can go wherever it wants and

episodes.description: Website reconnaissance has to do with looking at what kind of information one can gather from a website somebody is hosting. Viewers will hear about some of the tools used to gather information from websites, which include the lbd, wget, and theharvester command-line tools.

So I'm thinking,

Sean, just from that title,

All their concern was

And that's where you get within this

I'm starting to find that it's almost

It's two different things, so

00:09:51.540 --> 00:09:55.420

episodes.description: Utilizing website reconnaissance tactics and tools can allow one to extract metadata from public documents, generate and test domain typos, and perform lots of other functions. Viewers will hear about further tools to gather information from a public interface like the URLCrazy and Metagoofil command-line tools.

Things like that you don't want

[LAUGH]

420
00:24:07.195 --> 00:24:09.660
gentlemen we hope you enjoyed
watching this episode.

421
00:24:09.660 --> 00:24:12.060
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I'm Mike Rodrick.

422
00:24:12.060 --> 00:24:13.130
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

423
00:24:13.130 --> 00:24:15.045
>> And we'll see you next time.

424
00:24:15.045 --> 00:24:19.770
[SOUND]

episodes.description: Once information is gathered using open-source intelligence, there are a lot of options for scanning one can do when moving over to the scanning phase. Viewers will hear about different types of scanning that can be done, which include host-based scanning, port scanning, network scanning, and vulnerability scanning and also hear about some techniques that can be used when implementing scanning techniques on a target network.
episodes.title: What is Network Scanning
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.923
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:09.923 --> 00:00:12.804
Hello and
welcome to another episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:12.804 --> 00:00:15.820
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:15.820 --> 00:00:17.080
How are you doing Sean?

5
00:00:17.080 --> 00:00:18.440
I'm doing great, how are you?

6
00:00:18.440 --> 00:00:19.620
>> I'm doing fantastic.

7
00:00:19.620 --> 00:00:23.260
We are having another episode in our
Kali Linux series here at ITProTV.

8
00:00:23.260 --> 00:00:26.300
And in this episode,
we are going to be looking at scanning.

9
00:00:26.300 --> 00:00:29.917
So we are going to be talking about
different types of scanning that can be

10
00:00:29.917 --> 00:00:32.000
done during that scanning phase.

11
00:00:32.000 --> 00:00:35.780
As well as, take a look at some
of the tools in later episodes

12
00:00:35.780 --> 00:00:37.790
that we can use to accomplish scanning.

13
00:00:37.790 --> 00:00:38.790
So Sean,

14
00:00:38.790 --> 00:00:42.220
scanning is really when we're starting and
we've done our reconnaissance.

15
00:00:42.220 --> 00:00:47.030
We've gathered all that information
using our open-source intelligence, and

16
00:00:47.030 --> 00:00:49.970
some other places we've looked
to get that information.

17
00:00:49.970 --> 00:00:52.470
Now we move into the scanning phase,
that we start reaching out and

18
00:00:52.470 --> 00:00:54.290
actually touching our target, right?

19
00:00:54.290 --> 00:00:57.920
>> Yeah, we're gonna be
getting into a lot deeper now.

20
00:00:57.920 --> 00:01:02.090
What scanning's gonna do is really start,
it's gonna encompass two things.

21
00:01:02.090 --> 00:01:04.470
First of all, it's gonna be
the scanning and the numeration.

22
00:01:04.470 --> 00:01:07.237
Remember, we're pushing
those both together and

23
00:01:07.237 --> 00:01:09.810
not really making too
much of a distinction.

24
00:01:09.810 --> 00:01:15.170
But enumeration does, if you do want
to put kind of a fine point on it.

25
00:01:15.170 --> 00:01:19.910
Within the scanning phase,
we have the actual scanning part, and

26
00:01:19.910 --> 00:01:22.090
then we have enumeration
comes right after that.

27
00:01:22.090 --> 00:01:24.390
So there is a definite sequence to it.

28
00:01:24.390 --> 00:01:26.970
But the whole thing itself
is called scanning.

29
00:01:26.970 --> 00:01:29.730
So they really only use the first part of

30
00:01:29.730 --> 00:01:34.120
those two pieces to give you
the name of the whole phase overall.

31
00:01:34.120 --> 00:01:35.840
>> It's always confused me a little bit.

32
00:01:35.840 --> 00:01:40.080
Because I know certain curriculum
will break those two out.

33
00:01:40.080 --> 00:01:45.740
But scanning gives you, in the end,
a list of things that it found.

34
00:01:45.740 --> 00:01:49.490
Enumeration is,
to enumerate is to list, right?

35
00:01:49.490 --> 00:01:52.380
So there's nothing,
they kinda should be put together.

36
00:01:52.380 --> 00:01:54.470
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, they do make sense,

37
00:01:54.470 --> 00:01:56.595
as one leads directly into the other.

38
00:01:56.595 --> 00:02:00.030
And if you just go scanning,
enumeration, and

39
00:02:00.030 --> 00:02:05.440
then gaining access to a system,
you can see the progress being made there.

40
00:02:05.440 --> 00:02:07.300
But, yeah, I would agree with you.

41
00:02:07.300 --> 00:02:10.900
It does tend to be,
makes sense to have scan enumeration.

42
00:02:10.900 --> 00:02:15.560
Just join them together, and say gaining
access is an excellent app for that.

43
00:02:15.560 --> 00:02:19.770
You found you target, found information
about a target, let's get into the target.

44
00:02:19.770 --> 00:02:20.760
>> Let's do it.

45
00:02:20.760 --> 00:02:22.530
All right, so
when it comes to scanning then,

46
00:02:22.530 --> 00:02:26.030
we've got different things we can scan or
scan for.

47
00:02:26.030 --> 00:02:28.920
What kind of different
scanning options do we have?

48
00:02:28.920 --> 00:02:32.526
>> Yeah, there is actually a whole lot
options on the table at this point,

49
00:02:32.526 --> 00:02:33.812
as far as scanning goes.

50
00:02:33.812 --> 00:02:38.500
We have the ability to scan and
look for live hosts, so

51
00:02:38.500 --> 00:02:40.800
we can see what's up or down.

52
00:02:40.800 --> 00:02:42.630
And there's plenty of tools that do that.

53
00:02:42.630 --> 00:02:47.050
Some of them we've already seen,
other ones we are gonna kinda reintroduce.

54
00:02:47.050 --> 00:02:51.800
And we do have some new ones that
are gonna start coming in to the picture

55
00:02:51.800 --> 00:02:52.910
once again.

56
00:02:52.910 --> 00:02:54.990
So we're gonna look for those live hosts,

57
00:02:54.990 --> 00:02:59.535
the hosts that we really want to kinda
focus our attention more tightly on.

58
00:02:59.535 --> 00:03:03.990
Because if we have a whole range of IPs,
there's no reason on spending time

59
00:03:03.990 --> 00:03:07.755
monkeying around with IPs that
there's nothing behind them.

60
00:03:07.755 --> 00:03:10.255
There's nothing there, so
you're just wasting time.

61
00:03:10.255 --> 00:03:13.831
>> 65,535 packets to an IP
address that doesn't have a host

62
00:03:13.831 --> 00:03:15.450
on the other end of it.

63
00:03:15.450 --> 00:03:16.540
That's kind of a waste, right?

64
00:03:16.540 --> 00:03:17.136
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and

65
00:03:17.136 --> 00:03:21.143
all it's gonna do is tell someone,
at first, that you're there and second,

66
00:03:21.143 --> 00:03:22.151
you're an idiot.

67
00:03:22.151 --> 00:03:23.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> So-

68
00:03:23.420 --> 00:03:24.478
>> Not too worried about that hacker,

69
00:03:24.478 --> 00:03:25.260
just let him do his thing.

70
00:03:25.260 --> 00:03:26.640
>> Yeah, it's like oh, come on.

71
00:03:26.640 --> 00:03:28.590
Get some chips, and
sit there and just start.

72
00:03:28.590 --> 00:03:32.850
It's not gonna really get you that far.

73
00:03:32.850 --> 00:03:36.190
>> And as a pin tester, not going
to make me look very efficient or

74
00:03:36.190 --> 00:03:38.225
very smart to my customers, right.

75
00:03:38.225 --> 00:03:39.760
>> Yeah, so don't do that.

76
00:03:39.760 --> 00:03:45.040
So that's the first thing, is finding out
what hosts are actually gonna be live and

77
00:03:45.040 --> 00:03:46.160
have something back there.

78
00:03:46.160 --> 00:03:49.930
Once you find that, then that's when you
are going to start getting in deeper and

79
00:03:49.930 --> 00:03:53.260
seeing what ports are open on that system.

80
00:03:53.260 --> 00:03:57.760
And then even getting further into that
and seeing what lives behind those ports.

81
00:03:57.760 --> 00:04:02.366
And that's where numeration really starts
coming in, is we're starting to probe

82
00:04:02.366 --> 00:04:06.048
those ports to see what information
we can extract out of them, and

83
00:04:06.048 --> 00:04:08.090
see what the nature of that is.

84
00:04:08.090 --> 00:04:11.180
And this is one of those points where

85
00:04:11.180 --> 00:04:15.208
you are goingg to see more towards
the enumeration section of this.

86
00:04:15.208 --> 00:04:18.390
You are gonna see that Kali

87
00:04:18.390 --> 00:04:23.760
has a really broad range of tools at
that point, that can help you out.

88
00:04:23.760 --> 00:04:28.270
One of the things that we saw in the CEH
course is that we could extract stuff out

89
00:04:28.270 --> 00:04:31.830
of Windows specifically, and
start looking for user names,

90
00:04:31.830 --> 00:04:33.820
share names, machine names.

91
00:04:33.820 --> 00:04:37.240
I mean, there's a great number of
things we could pull out of that.

92
00:04:37.240 --> 00:04:42.170
But when we get over to Kali, Kali
introduces another set of tools that we

93
00:04:42.170 --> 00:04:46.920
can use to do even additional
things that we haven't seen before.

94
00:04:46.920 --> 00:04:49.122
For example,
one of the things you can do is,

95
00:04:49.122 --> 00:04:53.875
during enumeration, you can extract
things specifically from Oracle.

96
00:04:53.875 --> 00:04:59.010
There's tools specifically in Kali
that target the Oracle database.

97
00:04:59.010 --> 00:05:02.397
So if you find that system present
by looking at the ports and

98
00:05:02.397 --> 00:05:07.211
see that there's something sitting behind
that, that indicates Oracle is there,

99
00:05:07.211 --> 00:05:11.546
you have a tool that you can now bring to
bear and extract stuff with Oracle and

100
00:05:11.546 --> 00:05:13.810
find all sorts of interesting things.

101
00:05:13.810 --> 00:05:16.860
So they put that into the mix.

102
00:05:16.860 --> 00:05:22.580
So now once you find the live ones, and
you start finding what ports are open and

103
00:05:22.580 --> 00:05:26.310
what the nature of that system is,
now you start digging behind that and

104
00:05:26.310 --> 00:05:29.280
seeing what those services and
all that actually mean.

105
00:05:29.280 --> 00:05:30.720
Maybe fingerprinting the OS.

106
00:05:30.720 --> 00:05:34.790
We definitely have tools that can do that
for us, plenty of ones in that category,

107
00:05:34.790 --> 00:05:35.900
as a matter of fact.

108
00:05:35.900 --> 00:05:39.255
That's probably one of the easiest
things to do is to fingerprint an OS.

109
00:05:39.255 --> 00:05:41.870
Cuz there's so
many different ways to do it.

110
00:05:41.870 --> 00:05:43.450
Once we have that, then yeah,

111
00:05:43.450 --> 00:05:47.250
we figure out what we specifically
want to target in that system.

112
00:05:47.250 --> 00:05:50.490
And then bring the tool that
we want to use to bear.

113
00:05:50.490 --> 00:05:54.470
Whether it's Oracle or Sequel Server, or

114
00:05:54.470 --> 00:05:57.580
some other web application,
or what have you.

115
00:05:57.580 --> 00:06:00.180
It could be, for example,
could be NetBIOS.

116
00:06:00.180 --> 00:06:04.630
I mean NetBIOS is one that we
had spent some time discussing

117
00:06:04.630 --> 00:06:06.790
over in the CEH course.

118
00:06:06.790 --> 00:06:08.510
It hasn't gone away.

119
00:06:08.510 --> 00:06:14.240
Just because things like Kali do
not use NetBIOS, doesn't mean that

120
00:06:14.240 --> 00:06:19.150
it can't utilize it to
investigate another target.

121
00:06:19.150 --> 00:06:23.120
It definitely has that capability to go
out and investigate a Windows system and

122
00:06:23.120 --> 00:06:25.960
say, okay, well,
there's NetBIOS running there.

123
00:06:25.960 --> 00:06:28.350
Even though Kali doesn't use
it on a day-to-day basis,

124
00:06:28.350 --> 00:06:32.320
it does have the ability to sweep it and
scan it and say yeah, it's there.

125
00:06:32.320 --> 00:06:34.660
And let me see if I can open
up an old session to it.

126
00:06:34.660 --> 00:06:38.980
And if you have that,
then a whole other can of worms opens.

127
00:06:38.980 --> 00:06:43.686
So there's quite a few things
that could happen at this

128
00:06:43.686 --> 00:06:48.070
scanning phase to really
get into the system.

129
00:06:48.070 --> 00:06:53.110
And then later on even, get in even
further when you start punching in, and

130
00:06:53.110 --> 00:06:57.575
kicking in the front door, or back door,
or whatever it is, and get into there.

131
00:06:57.575 --> 00:06:58.790
And so-
>> Nice.

132
00:06:58.790 --> 00:07:01.350
>> You won't believe the range
of tools that you have here.

133
00:07:01.350 --> 00:07:05.900
There's a good chunk of tools that can
do quite a bit of information gathering

134
00:07:05.900 --> 00:07:08.320
during the scanning phase.

135
00:07:08.320 --> 00:07:12.130
There's ones in here that extract
policy information if you're

136
00:07:12.130 --> 00:07:14.200
joined to Active Directory.

137
00:07:14.200 --> 00:07:18.020
There's ones that can do, like I said,
stuff with different data bases.

138
00:07:18.020 --> 00:07:20.060
There's ones up and
above what we have there.

139
00:07:20.060 --> 00:07:23.060
There's ones targeted for
specific applications.

140
00:07:23.060 --> 00:07:28.160
There's even tools in here
designed to collect information

141
00:07:28.160 --> 00:07:30.720
as it relates to network authentication.

142
00:07:30.720 --> 00:07:32.200
It's specifically designed for that.

143
00:07:32.200 --> 00:07:35.470
It scans for that, and you see,
yeah, I know what that is.

144
00:07:35.470 --> 00:07:38.040
And it can start pulling
information out of that too.

145
00:07:38.040 --> 00:07:44.520
So they've really equipped
you quite well at this point.

146
00:07:44.520 --> 00:07:46.100
>> Yeah, so
you've got a lot of different scanners.

147
00:07:46.100 --> 00:07:49.790
You've got some general purposes scanners
that we can use, do host scanning,

148
00:07:49.790 --> 00:07:50.590
do network scanning.

149
00:07:50.590 --> 00:07:53.320
And then we've got scanners that
are specific to applications.

150
00:07:53.320 --> 00:07:56.806
And that just means they understand
that application very well.

151
00:07:56.806 --> 00:08:00.679
They're designed to work against that
application, be it a database, or

152
00:08:00.679 --> 00:08:01.481
what have you.

153
00:08:01.481 --> 00:08:03.735
Which means it can pull
a lot more information back,

154
00:08:03.735 --> 00:08:05.178
because It's been programmed.

155
00:08:05.178 --> 00:08:07.194
It knows what to look for
and where to look for

156
00:08:07.194 --> 00:08:09.220
the information within that application.

157
00:08:09.220 --> 00:08:12.435
Or a specific type of traffic
that's going across the network.

158
00:08:12.435 --> 00:08:16.400
It's fine tuned to look for just that,
which can make our life a lot easier.

159
00:08:16.400 --> 00:08:19.700
Sometimes when you're doing this type of
scanning, you get so much information,

160
00:08:19.700 --> 00:08:21.850
some of it maybe you didn't
want at this point, or

161
00:08:21.850 --> 00:08:24.050
you've already gathered with other tools.

162
00:08:24.050 --> 00:08:27.320
Nice to be able to have some tools
that really focus in on your target.

163
00:08:27.320 --> 00:08:32.218
>> Yeah, it saves you a lot of time and
just think of with the amount of systems

164
00:08:32.218 --> 00:08:36.089
out there, the amount of
environments out there rather,

165
00:08:36.089 --> 00:08:39.100
that do have something
like Oracle present.

166
00:08:39.100 --> 00:08:44.212
I mean, you've got the Oracle database is
very popular just like SQL server as well,

167
00:08:44.212 --> 00:08:48.230
we're equipped to deal with both
of those now at this point.

168
00:08:48.230 --> 00:08:52.620
To see what we can extract out of there.

169
00:08:52.620 --> 00:08:55.890
It's actually a scary amount of
information if those are present,

170
00:08:55.890 --> 00:08:57.000
that it can get out of it.

171
00:08:57.000 --> 00:09:01.100
>> Absolutely and I'm hard pressed to
find a website nowadays that's not

172
00:09:01.100 --> 00:09:03.610
tied to some type of
back end to store data.

173
00:09:03.610 --> 00:09:05.685
An n-tier, a multi-tier type system.

174
00:09:05.685 --> 00:09:07.710
>> Yep.
>> Cuz we love those dynamic web pages and

175
00:09:07.710 --> 00:09:12.610
we love to make that user feel like
they are recognized when they come back.

176
00:09:12.610 --> 00:09:14.700
Well, all that information
is stored somewhere and

177
00:09:14.700 --> 00:09:17.170
these kinda tools might help
me dig some of that out.

178
00:09:17.170 --> 00:09:18.720
>> Yeah.
People definitely expect

179
00:09:18.720 --> 00:09:21.360
certain experiences and
certain things to happen and

180
00:09:21.360 --> 00:09:27.670
it's databases are part of
the technological landscape now.

181
00:09:27.670 --> 00:09:31.580
They expect to be delivered, certain types
of content, expect them to deliver it

182
00:09:31.580 --> 00:09:36.780
a certain way, and
that's just become something's that there.

183
00:09:36.780 --> 00:09:41.430
So, we have these tools that can help
us out with extracting that data and

184
00:09:41.430 --> 00:09:43.117
seeing what's going on.

185
00:09:43.117 --> 00:09:47.510
It's kind of mind numbing in a way
when you see what it can do.

186
00:09:47.510 --> 00:09:50.780
So we're gonna start introducing
those into the picture.

187
00:09:50.780 --> 00:09:56.470
And we're also gonna be talking,
probably more when we get to a few future

188
00:09:56.470 --> 00:10:02.520
pieces of Kali over the next couple days.

189
00:10:02.520 --> 00:10:07.300
When we get into specific sections dealing
with databases we'll start really getting

190
00:10:07.300 --> 00:10:08.880
into that portion of it.

191
00:10:08.880 --> 00:10:12.450
Because even up above,
just kind of see what is down the road,

192
00:10:12.450 --> 00:10:17.640
not only can we scan and
locate a database if its present,

193
00:10:17.640 --> 00:10:21.765
we also have the ability at
a later point do SQL injections.

194
00:10:21.765 --> 00:10:24.930
There's tools specifically in Kali,

195
00:10:24.930 --> 00:10:28.130
that are designed to help
you do SQL injections.

196
00:10:28.130 --> 00:10:28.820
>> Wow.
>> Yeah, so

197
00:10:28.820 --> 00:10:31.570
they've brought that to bear as well.

198
00:10:31.570 --> 00:10:34.740
So, you've got a fair amount of
tools in there to help you out.

199
00:10:35.960 --> 00:10:37.800
That's how cool this really is.

200
00:10:37.800 --> 00:10:41.795
>> Okay, now I was gonna say, Kali, it
reminds me of the old swiss army knife but

201
00:10:41.795 --> 00:10:43.945
I don't even know if that does it justice.

202
00:10:43.945 --> 00:10:46.175
It have to be one of those really wide,
200 tool-

203
00:10:46.175 --> 00:10:47.655
>> Yeah, a pretty big one.

204
00:10:47.655 --> 00:10:49.495
>> Swiss army knives
that'll fit in your pocket.

205
00:10:49.495 --> 00:10:52.889
It really does just about
everything we need as

206
00:10:52.889 --> 00:10:55.595
a pen tester all wrapped up into one.

207
00:10:55.595 --> 00:11:01.395
>> It's got so many in there, you're never
really going use all the tools in there.

208
00:11:01.395 --> 00:11:05.820
I mean you're going to go and
investigate this stuff undoubtedly, but

209
00:11:05.820 --> 00:11:08.970
you're probably never
going to use them all.

210
00:11:08.970 --> 00:11:11.070
In fact if you look at that list of tools,

211
00:11:11.070 --> 00:11:14.240
the one you were showing
yesterday on the Kali website.

212
00:11:14.240 --> 00:11:17.060
Some of those you still
have to actually load.

213
00:11:17.060 --> 00:11:20.320
So, not even all those are present,
so you can load those.

214
00:11:20.320 --> 00:11:23.360
Then there's even ones that aren't even
there, that you can grab from other

215
00:11:23.360 --> 00:11:28.340
places, there's plenty of places that have
little packages that you can download and

216
00:11:28.340 --> 00:11:31.050
install on the system to
enhance the security or

217
00:11:31.050 --> 00:11:35.790
enhance the capabilities up above that,
but it's kinda questionable.

218
00:11:35.790 --> 00:11:38.712
Do you really need all those
other packages, when you have so

219
00:11:38.712 --> 00:11:40.560
much capability right out of the box?

220
00:11:40.560 --> 00:11:43.436
>> I would think only if you
needed a specific tool for

221
00:11:43.436 --> 00:11:47.064
a specific target, or
you just had a favorite that you really,

222
00:11:47.064 --> 00:11:50.510
really liked above some of
those that are built in.

223

They've got all these different things, so

In fact if you recall from our CEH course,

You could be trying to locate

There's a bunch of

But yeah, you're trying to get a better

You could start trying to look around

So yeah, that's what a network

You know?
Do banner grabs and stuff like that.

To be able to get inside and see that.

Unless the range you're looking

00:15:17.815 --> 00:15:18.670
>> Mm-hm.

00:15:18.670 --> 00:15:20.160
>> That's a different story.

If it's something that's over the wall and

inside then you're going to have

Packet crafters are something that

A packet crafter,

pack with specific flags and settings.

00:16:25.907 --> 00:16:28.470
Designed to detect certain things or

00:16:28.470 --> 00:16:33.827

00:16:33.827 --> 00:16:37.329
Is that you craft a packet,
you sensor it and flag,

00:16:37.329 --> 00:16:42.224

00:16:42.224 --> 00:16:45.789

00:16:50.488 --> 00:16:55.697

00:16:55.697 --> 00:16:59.880

00:17:04.760 --> 00:17:11.590

We have things to help us defragment,

We have stuff to identify different

So, those are specifically designed,

you gotta assume,

We actually have stuff there

00:17:48.512 --> 00:17:52.592
yeah, I know there's an IDS there or

Or how it didn't move, as the case may be.

>> Yeah, and
that brought me to another question,

then is when I'm doing this scanning,

that is one of the things that

If I'm doing penetration testing,

We're kind of counting on you since you've

episodes.description: Scanning for live hosts are a big part of the penetration process that helps lead to finding out what ports are open and then to what lies behind those ports. Viewers will hear about the process of scanning for live hosts and some of the tools used in the scanning and enumeration phase including fping, nmap, masscan, unicornscan, and netdiscover.

so you could try those ones out too.

462
00:25:41.230 --> 00:25:45.170
Those ones are different methods

463

so it brings so much stuff to bear,
and there's just

464
00:25:49.710 --> 00:25:53.000
information gathering with the network
scanners, that's just a few of them.

465
00:25:53.000 --> 00:25:57.300
There's other ones that are stuck
in other submenus that also do

466
00:25:57.300 --> 00:25:58.710
different forms of scanning.

467
00:25:58.710 --> 00:26:02.220
So it all depends on really what
you're trying to accomplish.

I mean, you've got so many, that's why

Explore.

We can sleep when we're dead.

00:26:21.160 --> 00:26:24.140

All right, well, tell you what, Shawn,

00:26:31.270 --> 00:26:34.520
But for now, signing off for

00:26:36.734 --> 00:26:43.010
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Once one has gone through the scanning phase and found live systems, one can then do port scans and start to enumerate things off those systems like list out groups, users, and password policies. Viewers will hear about the involved process, tools that function in both scanning and enumeration, and others that are limited only to enumeration.
episodes.title: Enumeration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

So, yeah, they both definitely are very,

Cuz we did do a lot with scanning

And just to kind of mention it, to show

Just like enumeration, what type of

One of the ones I kinda wanna

it kinda fits in the whole idea

It kind of straddles the line between

S, I've got Miranda sitting up there.

If you go ahead and hit Enter on it,

Right now,

It says it's restricted to this

It's not gonna go out on the network

out here that we have running [LAUGH]

00:06:51.300 --> 00:06:54.052
We don't really need that

But [COUGH] if this was a network that we

So that's kind of, you can see it's

00:07:32.430 --> 00:07:36.470
So that would help you

00:07:36.470 --> 00:07:39.600
Universal plug and play is one of those

00:07:39.600 --> 00:07:43.588
If you look around,

00:07:48.040 --> 00:07:52.933
Because of the fact that you can

135
00:08:11.415 --> 00:08:15.480
>> Yeah, It's one of those darn services

00:08:15.480 --> 00:08:19.280
security plus classes and other
security related shows that we've done.

137
00:08:19.280 --> 00:08:23.840
We draw that triangle, we put ease

138
00:08:23.840 --> 00:08:28.620
the second point of the triangle, and
functionality at that third point.

139
00:08:28.620 --> 00:08:32.432
Well, universal plug and play is
convenient, easy to use, right, and so

140
00:08:32.432 --> 00:08:35.519
that means as we move towards
that point of the triangle, and

141
00:08:35.519 --> 00:08:38.930
at that point of the triangle,
we're moving away from security.

142
00:08:38.930 --> 00:08:42.790
So it's great because it makes
it very easy to find devices,

143
00:08:42.790 --> 00:08:45.060
to configure devices to talk together.

144
00:08:45.060 --> 00:08:48.780
But because it's so easy, there's not
a lot of security built in to it and

145
00:08:48.780 --> 00:08:50.690
also it means it could be a vulnerability.

146
00:08:50.690 --> 00:08:54.740
So one of those things you gotta decide
if it's really worth using or not.

147
00:08:54.740 --> 00:08:59.520
And here's a tool that shows you how easy

148
00:08:59.520 --> 00:09:04.510
So, if you are using that, bad guys,
or pen testers, or what have you,

149
00:09:04.510 --> 00:09:06.130

150
00:09:06.130 --> 00:09:09.050
>> Yeah, you can start picking up
devices that have been plugged

151
00:09:09.050 --> 00:09:10.910
in without too much effort.

152
00:09:10.910 --> 00:09:14.170
So that's what this would be useful for.

153
00:09:14.170 --> 00:09:21.870
So be aware of this, this is one even at
if, those of you who follow Steve Gibson.

154
00:09:21.870 --> 00:09:25.539
This is one that he actually talked to
Microsoft about was universal plug and

155
00:09:25.539 --> 00:09:29.687
play, and that it was a vulnerability and
it was something that just wasn't needed.

156
00:09:29.687 --> 00:09:32.990
But Microsoft went with it anyway.

157
00:09:32.990 --> 00:09:35.510
And so
we've had to deal with some of the mess.

158
00:09:35.510 --> 00:09:38.770
And he wasn't the only one,
just to be fair, that pointed it out.

159
00:09:38.770 --> 00:09:42.370
Microsoft didn't really worry about,
listen to anybody on it.

160
00:09:42.370 --> 00:09:45.720
Like, yeah, whatever, we don't care.

161
00:09:45.720 --> 00:09:46.490
That type of deal,

162
00:09:46.490 --> 00:09:51.550
so this is something that's specifically

163
00:09:51.550 --> 00:09:55.230
And like I said, it straddles that line,

164
00:09:55.230 --> 00:09:59.006
It's literally doing both of
these things at the same time.

165
00:09:59.006 --> 00:09:59.702
>> Nice.

166
00:09:59.702 --> 00:10:05.600
>> So, that's Miranda and
you can choose to use that.

167
00:10:05.600 --> 00:10:09.630
This is something that, to be honest, you
can probably, if you're doing your sandbox

168
00:10:09.630 --> 00:10:15.038
type experimentation,
if you've got Windows boxes on there.

169
00:10:15.038 --> 00:10:20.005
This would probably be very useful for
you and to try on that home network that

170
00:10:20.005 --> 00:10:24.390
you've got set aside or that lab you have
at work that has Windows devices on it.

171
00:10:24.390 --> 00:10:29.350
Because they definitely have that running

172
00:10:29.350 --> 00:10:31.810
You can turn this on and

173
00:10:31.810 --> 00:10:35.580
start locating those devices

174
00:10:35.580 --> 00:10:39.330
>> And I know Roku devices will show up

00:10:39.330 --> 00:10:41.890
points, if you haven't disabled

00:10:41.890 --> 00:10:46.740
That push button, connect type thing,
those all rely on that universal plug and

00:10:46.740 --> 00:10:47.910
play, and they're gonna show up,

178
00:10:47.910 --> 00:10:49.710
people are gonna be able

179
00:10:49.710 --> 00:10:55.020
>> Yeah, so it would be a really
interesting exercise for you to try and

00:10:55.020 --> 00:11:01.440
just see that, hey,
this opens up a huge can of worms for you.

181
00:11:01.440 --> 00:11:07.199
So, that's Miranda, but we do have other
tools available that can do stuff for us.

182
00:11:08.230 --> 00:11:14.829
I've got, so I'll close out Miranda,
this is another one called DMitry.

183
00:11:14.829 --> 00:11:19.420
DMitry is another way of extracting
information, and what I'm doing here is

00:11:19.420 --> 00:11:23.260
I'm actually targeting, again,

185
00:11:23.260 --> 00:11:27.190
And what I'm gonna do is I will turn
this thing on, and it goes through and

00:11:27.190 --> 00:11:29.810
does a quick, just boom, right on through.

187
00:11:29.810 --> 00:11:36.576
But I am going to go ahead and move right

188
00:11:36.576 --> 00:11:38.915
There's DMitry.

00:11:38.915 --> 00:11:40.130
I like it.

00:11:40.130 --> 00:11:42.671
There be some deep magic going on,

191
00:11:42.671 --> 00:11:44.590
>> [LAUGH] That is nice.

192
00:11:44.590 --> 00:11:45.480
And what is that right after?

00:11:45.480 --> 00:11:47.550
I'm trying to get that command for

00:11:47.550 --> 00:11:53.290
Let's see, it's dmitry -winsep-
>> W-I-N-S-E-P-F-B.

>> F-B, okay.

episodes.description: Gaining access is the third phase when one actually begins to penetrate a system. Viewers will hear a high level overview about gaining access to a system, which can entail cracking passwords and escalating privileges and lead to the point where one can implement tactics to maintain access to the system.
episodes.title: Gaining Access

So, we've gotta have the tools and

There are other cases.

episodes.description: Cracking passwords are one of the first steps when it comes down to gaining access to a system, which the Kali Linux environment holds a lot of means to do so. Viewers will hear about the basic process to go through to get password information and hear discussions about the different kinds of tools used to crack passwords both online and offline.
episodes.title: Cracking Passwords

episodes.description: Online password cracking can run a higher risk of being detected and triggering system policy that will shut down a password attack, so one might want to start with offline tactics before they jump into using online tactics. Viewers will hear about some of the online password tracking techniques including password guessing and some of the tools that can be used to accomplish the task of online password cracking.

episodes.description: A sniffer is something someone uses to capture network traffic and it can be used to intercept things like credentials and confidential data. Viewers will hear about sniffers, what they can be used for, and see a brief demonstration on the Driftnet, EtherApe, and Wireshark network sniffers.
episodes.title: Using Sniffers

00:01:29.640 --> 00:01:33.200
And none of this is going to be targeted
specifically towards Wire Shark.

29
00:01:33.200 --> 00:01:35.430
Yes, we do know about it.

30
00:01:35.430 --> 00:01:41.030
It is in Kali to use if you decide
that that's the way you want to go.

31
00:01:41.030 --> 00:01:46.840
But the purpose of this is to not just
give you the option of using Wire Shark,

32
00:01:46.840 --> 00:01:49.320
but also tell you there
are other things there

33
00:01:49.320 --> 00:01:53.440
that you can use to accomplish either
the same thing Wire Shark's doing,

34
00:01:53.440 --> 00:01:57.540
or modified Versions of
what Wire Shark's doing.

35
00:01:57.540 --> 00:02:00.280
So, just keep that in mind.

36
00:02:01.600 --> 00:02:05.100
To start off with things,
let's talk about what a sniffer is.

37
00:02:05.100 --> 00:02:07.790
And you described it pretty well, Mike.

38
00:02:07.790 --> 00:02:11.750
It's something that we use to
capture traffic as it flows back and

39
00:02:11.750 --> 00:02:15.120
forth over a network, and
that can be wired or wireless.

40
00:02:15.120 --> 00:02:19.120
So we're capturing traffic as it
goes back and forth, back and forth.

41
00:02:19.120 --> 00:02:25.027
It's really, really low down in the OSI
model where it's catching that.

42
00:02:25.027 --> 00:02:29.550
So, we'll just see that traffic, whether
or not it's encrypted, or whatever.

43
00:02:29.550 --> 00:02:31.400
You just won't be able to
read it if it's encrypted.

44
00:02:31.400 --> 00:02:34.502
But if it's formatted by a certain
application, you'll see it.

45
00:02:34.502 --> 00:02:36.622
You may not be able to
understand the underlying data,

46
00:02:36.622 --> 00:02:40.270
cuz an application formatted it, but
you'll be able to see it with the sniffer.

47
00:02:40.270 --> 00:02:43.500
So, there's that aspect of it.

48
00:02:43.500 --> 00:02:45.270
Now, what we can use a sniffer for is,

49
00:02:45.270 --> 00:02:49.830
we can use it to intercept things like
credentials and confidential data.

50
00:02:49.830 --> 00:02:52.850
Stuff like that is very important to us.

51
00:02:52.850 --> 00:02:54.530
But how do they work?

52
00:02:54.530 --> 00:03:01.590
Well, a sniffer works by turning your
wired network card Into promiscuous mode.

53
00:03:01.590 --> 00:03:05.960
And promiscuous mode means that that
card goes from being able to see

54
00:03:05.960 --> 00:03:10.250
just the traffic either leaving that
system or going to that system.

55
00:03:10.250 --> 00:03:13.550
It switches it to being able to
see anything that's floating by,

56
00:03:13.550 --> 00:03:17.190
whether it's addressed to or
from that card, or to anybody else.

57
00:03:17.190 --> 00:03:22.020
So, once you're switched in that mode,
you will see everything that happens to be

58
00:03:22.020 --> 00:03:25.160
swimming by on the cable no
matter who it's addressed to.

59
00:03:25.160 --> 00:03:28.910
And therefore, once you have that
happening, you can start putting

60
00:03:28.910 --> 00:03:33.050
filters and stuff you've got in place just
to see the information that you wanna see.

61
00:03:33.050 --> 00:03:36.660
Or you just choose to capture it all,
write it out to a file, and

62
00:03:36.660 --> 00:03:41.150
then kind of dissect the file,
and do what you want offline.

63
00:03:41.150 --> 00:03:42.970
That's a possibility as well.

64
00:03:42.970 --> 00:03:47.390
So, you've got some really neat
stuff here you can do with sniffers.

65
00:03:47.390 --> 00:03:52.007
And basically, all of them work in
a mode very similar to what I just

66
00:03:52.007 --> 00:03:54.486
described with little variation.

67
00:03:54.486 --> 00:03:58.737
Where they start varying from one another
is the features, their efficiency,

68
00:03:58.737 --> 00:04:02.890
speed, stuff like that are gonna
make one different from another.

69
00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:05.350
>> Yeah, just so really,
when we're talking about sniffing,

70
00:04:05.350 --> 00:04:08.220
that's a good concept to understand,
that promiscuous mode.

71
00:04:08.220 --> 00:04:11.650
Normally, that network adapter
ignores anything that's not

72
00:04:11.650 --> 00:04:12.910
destined for him, right?

73
00:04:12.910 --> 00:04:16.280
If it's not him on the destination
address, he drops the packet.

74
00:04:16.280 --> 00:04:18.030
He's not supposed to receive it.

75
00:04:18.030 --> 00:04:19.500
Switch it over to promiscuous mode, and

76
00:04:19.500 --> 00:04:21.490
all of the sudden,
he'll take in all that traffic.

77
00:04:21.490 --> 00:04:24.080
And that gives us the ability
to capture that information.

78
00:04:24.080 --> 00:04:26.600
And most of our network
adapters nowadays support that.

79
00:04:26.600 --> 00:04:29.660
Most of our operating systems give
us the ability to switch into that

80
00:04:29.660 --> 00:04:31.270
promiscuous mode?

81
00:04:31.270 --> 00:04:33.500
>> Yes, it's a very common thing.

82
00:04:33.500 --> 00:04:37.760
You can expect to see just about any
card you run into to support that.

83
00:04:37.760 --> 00:04:41.600
Why there are still some cases
where they don't support that,

84
00:04:41.600 --> 00:04:43.420
those are the exception not the rule.

85
00:04:43.420 --> 00:04:47.390
So, don't expect to see a card
that won't switch into that.

86
00:04:47.390 --> 00:04:50.140
It's been many years
since we've had a card,

87
00:04:50.140 --> 00:04:51.640
since we really had to deal with cards,

88
00:04:51.640 --> 00:04:55.900
that were not gonna run a promiscuous
mode versus the ones that we have now.

89
00:04:55.900 --> 00:05:00.450
So, now it's just a question of,
do you have something that can switch it

90
00:05:00.450 --> 00:05:04.210
over from promiscuous mode, and
do you need to have it a promiscuous mode?

91
00:05:04.210 --> 00:05:08.440
Even though a card goes for promiscuous
mode, there is very few cases in

92
00:05:08.440 --> 00:05:12.450
normal practice that you need to
have it actually go into that mode.

93
00:05:12.450 --> 00:05:16.270
Sniffing is one of them that you would
need a card to have promiscuous mode to

94
00:05:16.270 --> 00:05:17.670
do it the right way.

95
00:05:17.670 --> 00:05:23.470
Another reason that you could have
a card switched into promiscuous mode is

96
00:05:23.470 --> 00:05:28.915
if you have Add an IDS or IPS, something
that's designed to analyze traffic.

97
00:05:28.915 --> 00:05:32.385
That has to see everything
that's moving by, and

98
00:05:32.385 --> 00:05:35.725
then it applies rules to it to
see the stuff that's flowing by.

99
00:05:35.725 --> 00:05:38.045
Does it match stuff that
I know is malicious?

100
00:05:38.045 --> 00:05:41.905
And if so,
what is gonna be my reaction to that?

101
00:05:41.905 --> 00:05:48.100
But those are two of the few cases where
you ever need to be In promiscuous mode.

102
00:05:48.100 --> 00:05:53.620
Outside of that, if you see something in
promiscuous mode, it's now a question of,

103
00:05:53.620 --> 00:05:59.010
why is it that way, and let's go find out,
and probably shut it down.

104
00:05:59.010 --> 00:06:02.090
>> Right, it's probably not doing anything
you want it to do, in other words.

105
00:06:02.090 --> 00:06:05.353
>> Yeah,
it really should probably not be that way.

106
00:06:05.353 --> 00:06:07.497
And then they actually do
catch people that way.

107
00:06:07.497 --> 00:06:12.352
They will have systems on networks,
and they will have people that monitor

108
00:06:12.352 --> 00:06:17.070
sort of thing, where they're watching
the traffic go back and forth.

109
00:06:17.070 --> 00:06:22.200
And they start seeing other traffic
that's indicative of a card someplace

110
00:06:22.200 --> 00:06:26.840
being in promiscuous mode, because they'll
look at the responses and beacons, or

111
00:06:26.840 --> 00:06:28.282
whatever you want to call it,
that come out.

112
00:06:28.282 --> 00:06:31.583
And they'll say, yeah,
that's a card in promiscuous mode.

113
00:06:31.583 --> 00:06:36.073
And there's only certain systems we know
that are documented that are supposed to

114
00:06:36.073 --> 00:06:38.360
be that way, and that's not one of them.

115
00:06:38.360 --> 00:06:42.980
So, we need to go track that down and
figure out why it's that way.

116
00:06:42.980 --> 00:06:44.670
>> All right, so,
to run these sniffers and

117
00:06:44.670 --> 00:06:47.930
to be able to capture useful information,
typically, cuz usually,

118
00:06:47.930 --> 00:06:53.480
the information is not coming to my system
that I'm using to do this pen test,

119
00:06:53.480 --> 00:06:55.850
we gotta be able to switch
over to promiscuous mode.

00:06:55.850 --> 00:06:59.440
And then, when it comes to sniffers, we've

Sniffers don't necessarily

It's just what you're actually gonna see.

Of dealing with information.
