00:14:45.630 --> 00:14:50.000
That's just standard network traffic,
nothing really special.

251
00:14:50.000 --> 00:14:53.320
And we can do odd little things like
set up filters and all that good stuff,

252
00:14:53.320 --> 00:14:55.790
so really no problem there.

253
00:14:55.790 --> 00:15:00.210
We're seeing what we would expect,
so that's one sniffer.

254
00:15:00.210 --> 00:15:02.720
Just wanted to show you that one.

255
00:15:02.720 --> 00:15:05.690
There already is a course on Wire Shark.

256
00:15:05.690 --> 00:15:11.260
Wire Shark was covered again in the CEH,
we covered it in the DFI course too.

257
00:15:11.260 --> 00:15:13.590
So it's had some coverage already.

258
00:15:13.590 --> 00:15:16.390
Right now we're kinda not worried
about it since it's had that.

259
00:15:16.390 --> 00:15:21.168
But just to let you know it is there,
and there are some things it does kind

260
00:15:21.168 --> 00:15:26.650
of chatter away about, but
it does run, and it does do its job.

261
00:15:26.650 --> 00:15:29.050
So, let me go ahead and
I'll just close that one.

262
00:15:29.050 --> 00:15:31.890
I am not going to save any of that.

263
00:15:31.890 --> 00:15:32.785
Just close right out.

264
00:15:34.915 --> 00:15:37.470
And there we go.

265
00:15:37.470 --> 00:15:40.440
So I've got that as a sniffer.

266
00:15:40.440 --> 00:15:45.280
Now there are other ways of
capturing traffic of course.

267
00:15:45.280 --> 00:15:47.368
One that I like to point out,

268
00:15:47.368 --> 00:15:52.676
it's another one that you have available
to you is one called Ether Ape.

269
00:15:52.676 --> 00:15:57.674
Ether Ape, let's see if we will
have to restart that a bit.

270
00:15:57.674 --> 00:15:59.427
But what EtherApe does,

271
00:15:59.427 --> 00:16:04.790
I had this running while I was playing
around with stuff, so I broke it.

272
00:16:04.790 --> 00:16:05.740
My fault.

273
00:16:05.740 --> 00:16:10.530
So what I'm going to do is, let me see
if I can start up EtherApe again here.

274
00:16:11.820 --> 00:16:14.850
So what EtherApe does is, there you go.

275
00:16:14.850 --> 00:16:19.980
It doesn't look like much is happening but
if I were to open up my

276
00:16:19.980 --> 00:16:24.360
browser again here, I'm trying to
induce traffic that it can monitor.

277
00:16:24.360 --> 00:16:28.170
So I will just do that again, and click.

278
00:16:28.170 --> 00:16:34.330
If I go over to EtherApe, what's happening
there, it's not showing you the traffic,

279
00:16:34.330 --> 00:16:38.320
but it is showing you what this
system is actually attaching to.

280
00:16:38.320 --> 00:16:39.260
So if you look at it,

281
00:16:39.260 --> 00:16:44.390
you can actually see those things are
pulsating a bit and doing a little magic.

282
00:16:44.390 --> 00:16:47.980
What's happening there is those
are active connections going out to

283
00:16:47.980 --> 00:16:49.960
all those systems.

284
00:16:49.960 --> 00:16:54.750
And it's telling me that, hey,
when you attach to the ITProTV site,

285
00:16:54.750 --> 00:16:57.000
it's dialing up connections
to these other guys.

286
00:16:57.000 --> 00:17:01.080
So I could look up those
IP addresses on there or

287
00:17:01.080 --> 00:17:03.820
DNS names on there and see who that is.

288
00:17:03.820 --> 00:17:08.190
Those could be things like advertising
networks or what have you.

289
00:17:08.190 --> 00:17:13.360
The different colors do
tell you different things.

290
00:17:13.360 --> 00:17:15.930
If you look down the left-hand side,
you probably can't read it

291
00:17:15.930 --> 00:17:19.420
too well on the screen here, but
if you look down the left-hand side,

292
00:17:19.420 --> 00:17:24.040
you can see it's got
different colors over there.

293
00:17:24.040 --> 00:17:24.700
It's telling you,

294
00:17:24.700 --> 00:17:29.670
well, those different colors
correspond to a specific protocol type.

295
00:17:30.950 --> 00:17:32.160
It's kind of a neat thing.

296
00:17:32.160 --> 00:17:36.885
It's not giving you specific
traffic at that level, but

297
00:17:36.885 --> 00:17:41.819
it is telling you,
giving you kind of a way to visualize it.

298
00:17:41.819 --> 00:17:46.161
And I kind of like this tool because
when you look at it, it very quickly and

299
00:17:46.161 --> 00:17:51.390
easily shows you how things are flowing
back and forth from the various systems.

300
00:17:51.390 --> 00:17:54.610
And so you can get an idea of well,
my system's attaching to this one,

301
00:17:54.610 --> 00:17:55.320
this one, and this one.

302
00:17:55.320 --> 00:17:59.430
And then sometimes you'll see
the individual systems pass traffic

303
00:17:59.430 --> 00:18:00.790
amongst themselves.

304
00:18:00.790 --> 00:18:05.180
It's really a fascinating
look to see how things work.

305
00:18:05.180 --> 00:18:08.342
It also shows you,
I'm not touching anything right now.

306
00:18:08.342 --> 00:18:10.436
All I have right there is, there's,

307
00:18:10.436 --> 00:18:14.104
obviously there's some traffic
going in and out of this machine,

308
00:18:14.104 --> 00:18:18.062
cuz I'm cast down, broadcasting out
some video so you guys can see it.

309
00:18:18.062 --> 00:18:22.850
Seeing that, and there's some
stuff going on my host machine.

310
00:18:22.850 --> 00:18:26.300
But I'm just sitting here and
I'm not doing much.

311
00:18:26.300 --> 00:18:28.750
And you can see, I've got my hands off.

312
00:18:28.750 --> 00:18:30.178
And it's doing things.

313
00:18:30.178 --> 00:18:34.570
So that's a chatty system.

314
00:18:34.570 --> 00:18:35.462
>> Look, ma, no hands.
[LAUGH]

315
00:18:35.462 --> 00:18:37.041
>> Yeah, pretty much.

316
00:18:37.041 --> 00:18:38.850
>> Yeah, it really is.

317
00:18:38.850 --> 00:18:39.637
It's capturing the traffic.

318
00:18:39.637 --> 00:18:44.480
You're not seeing the raw package, though,
it's more of like a protocol analyzer.

319
00:18:44.480 --> 00:18:47.940
Gives me the ability to see what
connections are being made,

320
00:18:47.940 --> 00:18:52.160
discover IP addresses that I didn't know
about, systems that I didn't know about,

321
00:18:52.160 --> 00:18:54.560
seeing what protocols
are being used on a network.

322
00:18:54.560 --> 00:18:58.100
Cuz maybe I've got some tools that I
can then capture that specific type

323
00:18:58.100 --> 00:18:58.670
of traffic.

324
00:18:58.670 --> 00:19:03.100
Or maybe I wanna go back to my Wireshark
packet dump, and now filtered.

325
00:19:03.100 --> 00:19:07.820
I saw a whole lot of certain type of
traffic going on using EtherApe or

326
00:19:07.820 --> 00:19:09.990
EtherApe, and
now I go back to Wireshark and

327
00:19:09.990 --> 00:19:12.600
I filter it and
find those actual packets and look for it.

328
00:19:12.600 --> 00:19:17.060
So just another great tool to
have in the toolbag there.

329
00:19:17.060 --> 00:19:20.990
>> Yeah, it's just helping you visualize
that information in a different way.

330
00:19:20.990 --> 00:19:26.990
Because realistically, just looking
at stuff as it flows by on Wireshark,

331
00:19:26.990 --> 00:19:29.850
we can look at that and analyze it.

332
00:19:29.850 --> 00:19:32.840
Heck, I know people that can
go all matrix on that stuff,

333
00:19:32.840 --> 00:19:34.900
and do that to a certain degree.

334
00:19:34.900 --> 00:19:39.780
But they're still, because of how
rapid that traffic passes, and

335
00:19:39.780 --> 00:19:44.258
how quickly it accumulates, it still
poses a big challenge to sort through.

336
00:19:44.258 --> 00:19:48.970
This tool just happens to be one with
EtherApe happens to be one that helps

337
00:19:48.970 --> 00:19:50.294
ease that process.

338
00:19:50.294 --> 00:19:55.807
So it's not a bad thing to have
something like that in your arsenal.

339
00:19:55.807 --> 00:20:00.622
So, that's just one that you
could run on your system,

340
00:20:00.622 --> 00:20:05.120
but again, there are other ones out there.

341
00:20:05.120 --> 00:20:08.390
So we'll take a look at Driftnet and
what it does.

342
00:20:08.390 --> 00:20:11.200
So what I've done to set this up,

343
00:20:11.200 --> 00:20:14.510
as you can see I've got
Driftnet running back here.

344
00:20:14.510 --> 00:20:19.596
What I did is did driftnet -i eth0.

345
00:20:19.596 --> 00:20:25.768
And you should recognize that now as
saying, well, run the driftnet command and

346
00:20:25.768 --> 00:20:30.150
have it observe what's going
on on the eth0 interface.

347
00:20:30.150 --> 00:20:31.670
You could change it to whatever you want.

348
00:20:31.670 --> 00:20:35.530
If you have multiple network interfaces,
you can definitely do that.

349
00:20:35.530 --> 00:20:39.570
So, I only have the one, so
I'm gonna leave it just with eth0.

350
00:20:40.640 --> 00:20:43.610
But you can see it's not doing
anything just sitting there.

351
00:20:43.610 --> 00:20:47.720
What it did, is it actually opened
up that box, nothing in the box.

352
00:20:47.720 --> 00:20:51.610
So what I'll do is, I will go over and

353
00:20:51.610 --> 00:20:56.170
I will just find a website,
something that's got graphics or

354
00:20:56.170 --> 00:20:59.650
something I know is going to be in,
gonna pop up here.

355
00:20:59.650 --> 00:21:05.270
So I could do something like I
typed in a video gaming site,

356
00:21:05.270 --> 00:21:10.670
and something that I know is
gonna have some images on it.

357
00:21:10.670 --> 00:21:13.220
And you can see what's happening
there as it goes through,

358
00:21:13.220 --> 00:21:15.550
you can see the images actually pop up.

359
00:21:15.550 --> 00:21:21.110
All the sniffer's doing is it's
harvesting those images as they go by.

360
00:21:21.110 --> 00:21:24.680
It looks at the traffic and says,
okay, this data and these payloads,

361
00:21:24.680 --> 00:21:25.780
that's all the same image.

362
00:21:25.780 --> 00:21:28.620
It assembles them and displays them there.

363
00:21:28.620 --> 00:21:29.903
>> So [CROSSTALK] I was talking about

364
00:21:29.903 --> 00:21:31.952
earlier that just focuses on the pictures,
then.

365
00:21:31.952 --> 00:21:32.465
>> Yeah.

366
00:21:32.465 --> 00:21:34.145
That's exactly what that one is.

367
00:21:35.195 --> 00:21:38.605
And you can see as you
go to different sites.

368
00:21:38.605 --> 00:21:42.640
If I type in,
this is kinda like a funny news site.

369
00:21:42.640 --> 00:21:46.318
You can see as it goes through that,
it will start doing the same thing.

370
00:21:46.318 --> 00:21:52.513
It starts popping stuff up on screen and
just scrolling right by and

371
00:21:52.513 --> 00:21:56.283
saying this is what I found on this site.

372
00:21:56.283 --> 00:22:01.996
So it's pretty neat when you
start taking a look at it.

373
00:22:01.996 --> 00:22:06.000
You start seeing all these things flow by.

374
00:22:06.000 --> 00:22:10.005
I don't know in a practical sense
how really good it is, but.

375
00:22:10.005 --> 00:22:14.640
>> [LAUGH] Still good to see the fact
that they've got these sniffers that

376
00:22:14.640 --> 00:22:16.030
are very focused.

377
00:22:16.030 --> 00:22:17.330
I didn't have to write any filters.

378
00:22:17.330 --> 00:22:18.920
Didn't have to do anything crazy.

379
00:22:18.920 --> 00:22:23.240
This one grabs images and we can find
others that are specific to certain

380
00:22:23.240 --> 00:22:25.470
things so that's some very handy stuff.

381
00:22:25.470 --> 00:22:30.120
>> Yeah, it can be a good way to kinda
see what people are looking at on your

382
00:22:30.120 --> 00:22:30.800
network.

383
00:22:30.800 --> 00:22:34.040
I've heard of places do that,
having done stuff like that,

384
00:22:34.040 --> 00:22:36.648
and they're just, why do we do that?

385
00:22:36.648 --> 00:22:39.850
>> [LAUGH] All right, well,
I'll tell you what, Sean.

386
00:22:39.850 --> 00:22:42.460
I know we got more that we
wanna talk about sniffers.

387
00:22:42.460 --> 00:22:46.550
But looking at the clock, we're about
out of time for this episode, so

388
00:22:46.550 --> 00:22:51.110
let's go ahead and call it here, and
we'll do another episode on sniffing.

389
00:22:51.110 --> 00:22:51.880
Sound like a plan?

390
00:22:51.880 --> 00:22:52.670
>> Sounds good.

391
00:22:52.670 --> 00:22:55.000
>> All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed watching this one.

392
00:22:55.000 --> 00:22:57.620
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

393
00:22:57.620 --> 00:22:58.740
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

394
00:22:58.740 --> 00:22:59.630
>> And we'll see you next time.

395
00:22:59.630 --> 00:23:05.860
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: There are a lot of different sniffers that can grab a multitude of useful information, so learning more about all the tools and different functions of a sniffer should help to better evaluate which set of unique capabilities and options should be utilized in different situations. Viewers will hear about different sniffers, how they can be used to capture information and different types of traffic, and the things one has to worry about with sniffers on a modern network.
episodes.title: Using Sniffers Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.111
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.111 --> 00:00:07.172
Hello.

3
00:00:07.172 --> 00:00:15.450
And welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.450 --> 00:00:16.530
I'm your host, Mike Roderick.

5
00:00:16.530 --> 00:00:18.280
And with me today is Mister Sean Oriyano.

6
00:00:18.280 --> 00:00:19.390
How you doing Sean?

7
00:00:19.390 --> 00:00:20.510
>> I'm doing pretty good.

8
00:00:20.510 --> 00:00:22.240
How you doing?
>> I'm doing fantastic.

9
00:00:22.240 --> 00:00:26.230
We've got another exciting episode
coming your way here at ITProTV.

10
00:00:26.230 --> 00:00:30.550
We're continuing on with our
Kali Linux series and in particular,

11
00:00:30.550 --> 00:00:32.540
we're talking about sniffers.

12
00:00:32.540 --> 00:00:34.760
So if you missed the previous episode,
make sure you go back and

13
00:00:34.760 --> 00:00:36.100
check that one out.

14
00:00:36.100 --> 00:00:37.600
We got our intro to sniffers and

15
00:00:37.600 --> 00:00:41.130
we've already gone over a few
different types of sniffers.

16
00:00:41.130 --> 00:00:43.410
There's so many though and
then they're so fun to use.

17
00:00:43.410 --> 00:00:45.490
Now they give us a lot
of good information.

18
00:00:45.490 --> 00:00:49.340
We're gonna continue on taking
a look at different sniffers,

19
00:00:49.340 --> 00:00:51.940
as well as talking about some of
the caveats or some of the things that

20
00:00:51.940 --> 00:00:55.190
we've got to worry about with
sniffers in our modern networks.

21
00:00:55.190 --> 00:00:57.410
So Sean,
let's get back into sniffers though.

22
00:00:57.410 --> 00:01:01.400
I know we took a look at a couple,
we looked at Wireshark.

23
00:01:01.400 --> 00:01:04.540
We looked at EtherApe, which was
a nice kind of a protocol analyzer.

24
00:01:04.540 --> 00:01:07.377
It didn't really show us the raw packets,
but

25
00:01:07.377 --> 00:01:12.240
it showed us who we were connecting to and
what protocols were being used.

26
00:01:12.240 --> 00:01:14.990
We also saw Driftnet,

27
00:01:14.990 --> 00:01:19.790
that grabbed all the images that
were flowing by on the network.

28
00:01:19.790 --> 00:01:21.360
So a couple of cool ones there.

29
00:01:21.360 --> 00:01:23.630
What else do you wanna take a look at?

30
00:01:23.630 --> 00:01:27.890
>> Okay, we do have some
other ones in the bag here.

31
00:01:27.890 --> 00:01:33.690
The one I really think that needs to
be brought up is what they call dsniff.

32
00:01:33.690 --> 00:01:36.900
And dsniff just isn't one thing,
by the way.

33
00:01:36.900 --> 00:01:38.555
It's more than one.

34
00:01:38.555 --> 00:01:41.790
It's accomplishes a good number of tasks.

35
00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:46.595
Now we did previously talk about
dsniff in a previous segment,

36
00:01:46.595 --> 00:01:50.230
but not we kinda wanna
flush that out a bit more.

37
00:01:50.230 --> 00:01:55.590
Cuz it does so much more than be
used just as an exploitation tool.

38
00:01:55.590 --> 00:01:58.660
It is designed to be a sniffer and
it does that quite well,

39
00:01:58.660 --> 00:02:01.294
it's just the fact that when
we talked about it previously.

40
00:02:01.294 --> 00:02:04.270
We're using it to gain
information that could be used to

41
00:02:04.270 --> 00:02:06.180
gain access to someone's account.

42
00:02:06.180 --> 00:02:10.290
So what we wanna do is we
wanna look at the whole thing.

43
00:02:10.290 --> 00:02:13.350
What dsniff is, is dsniff is like,

44
00:02:13.350 --> 00:02:19.050
say the suite of tools, dsniff is
just one tool as part of that bundle.

45
00:02:19.050 --> 00:02:22.360
The other tools do just
a bunch of different things.

46
00:02:22.360 --> 00:02:26.130
Some of the stuff we will
look at later on, but

47
00:02:26.130 --> 00:02:31.050
we do wanna start talking and
bringing this into your thought process.

48
00:02:31.050 --> 00:02:36.600
What we have is the first
one in here which is dsniff.

49
00:02:36.600 --> 00:02:39.470
Dsniff, it's simple,
you just go through and

50
00:02:39.470 --> 00:02:43.210
do -i and
tell it what interface to listen on.

51
00:02:43.210 --> 00:02:45.370
And boom, it's listening, okay?

52
00:02:45.370 --> 00:02:47.370
Now nothing showing up, I know.

53
00:02:47.370 --> 00:02:50.010
It's like, what's going on in there?

54
00:02:50.010 --> 00:02:51.760
Well what it's waiting for

55
00:02:51.760 --> 00:02:57.600
is if I was to now open up a browser,
open up an FTP client.

56
00:02:57.600 --> 00:03:03.220
I could just start typing in my username
and password and connect to it.

57
00:03:03.220 --> 00:03:06.060
If dsniff is running and it's running,

58
00:03:06.060 --> 00:03:10.810
as you can clearly see here,
it picks up that FTP traffic.

59
00:03:10.810 --> 00:03:15.210
It will now look at that traffic and
say filter out everything,

60
00:03:15.210 --> 00:03:16.550
the data transfer, everything.

61
00:03:16.550 --> 00:03:21.670
All I wanna display back on screen is the
server address you're connecting to and

62
00:03:21.670 --> 00:03:23.380
the username and password.

63
00:03:23.380 --> 00:03:25.270
That's all it will show you.

64
00:03:25.270 --> 00:03:28.470
It will let the other
stuff just do whatever.

65
00:03:28.470 --> 00:03:32.699
And so it will do that with
a multitude of different protocols.

66
00:03:33.900 --> 00:03:37.990
Some really kind of ones that you're
probably not gonna encounter nowadays.

67
00:03:37.990 --> 00:03:40.550
Other ones, you definitely are.

68
00:03:40.550 --> 00:03:45.450
If you're passing passwords over HTTP,
which you can, it will pick those up.

69
00:03:45.450 --> 00:03:49.430
Obviously, FTP it will do,
the mail protocols it will pick up.

70
00:03:49.430 --> 00:03:55.660
All you have to do for
stuff like SMTP and IMAP and

71
00:03:55.660 --> 00:04:00.680
POP, all those guys is just hit send or
receive on your client.

72
00:04:00.680 --> 00:04:04.520
And wherever the credentials are being
passed, it will pick them up and

73
00:04:04.520 --> 00:04:08.168
display them onscreen, telling you
this is the server you went to,

74
00:04:08.168 --> 00:04:10.350
this is your account username and done.

75
00:04:10.350 --> 00:04:10.970
>> Nice.

76
00:04:10.970 --> 00:04:14.250
Now, it's not breaking the password,
so if it's encrypted or hashed,

77
00:04:14.250 --> 00:04:16.180
it's just gonna show you that hash value?

78
00:04:16.180 --> 00:04:20.840
>> Well, if it's hash or
anything like that,

79
00:04:20.840 --> 00:04:24.370
it's just gonna say it doesn't read,
it's just not gonna display anything.

80
00:04:24.370 --> 00:04:26.770
If the whole thing is
encrypted using SSL or

81
00:04:26.770 --> 00:04:29.610
something, then it's not

00:13:14.145 --> 00:13:18.435
But what if you have a situation

00:13:18.435 --> 00:13:21.955

00:13:21.955 --> 00:13:23.355

00:13:23.355 --> 00:13:27.775
You're gonna have situations where

00:13:27.775 --> 00:13:33.320

00:13:33.320 --> 00:13:36.560

00:13:36.560 --> 00:13:39.310
So they've ripped out those

244
00:13:39.310 --> 00:13:43.360
It's on the other side of a switch,

245
00:13:43.360 --> 00:13:46.340
We have to so something about that switch.

246
00:13:46.340 --> 00:13:48.940
So we've got tools that
are gonna come into play.

247
00:13:48.940 --> 00:13:52.890
Remember, the way a switch works,
a switch keeps track of traffic and

248
00:13:52.890 --> 00:13:57.050
where it's going to go by
looking at the MAC addresses.

249
00:13:57.050 --> 00:14:01.210
It keeps track of those by having what
they call content addressable memory

250
00:14:01.210 --> 00:14:02.800
inside the switch.

251
00:14:02.800 --> 00:14:08.733
So it starts keeping track of MAC
addresses that are coming through, and

252
00:14:08.733 --> 00:14:13.995
so it knows where things are, and
it can get into the right spot.

253
00:14:13.995 --> 00:14:20.630
Now, if that memory gets filled up,
the switch can start having problems.

254
00:14:20.630 --> 00:14:25.790
Now in the old days,
if you started filling up that piece of

255
00:14:25.790 --> 00:14:30.890
memory too fast or put too much in there,
the switch would actually fail open.

256
00:14:30.890 --> 00:14:32.430
It would fail right open.

257
00:14:32.430 --> 00:14:33.320
>> Turn into a hub then basically.

258
00:14:33.320 --> 00:14:34.812
>> Yeah, it would turn into a hub.

259
00:14:34.812 --> 00:14:39.270
It would fail out into a hub.

260
00:14:39.270 --> 00:14:43.110
Which now is great for you as
an attacker cuz you can see everything.

261
00:14:43.110 --> 00:14:50.100
All the stuff we've seen here can be done
without any effort whatsoever on a hub.

262
00:14:50.100 --> 00:14:52.149
Okay, so that's all well and good.

263
00:14:52.149 --> 00:14:57.500
What if it doesn't do that?

264
00:14:57.500 --> 00:15:01.670
Modern switches,
most of them tend to fail the other way.

265
00:15:01.670 --> 00:15:06.980
Where if you beat on it enough, it will
fill up that memory and it fails closed.

266
00:15:06.980 --> 00:15:13.400
Until it gets reset or
it can deal with what it has on hand.

267
00:15:13.400 --> 00:15:18.480
So thinking about this,
how do we cause a situation where

268
00:15:20.160 --> 00:15:22.320

269
00:15:22.320 --> 00:15:28.250
Well the way we can do that is

270
00:15:28.250 --> 00:15:31.220
Now we have, of course,

00:15:31.220 --> 00:15:35.993
One of the tools that we have to do

00:15:35.993 --> 00:15:41.869
And what we have is you can type

00:15:43.010 --> 00:15:45.291

00:15:45.291 --> 00:15:46.040

00:15:48.136 --> 00:15:51.346

you can see it just blasting stuff by,

00:15:57.608 --> 00:16:01.360

00:16:01.360 --> 00:16:05.870
If I keep letting this go, it has

280
00:16:05.870 --> 00:16:09.948

I think it's like every minute or

00:16:09.948 --> 00:16:17.050

282
00:16:17.050 --> 00:16:20.250
So it's gonna crush in short order,

283
00:16:20.250 --> 00:16:25.400
it's gonna crush a switch in there with
the amount of traffic it's getting, so

284
00:16:26.500 --> 00:16:31.110
this would be a good way
to throttle that switch, so

285
00:16:31.110 --> 00:16:35.040

if it will fail like that.

286
00:16:35.040 --> 00:16:35.960
>> Right.

287
00:16:35.960 --> 00:16:38.110
And that's something we've
gotta find out I guess, and

288
00:16:38.110 --> 00:16:39.880
really only one way to find out.

289
00:16:39.880 --> 00:16:43.990
Remember, you compromise a machine,
you get on to that machine, but

290
00:16:43.990 --> 00:16:47.860
the problem is that machine is hooked up
to the corporate network or whatever, and

291
00:16:47.860 --> 00:16:49.090
it's connected to a switch.

292
00:16:49.090 --> 00:16:52.500
And as Sean said and we've learned in
Network Plus, that's a point to point

293
00:16:52.500 --> 00:16:56.200
connection between you and the switch,
and all you're gonna see, that switch

294
00:16:56.200 --> 00:16:59.950
is only allowing traffic that's destined
for that node that's out that port.

295
00:16:59.950 --> 00:17:01.890
So the idea is a tool like Macof.

296
00:17:01.890 --> 00:17:03.680
Flood it with Mac address.

297
00:17:03.680 --> 00:17:08.220
It can't keep track of who's out what's
port and, hopefully, fails open.

298
00:17:08.220 --> 00:17:11.318
And now it's like a hub, and I can
capture all the traffic that's going by,

299
00:17:11.318 --> 00:17:13.400
cuz now all traffic goes out every port.

300
00:17:13.400 --> 00:17:15.520
There's a problem we have,
modern networks.

301
00:17:15.520 --> 00:17:17.490
Nobody buys hubs anymore.

302
00:17:17.490 --> 00:17:21.080
Switches are comparable or
in price to a hub.

303
00:17:21.080 --> 00:17:22.570
And you get so much more functionality,

304
00:17:22.570 --> 00:17:26.790
and we depend on that to make
those contention domains in our

305
00:17:28.460 --> 00:17:33.890
Ethernet networks that you're gonna have
to have a tool like this under your belt.

306
00:17:33.890 --> 00:17:35.710
>> It's definitely not the only
one that does it either.

307
00:17:35.710 --> 00:17:38.050
There are other tools that
do this sort of thing,

308
00:17:38.050 --> 00:17:43.650
that will just blast stuff at a switch
with the intention of seeing if they

And like I said, some will fail

either way you're gonna do

I mean not hopefully for us but,

00:18:28.720 --> 00:18:31.718
But, maybe that's what

>> Yep.

>> A good tool to have in the belt,
and as you said,

there's others that'll let me

we did do an analysis service

So [LAUGH] keep that in mind

Might also remember, when you blast that

I just ran that really quickly

>> You would have to keep an eye on what

>> And that's one of those things you're

Well, how do I know if I'm a on

00:21:02.440 --> 00:21:05.490
So one of the ways you might be able

374
00:21:10.380 --> 00:21:10.930
>> Exactly.

00:21:10.930 --> 00:21:16.790
It's pretty much common sense once

00:21:42.280 --> 00:21:42.790

Sean again,
a lot of good information on sniffers, and

There are ways that I can

episodes.description: Social engineering is a collection of different techniques used to take advantage of the human nature to get people to give up information that they shouldn't. Viewers will hear about what all social engineering entails and also see a brief demonstration of the Social Engineering Toolkit (SET) within Kali.
episodes.title: Social Engineering Toolkit

episodes.description: Before one performs a penetration test on a web application, one should take a closer look at what it's expected to do and common issues that are associated with it. Viewers will hear about web applications in general, the various tools available in Kali for web application analysis, and about the client server relationship between the web server, the applications, and the client.
episodes.title: Web Applications
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

[MUSIC]

Hello, and

00:01:09.360 --> 00:01:12.730
when we talk about web applications,

00:01:12.730 --> 00:01:15.220
we really wanna kind of get

00:01:15.220 --> 00:01:18.960
so we can understand the tools and

00:01:18.960 --> 00:01:22.730

00:01:22.730 --> 00:01:26.740
So to get things started we talk

But to really do a full-blown and

50
00:02:46.880 --> 00:02:49.990

00:02:49.990 --> 00:02:53.154

so that's always a great thing to have.

00:01:53.070 --> 00:01:55.730

00:02:00.865 --> 00:02:05.143

00:02:07.840 --> 00:02:13.270

00:02:13.270 --> 00:02:18.590

00:02:18.590 --> 00:02:21.430
All these things should be

00:02:21.430 --> 00:02:24.570
But you really wanna take a look

44
00:02:24.570 --> 00:02:26.570

45
00:02:26.570 --> 00:02:30.900
I have it for years, and
stuff like this situation,

46
00:02:30.900 --> 00:02:33.738
one of the things I'm gonna bring

47
00:02:33.738 --> 00:02:39.740
Vulnerability scanners,
I've compared in some of my classes and

00:02:39.740 --> 00:02:43.960

00:02:47.830 --> 00:02:50.950

52
00:02:59.230 --> 00:03:02.750
One will pick up some things

00:03:02.750 --> 00:03:04.380

00:03:04.380 --> 00:03:08.340
One of them says oh, this is very serious

55
00:03:08.340 --> 00:03:09.450

56
00:03:09.450 --> 00:03:10.990
And then this one says,

00:03:10.990 --> 00:03:12.122
This is all, everything's all good.

58
00:03:12.122 --> 00:03:17.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's, like, that's a big problem there.

59
00:03:17.100 --> 00:03:20.340
If I just got minor issues,
that's still of a concern to me.

60
00:03:20.340 --> 00:03:21.970
Why are they over here and not here?

61
00:03:21.970 --> 00:03:22.750
>> Right.

62
00:03:22.750 --> 00:03:26.439
>> But if it's big, hey,

00:03:27.820 --> 00:03:31.040
Why is there a difference there?

64
00:03:31.040 --> 00:03:33.520
Just FYI, test these things out.

65
00:03:33.520 --> 00:03:37.520
Fortunately, you don't just

66
00:03:37.520 --> 00:03:42.340
These tools, you can test just

67
00:03:42.340 --> 00:03:46.130

00:03:46.130 --> 00:03:48.303
Remember, one of the things we mentioned,

69
00:03:48.303 --> 00:03:50.437

70
00:03:50.437 --> 00:03:55.800
Is the fact that they do make vulnerable

71
00:03:55.800 --> 00:03:59.377

software of choice,

72
00:03:59.377 --> 00:04:03.320
as a matter of fact,
turn it on, and start testing.

73
00:04:03.320 --> 00:04:06.360
And the cool thing about
having that is not only

74
00:04:06.360 --> 00:04:08.640

75
00:04:08.640 --> 00:04:11.120
You also have something that has

00:04:11.120 --> 00:04:14.160

00:04:14.160 --> 00:04:17.760
Including databases such as MySequel,

78
00:04:17.760 --> 00:04:21.500
And, then even on top of that
those vulnerabilities for

79
00:04:21.500 --> 00:04:24.422

80
00:04:24.422 --> 00:04:30.760
So, you now know purposely what they put
in there and what should be showing up.

81
00:04:30.760 --> 00:04:33.470
So you can really do that trust but
verify thing.

82
00:04:33.470 --> 00:04:35.680
They're telling you these are bad.

83
00:04:35.680 --> 00:04:40.100
If you don't find,
at the very least, those, or

84
00:04:40.100 --> 00:04:43.365
a good number of those, there's a problem.

85
00:04:43.365 --> 00:04:46.545
You may want to see if that product
is one you really want to use.

86
00:04:46.545 --> 00:04:49.125
If it misses enough of them,
that's just not good.

87
00:04:49.125 --> 00:04:50.485
>> Either your technique is off or

88
00:04:50.485 --> 00:04:54.167
the tool is not doing what it's supposed
to do and you need to check that out.

89
00:04:54.167 --> 00:04:56.327
>> Yeah, definitely ask questions.

90
00:04:56.327 --> 00:05:03.477
Ask questions to make sure you understand
why those results are the way they are.

91
00:05:03.477 --> 00:05:08.260
And if you've answered that question
to your satisfaction then, heck.

92
00:05:08.260 --> 00:05:09.930
Go ahead and use it.

93
00:05:09.930 --> 00:05:11.580
I wouldn't tell you not to.

94
00:05:11.580 --> 00:05:14.611
Just telling you, make sure that you
know that those limitations are there.

95
00:05:14.611 --> 00:05:18.013
Don't want the bad guys find out and
you've gone ahead and

96
00:05:18.013 --> 00:05:21.358

to the best of my ability.

97
00:05:21.358 --> 00:05:24.890
And this, that could leave you open

98
00:05:24.890 --> 00:05:28.320
Not only looking stupid and
questioning your abilities, but

99
00:05:28.320 --> 00:05:30.900
also it could open you up

100
00:05:30.900 --> 00:05:33.360
If it's big enough they're going to say,
well that should have picked up,

101
00:05:33.360 --> 00:05:34.330
what's your problem?

102
00:05:34.330 --> 00:05:36.420
>> And that might hurt my
job prospects in the future,

103
00:05:36.420 --> 00:05:37.845
either one of those scenarios, so.

104
00:05:37.845 --> 00:05:38.640
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

105
00:05:38.640 --> 00:05:42.430
>> I could have a future
as a pen tester anyway.

106
00:05:42.430 --> 00:05:47.220
>> Yeah, there's people that have been

00:05:47.220 --> 00:05:48.320

108
00:05:48.320 --> 00:05:51.480
And these are not reputable

00:05:51.480 --> 00:05:54.780
They'll take the results out of

110
00:05:54.780 --> 00:05:57.640
paste it someplace else and

111
00:05:57.640 --> 00:06:00.940
And that makes you look even worse

112
00:06:00.940 --> 00:06:02.480

113
00:06:02.480 --> 00:06:05.158
If you're doing that you probably don't.

114
00:06:05.158 --> 00:06:08.565
You copy it over and paste it in there,

00:06:08.565 --> 00:06:11.960
Nessus and someone looks and

116
00:06:11.960 --> 00:06:14.950
Then they might challenge you on it,

00:06:14.950 --> 00:06:18.100
you're even plagiarizing
stuff from another place.

118
00:06:18.100 --> 00:06:19.760
That will end your career pretty quickly,

119
00:06:19.760 --> 00:06:23.240
decapitated by someone really
quick if that happens.

120
00:06:23.240 --> 00:06:25.403
So don't do that.

121
00:06:25.403 --> 00:06:29.515
I've stuck some stuff in my reports
that I've found in Nessus and

122
00:06:29.515 --> 00:06:33.348

00:06:33.348 --> 00:06:36.125
But it was very clear

00:06:36.125 --> 00:06:38.858
I would cite it saying yeah,
this is where this came from and

125
00:06:38.858 --> 00:06:42.060
I just pulled it over instead

126
00:06:42.060 --> 00:06:46.760
People have done that too, but

127
00:06:46.760 --> 00:06:47.640
know your environment.

here's what fuzzing is and

00:08:06.537 --> 00:08:09.545

00:08:09.545 --> 00:08:12.630

00:08:15.928 --> 00:08:19.560
Heck, when I wrote that CEH book.

00:08:19.560 --> 00:08:23.420
When I wrote that thing I mentioned that

00:08:23.420 --> 00:08:28.140

154
00:08:28.140 --> 00:08:32.870
Because to really understand that you

155
00:08:32.870 --> 00:08:35.690
that to really get
the full power of it and

156
00:08:35.690 --> 00:08:38.650
that's a big can of worms

157
00:08:38.650 --> 00:08:44.310
But what fuzzing is,
just in a very brief sense, in a nutshell,

158
00:08:44.310 --> 00:08:47.750
is it means you're feeding different
ranges and different combinations of

159
00:08:47.750 --> 00:08:51.850
values into an application,
to watch and see how it responds.

160
00:08:51.850 --> 00:08:56.120
Because when you feed a range of values
into it, and maybe even outside or

161
00:08:56.120 --> 00:09:00.420
different ways than it's expecting, that
application can do funny things and may

162
00:09:00.420 --> 00:09:03.740
even give people access or allow them to
do stuff they shouldn't be allowed to do.

163
00:09:03.740 --> 00:09:04.615
>> Yeah, absolutely.

164
00:09:04.615 --> 00:09:09.070
You got a field on a web form that's
expecting your phone number, and

165
00:09:09.070 --> 00:09:11.560
what if somebody puts pound symbols
all the way through it, and

166
00:09:11.560 --> 00:09:15.390
all of a sudden a shell pops open or
an error message

167
00:09:15.390 --> 00:09:19.940
pops up that spits out all kinds of
information about the back-end database.

168
00:09:19.940 --> 00:09:21.380
Or it crashes a server.

169
00:09:21.380 --> 00:09:24.630
The database hangs up cuz
it's trying to process this,

170
00:09:24.630 --> 00:09:29.440
and there's a data type set on the field
that it's trying to dump that value into.

171
00:09:29.440 --> 00:09:33.590
So fuzzing it allows you to throw
stuff at it, that's not expected.

172
00:09:33.590 --> 00:09:37.760
A lot of times, when you're developing
applications, you're developing this.

173
00:09:37.760 --> 00:09:40.510
You're like okay here's a user name field,
here's a password field,

174
00:09:40.510 --> 00:09:41.930
here's a phone number field.

175
00:09:41.930 --> 00:09:45.840
And as you're developing it, you're typing
in a dummy user name, a dummy last name or

176
00:09:45.840 --> 00:09:48.260
password, and a dummy phone number.

177
00:09:48.260 --> 00:09:51.130
You never even think about what if
somebody put their name in the phone

178
00:09:51.130 --> 00:09:52.000
number field, right?

179
00:09:52.000 --> 00:09:54.630
So those are the kind of
things that fuzzing can find.

180
00:09:54.630 --> 00:09:57.950
It exposed some of those weaknesses
in the code and those applications.

181
00:09:57.950 --> 00:09:59.268
>> Yeah.
They're starting to check for

182
00:09:59.268 --> 00:09:59.870
a little more.

183
00:09:59.870 --> 00:10:01.860
It's tools like this
that are helping it out.

184
00:10:01.860 --> 00:10:03.110
But yeah, you're right.

185
00:10:03.110 --> 00:10:08.140
When you're developing
an application it used to be that,

186
00:10:08.140 --> 00:10:09.580
you kind of had blinders on.

187
00:10:09.580 --> 00:10:14.470
You wrote it with a certain process in

00:10:14.470 --> 00:10:15.840

00:10:15.840 --> 00:10:18.330

this is the way things are gonna move, and

yeah, if I have something

00:12:04.825 --> 00:12:08.128
>> We got a question in the chatroom

00:12:08.128 --> 00:12:11.720
would you restrict fuzzing to test

00:12:11.720 --> 00:12:16.160

231
00:12:16.160 --> 00:12:18.449

00:12:21.560 --> 00:12:23.960
>> I would say if you
have the opportunity,

00:12:23.960 --> 00:12:27.310
test environments are,

that test and

00:12:29.590 --> 00:12:33.889

but if it gets deployed.

00:12:35.210 --> 00:12:38.950
If you find that input validation and

to tell them that this is what the problem
is, to give them a chance to maybe address

00:12:48.160 --> 00:12:52.890

00:12:52.890 --> 00:12:56.650
Or they may decide,
hey rock and roll, go ahead.

00:12:56.650 --> 00:12:59.830
If you crash it,

00:12:59.830 --> 00:13:02.750
People sometimes will do that.

00:13:02.750 --> 00:13:08.580
But I wouldn't count on it,

00:13:08.580 --> 00:13:12.460
thing is like ecommerce or something, they

245
00:13:12.460 --> 00:13:16.746
You're basically going over there and just

00:13:21.108 --> 00:13:25.506
So you really wanna,

00:13:25.506 --> 00:13:28.000

00:13:28.000 --> 00:13:29.800

00:13:33.350 --> 00:13:35.960

00:13:35.960 --> 00:13:41.310
It's one of those things that,

00:13:41.310 --> 00:13:46.030

00:13:55.770 --> 00:14:01.330

00:14:01.330 --> 00:14:03.390
all those risks really

00:14:03.390 --> 00:14:06.410

the bad guys are gonna try.

261
00:14:12.494 --> 00:14:17.219
You don't really know what they have or
whether they're gonna be separable, so

262
00:14:17.219 --> 00:14:19.659
you gotta test it, to be a thorough test.

263
00:14:19.659 --> 00:14:22.506
But we do the old,
remember the phrase CYA comes to mind.

264
00:14:22.506 --> 00:14:24.039
>> [LAUGH] Oh, yeah.
>> Back in the beginning,

265
00:14:24.039 --> 00:14:26.345
when we got hired on,
we made sure we said hey,

266
00:14:26.345 --> 00:14:29.208
if we do a thorough test there's
a chance this goes down.

267
00:14:29.208 --> 00:14:32.840
Maybe they've got certain hours they want
to perform the test in, that way if there

268
00:14:32.840 --> 00:14:38.000
is, something happens, they've got time to
restore it before business the next day.

269
00:14:38.000 --> 00:14:41.590
Or maybe they've got their own test
environment and they say well,

270
00:14:41.590 --> 00:14:45.190
if you're gonna do something like that,
let's test against this non-production

271
00:14:45.190 --> 00:14:48.950
duplication of our production environment,
or something like that.

272
00:14:48.950 --> 00:14:52.340
Really the main thing I think is,
make sure they're aware of it, don't do

273
00:14:52.340 --> 00:14:55.400
anything without letting them know there's
a chance, hey I might crash your server.

274
00:14:55.400 --> 00:14:57.730
You don't want to surprise
them with something like that.

275
00:14:57.730 --> 00:15:02.760
>> A healthy abundance of caution
is never going to hurt you.

276
00:15:02.760 --> 00:15:08.910
I'd rather get someone on the phone, and
just tell them, this is what I found.

277
00:15:08.910 --> 00:15:13.090
I do believe there is
a serious problem here.

278
00:15:13.090 --> 00:15:17.249
So, I am not gonna wait til I get to
the report, I'm telling you right now.

279
00:15:17.249 --> 00:15:21.244
And, do you want me to actually
take advantage of that,

280
00:15:21.244 --> 00:15:25.324
or would you just rather go ahead and
analyze your code and

281
00:15:25.324 --> 00:15:29.747
fix it quietly,
without me causing some major disturbance.

282
00:15:29.747 --> 00:15:32.637
Let them make the choice, but don't just
take it on yourself to go through and

283
00:15:32.637 --> 00:15:35.280
yeah, I'm gonna kick this thing down and
see what happens.

284
00:15:35.280 --> 00:15:36.675
That's not gonna turn out well.

285
00:15:36.675 --> 00:15:38.120
>> Right.
You're not gonna find too many

286
00:15:38.120 --> 00:15:40.275
clients going that was awesome,
do it again!

287
00:15:40.275 --> 00:15:41.760
>> [LAUGH]
>> No, they're not gonna do it.

288
00:15:41.760 --> 00:15:43.534
So be careful on that.

289
00:15:43.534 --> 00:15:45.220
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you can, then awesome.

290
00:15:45.220 --> 00:15:46.736
I would totally work for
a client like that.

291
00:15:46.736 --> 00:15:48.282
>> Right?
[LAUGH].

292
00:15:48.282 --> 00:15:51.861
So lots of different tools we can use
then, to put these web servers and

293
00:15:51.861 --> 00:15:54.786
the applications that are running
on them to their test.

294
00:15:54.786 --> 00:15:58.986
Any of them that you find particularly
useful, or we wanna take a look at?

295
00:15:58.986 --> 00:16:01.262
>> We are gonna take a look at
a number of other things here.

296
00:16:01.262 --> 00:16:08.110
There is a whole wide world of
these different tools out there.

297
00:16:08.110 --> 00:16:11.830
Just a couple more categories
to quickly mention,

298
00:16:11.830 --> 00:16:15.790
we talked about the web crawlers here.

299
00:16:15.790 --> 00:16:18.680
We can kinda go through and
it will look at a site.

300
00:16:18.680 --> 00:16:21.050
And then we also have the web
vulnerability scanners.

301
00:16:21.050 --> 00:16:23.360
I mean, look at the number of web
vulnerability scanners are on that.

302
00:16:23.360 --> 00:16:25.460
That's even one of those
scrolling menu deals.

303
00:16:25.460 --> 00:16:30.333
So you've got a lot of things to
bring to bear on a web application

304
00:16:30.333 --> 00:16:34.951
that you can check to see what
your particular problems are.

305
00:16:34.951 --> 00:16:39.693
They've got pretty much everything for
almost whatever you wanna do, and

306
00:16:39.693 --> 00:16:42.261
some interesting names in there, too.

307
00:16:43.398 --> 00:16:44.862
Whatweb.

308
00:16:44.862 --> 00:16:45.547
>> What web?

309
00:16:45.547 --> 00:16:49.750
>> Yeah, Whatweb, and
Hadbuster, I like that.

310
00:16:49.750 --> 00:16:52.408
Grabber, and my favorite, Cadaver.

311
00:16:52.408 --> 00:16:53.035
>> Cadaver.

312
00:16:53.035 --> 00:16:54.695
>> Cadaver, yeah.

313
00:16:54.695 --> 00:16:58.660
>> When you're doing a ping test
against a web server like this or

314
00:16:58.660 --> 00:17:02.703
any web server, do you do like
the server application first and

315
00:17:02.703 --> 00:17:06.000
then the applications that run on it or
vice versa?

316
00:17:06.000 --> 00:17:07.260
Or does it really matter?

317
00:17:07.260 --> 00:17:10.550
Do you focus on one or the other or
do you just start going at it and

318
00:17:10.550 --> 00:17:13.380
see what you can find?

319
00:17:13.380 --> 00:17:16.987
>> I will typically, if I can, kind of see
what I can figure out, because if you look

320
00:17:16.987 --> 00:17:20.491
at it you're probably already getting it
on the web server way before you get it

321
00:17:20.491 --> 00:17:23.491
on the application because you
need to do a reconnaissance phase.

322
00:17:23.491 --> 00:17:25.739
You're already pulling
some of that already.

323
00:17:25.739 --> 00:17:28.640
So, you already have kinda that in hand.

324
00:17:28.640 --> 00:17:31.530
Now, when you start going over and
test the web application,

325
00:17:31.530 --> 00:17:33.570
you're gonna grab the stuff
from the web server anyway.

326
00:17:33.570 --> 00:17:34.140
>> Got ya.

327
00:17:34.140 --> 00:17:37.524
>> And most of these tools
kinda treat them as they're so

328
00:17:37.524 --> 00:17:41.362
tightly in bed with one another
that they just kinda figure,

329
00:17:41.362 --> 00:17:46.300
we'll test them as a unit not as
there's this and there's that.

330
00:17:46.300 --> 00:17:48.310
>> Very good, very good.

331
00:17:48.310 --> 00:17:50.900
All right,
well let's do some testing shall we?

332
00:17:50.900 --> 00:17:51.460
>> Yeah.
As far,

333
00:17:51.460 --> 00:17:55.550
I mean to answer your question there
too by the way, do I have a favorite?

334
00:17:55.550 --> 00:18:00.720
And I don't even know if I'd wanna go
that far and say there's a favorite.

335
00:18:00.720 --> 00:18:03.915
There's some neat ones in here to be sure.

336
00:18:03.915 --> 00:18:04.510
>> Mm-hm.

337
00:18:04.510 --> 00:18:07.410
>> You're gonna take a look at these ones
in here we're gonna introduce you to.

338
00:18:07.410 --> 00:18:09.460
No way we're gonna introduce
you to all of them.

339
00:18:09.460 --> 00:18:12.280
But you're gonna look through these and
go yeah, there's some stuff in there that

340
00:18:12.280 --> 00:18:16.420
does some pretty, that's some pretty
neat stuff, some pretty helpful stuff.

341
00:18:16.420 --> 00:18:19.370
You're gonna have to do your
own kind of assessment and

342
00:18:19.370 --> 00:18:23.630
use your own judgement to figure out
which ones are gonna be your favorites.

343
00:18:23.630 --> 00:18:29.470
And you probably are gonna
have favorites when you look

344
00:18:29.470 --> 00:18:36.370
at stuff like things like w3af and
Vega and Burp Suite, Nikto.

345
00:18:36.370 --> 00:18:39.376
We talked about Nikto's cousin, Wikto.

346
00:18:39.376 --> 00:18:41.661
>> [LAUGH]
>> Over in CEH and so yeah, so

347
00:18:41.661 --> 00:18:42.616
we had that.

348
00:18:42.616 --> 00:18:44.276
>> Nice.

349
00:18:44.276 --> 00:18:48.152
>> You're gonna see that
yeah there's crossover.

350
00:18:48.152 --> 00:18:52.050
You're just gonna have to figure out
which ones are gonna do the job for you.

351
00:18:52.050 --> 00:18:55.460
Cool thing about it is that some of these
things even have other versions out there

352
00:18:55.460 --> 00:18:58.440
that you can also install and
upgrade from there.

353
00:18:58.440 --> 00:19:00.610
Selling cases for free.

354
00:19:00.610 --> 00:19:03.770
Some of them even have
versions that run on Windows.

355
00:19:03.770 --> 00:19:05.790
Burp Suite is one of the things that,

356
00:19:05.790 --> 00:19:08.210
there really is only one version of
Burp Suite, if you can believe that.

357
00:19:08.210 --> 00:19:09.615
There's actually only one version of it.

358
00:19:09.615 --> 00:19:10.400
>> Mm-hm.

359
00:19:10.400 --> 00:19:15.920
>> It's written in Java so you can
actually, if you've downloaded the CEH

360
00:19:15.920 --> 00:19:20.860
course, if you've downloaded it,
you can grab that file right off of your

361
00:19:20.860 --> 00:19:26.660
Windows system, drop it over on any Linux
system and it'll run, exact same way.

362
00:19:26.660 --> 00:19:28.442
So that's kind of neat.

363
00:19:28.442 --> 00:19:29.896
[CROSSTALK]
>> Yeah, that's uncommon.

364
00:19:29.896 --> 00:19:30.396
>> Yeah.

365
00:19:32.000 --> 00:19:34.180
>> So that's a good thing
with this type of stuff,

366
00:19:34.180 --> 00:19:37.100
so we're gonna see some of these things
and it's up to you to chose what your

367
00:19:37.100 --> 00:19:40.410
favorites are, like I said there's so
many different ones.

368
00:19:40.410 --> 00:19:44.385
So, we've got places that
we're gonna start in here.

369
00:19:44.385 --> 00:19:45.290
>> Mm-hm.

370
00:19:45.290 --> 00:19:48.628
>> We're gonna take a look at
things like the Burp Suite.

371
00:19:48.628 --> 00:19:50.485
So we're gonna take a look at that again.

372
00:19:50.485 --> 00:19:52.294
We'll take a look at Vega.

373
00:19:52.294 --> 00:19:56.780
Something that does the same type of
thing, with some other stuff thrown in.

374
00:19:56.780 --> 00:20:02.007
We are gonna take a look at the W3F,
OWASP and

375
00:20:02.007 --> 00:20:08.350
then we'll get a few other
ones in there along the way.

376
00:20:08.350 --> 00:20:11.380
So if you wanna kind of follow along,

377
00:20:11.380 --> 00:20:14.500
those are the big ones we're
gonna be using right off the bat.

378
00:20:14.500 --> 00:20:17.650
And then we can kinda throw some
other ones in along the way.

379
00:20:18.880 --> 00:20:21.390
And this is actually a good
point here too, by the way.

380
00:20:21.390 --> 00:20:26.310
The client may sometimes tell you
what tools that they want to use.

381
00:20:27.650 --> 00:20:34.010
Yeah, I have seen that type of stuff
happen, or heard of that stuff happen.

382
00:20:34.010 --> 00:20:36.080
I've never had that happened to me,
to be honest.

383
00:20:36.080 --> 00:20:40.600
So what I have had happen, is, I agree
with what you're saying, the client

384
00:20:40.600 --> 00:20:44.660
will specify what tools to use, cuz they
might be mitigating a previous finding,

385
00:20:44.660 --> 00:20:48.650
and attempting to reconstruct
the original findings to compare results.

386
00:20:48.650 --> 00:20:52.201
>> Try not to compare apples to oranges if
you had somebody come in and do a test,

387
00:20:52.201 --> 00:20:54.826
and they used a certain tool,
they got a set of results.

388
00:20:54.826 --> 00:20:57.779
You think you've fixed them, and
so you want someone to come in and

389
00:20:57.779 --> 00:21:00.649
use the same tools to see if those
results have changed, maybe.

390
00:21:00.649 --> 00:21:04.144
>> Yeah, it very well could be that.

391
00:21:04.144 --> 00:21:09.364
The situations that I've had that
kinda sorta talk to this is the client

392
00:21:09.364 --> 00:21:14.236
will have me come in and has a report
that they generate in XYZ tool,

393
00:21:14.236 --> 00:21:17.803
whatever it is,
they'll bring that in and say,

394
00:21:17.803 --> 00:21:22.762
this is what our guy found, or
this is what we found when we ran this,

395
00:21:22.762 --> 00:21:26.418
and we're concerned, and
we'll talk about it.

396
00:21:26.418 --> 00:21:30.029
They will not usually tell me,
well we want you to run the same tool.

397
00:21:30.029 --> 00:21:32.970
What they're gonna say is, well,
can you double check this?

398
00:21:32.970 --> 00:21:36.360
Or, do a more thorough
assessment to see if this is it?

399
00:21:36.360 --> 00:21:38.350
Or, is more problems we have here.

400
00:21:38.350 --> 00:21:40.960
So, I will use whatever tool I want and

401
00:21:40.960 --> 00:21:46.990
techniques I wanna use to do a thorough
examination to see what the problems are.

402
00:21:46.990 --> 00:21:50.790
And once i have that,
then I will get my report and

403
00:21:50.790 --> 00:21:54.520
give it back to them and
recommend changes.

404
00:21:54.520 --> 00:21:59.034
And what they'll do is they'll take
my report the buy recommendation on

405
00:21:59.034 --> 00:22:00.665
changes such as they are.

406
00:22:00.665 --> 00:22:04.854
Implement those, and
then they, themselves,

407
00:22:04.854 --> 00:22:08.027
may take that same tool and rerun it.

408
00:22:08.027 --> 00:22:12.319
It's within their rights to say,
hey, can you run this yourself,

409
00:22:12.319 --> 00:22:14.969
the same tool, yourself, and check it?

410
00:22:16.510 --> 00:22:21.120
I might tell them,
if they were to ask something like that,

411
00:22:21.120 --> 00:22:24.610
which I haven't, if they were to ask me,
could you run the same tool?

412
00:22:24.610 --> 00:22:28.620
I might tell them well,
I have my own stuff that does the same

413
00:22:29.730 --> 00:22:34.450
type of thing and I will go ahead and
use those tools instead.

414
00:22:34.450 --> 00:22:36.390
If you're okay with that.

415
00:22:36.390 --> 00:22:39.670
And I can't see a client saying no.

416
00:22:39.670 --> 00:22:43.990
Clients, usually, if they're calling
you [INAUDIBLE] or as the expert,

417
00:22:43.990 --> 00:22:47.520
more than likely, they're just gonna say,
okay, well, we called you as the experts

418
00:22:47.520 --> 00:22:52.930
so you go ahead and you do what's
appropriate, what you feel is appropriate.

419
00:22:52.930 --> 00:22:56.520
And so, I'll take it from there,
but they could ask us,

420
00:22:56.520 --> 00:22:57.570
it's well within their rights.

421
00:22:57.570 --> 00:22:59.250
And you're right, that does happen.

422
00:22:59.250 --> 00:23:03.150
I haven't had it happen to me, but they
very well could do that sort of thing.

423
00:23:03.150 --> 00:23:03.820
Who knows?

424
00:23:03.820 --> 00:23:06.480
Maybe I'll have someone put
that to me in the future.

425
00:23:06.480 --> 00:23:07.390
I just haven't had it yet.

426
00:23:09.310 --> 00:23:09.980
>> Well, Sean,

427
00:23:09.980 --> 00:23:12.698
I tell you looking at our clock we're
getting a little low on time here.

428
00:23:12.698 --> 00:23:16.078
Do we wanna take a look at these
tools in our next episode?

429
00:23:16.078 --> 00:23:18.549
>> Yeah, I think that's the best thing.

430
00:23:18.549 --> 00:23:21.830
I wanted to give an overview of
the different categories of tools so

431
00:23:21.830 --> 00:23:25.345
everyone is on the same thing,
we talked in our first segment about what

432
00:23:25.345 --> 00:23:29.170
web applications are and
some of the issues revolving around them.

433
00:23:29.170 --> 00:23:33.140
And now, because we have so many tools, I
wanted to use this segment to talk about,

434
00:23:33.140 --> 00:23:36.640
give you an overview of the different
types of tools that we have.

435
00:23:36.640 --> 00:23:40.630
And that was a very high level look so
what we'll do is,

436
00:23:40.630 --> 00:23:45.260
yeah we should do another segments now
looking at the individual tools, so

437
00:23:45.260 --> 00:23:49.520
you can really get a good look at
what these are and even go ahead and

438
00:23:49.520 --> 00:23:51.210
configure them yourself, and try them out.

439
00:23:51.210 --> 00:23:53.470
So, that's what we'll have coming up.

440
00:23:53.470 --> 00:23:54.490
>> Sounds like a plan to me.

441
00:23:54.490 --> 00:23:55.080
All right.

442
00:23:55.080 --> 00:23:56.160
Well, you heard it ladies and gentlemen.

443
00:23:56.160 --> 00:23:58.400
We're gonna call it there for
this particular episode.

444
00:23:58.400 --> 00:23:59.680
We hope you enjoyed watching it.

445
00:23:59.680 --> 00:24:01.583
Remember, stay tuned,
we've got another episode coming up.

446
00:24:01.583 --> 00:24:05.867
We're gonna take a look at some of the
tools we can use to do our web server and

447
00:24:05.867 --> 00:24:08.791
web application testing,
so stay tuned for that.

448
00:24:08.791 --> 00:24:11.845
But for now, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

449
00:24:11.845 --> 00:24:12.983
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

450
00:24:12.983 --> 00:24:14.875
>> And we'll see you next time.

451
00:24:14.875 --> 00:24:20.090
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Web crawlers are another facet to do web analysis with, which can give information on the structure of a website and test it for vulnerabilities. Viewers will hear detailed discussions about tools used for web server and web application testing and see some of the information one might be able to get back on a web server while using tools like Vega and WebScarab.
episodes.title: Web Analysis Tools Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.268
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.268 --> 00:00:14.380
Hello and welcome to another episode of
IT Pro TV I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

3
00:00:14.380 --> 00:00:16.060

How you doing, Sean?

5
00:00:17.140 --> 00:00:18.790

6
00:00:18.790 --> 00:00:19.920

7
00:00:19.920 --> 00:00:23.130
Ready for another exciting
episode in our Kali Linux series.

8
00:00:23.130 --> 00:00:26.110
And in this one, it's gonna be
a continuation of a previous episode.

9
00:00:26.110 --> 00:00:29.170
We've been going over some
of these web analysis tools.

10
00:00:29.170 --> 00:00:32.750
So, if you missed those previous episodes,

11

We kind of did a high level overview of
some of the different tools that we can

00:00:36.180 --> 00:00:39.280

web applications.

13
00:00:39.280 --> 00:00:43.138
And before that, we talked about just
the general concepts of what a web server,

14
00:00:43.138 --> 00:00:44.170
web application is.

15
00:00:44.170 --> 00:00:47.180
The client server relationship,
that kind of thing.

16
00:00:47.180 --> 00:00:50.280
And in this episode we're gonna actually
take a look at these kinds of tools and

17
00:00:50.280 --> 00:00:55.070

be able to get back on a web server.

18
00:00:55.070 --> 00:00:57.525
So Sean, where the heck do we start?

19
00:00:57.525 --> 00:01:02.312
>> We've got so many different
places we can start so I figured

20
00:01:02.312 --> 00:01:08.220
we'd start by showing probably a new
tool to a lot of you if not all of you.

21
00:01:08.220 --> 00:01:12.755
Definitely one we haven't seen in any
of the security stuff that we've done.

22
00:01:12.755 --> 00:01:17.170
It's kind of related to the some
of the other tools we have used.

23
00:01:17.170 --> 00:01:19.490
It is one called Vega.

24
00:01:19.490 --> 00:01:24.505
What Vega does for us is Vega is,
it fits in a category what they

25
00:01:24.505 --> 00:01:29.795
call webcrawlers so if you're going under
the menus in there you'll see webcrawlers.

26
00:01:29.795 --> 00:01:32.675
Now it's more than just a webcrawler in
the sense that it's going through and

27
00:01:32.675 --> 00:01:35.765
looking at a website and telling you
what the structure of it looks like.

28
00:01:35.765 --> 00:01:39.585
Yeah, it does that but there's much,
much more that it does.

29
00:01:39.585 --> 00:01:43.925
It actually combines the ability
of something that's crawling,

30
00:01:43.925 --> 00:01:45.540

episodes.description: A vast amount of websites are database driven, so it is important to test web applications, web servers, and the database behind them to prevent attacks like SQL injections. Viewers will hear about what a SQL injection is, what leads to it, and the tools that are available to assess databases and check for SQL injection vulnerabilities.

483
00:31:18.020 --> 00:31:20.580
look at what was discussed with
SQL injections over there and

484
00:31:20.580 --> 00:31:22.390
the examples that were given.

485
00:31:22.390 --> 00:31:25.900
It will give you a good
basic understanding

486
00:31:25.900 --> 00:31:29.350
of what a SQL injection actually is and
what it looks like, so

487
00:31:29.350 --> 00:31:33.490
you can kind of get your head around
that to at least get that level.

488
00:31:33.490 --> 00:31:37.610
Stuff in the CH is the most
basic level you should have,

489
00:31:37.610 --> 00:31:42.105
a little bit more than that actually, but
it's the good foundation you should have.

490
00:31:42.105 --> 00:31:47.580
You want to go beyond that and specialize
in something like SQL or Oracle then hey,

491
00:31:47.580 --> 00:31:52.875
more power to you, but If you want to kind
of get that, and your head around what it

492
00:31:52.875 --> 00:31:57.765
is, what it looks like, then yeah, take
a look at that stuff as soon as you can.

493
00:31:59.355 --> 00:32:02.135
>> All right, ladies and gentlemen,
we hope you enjoyed watching this episode,

494
00:32:02.135 --> 00:32:04.250
we know we enjoyed filming it for you.

495
00:32:04.250 --> 00:32:08.410
Filming it for you, if I can that out,
but signing off from ITProTV,

496
00:32:08.410 --> 00:32:09.510
I'm Mike Rodrick.

497
00:32:09.510 --> 00:32:10.320
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

498
00:32:10.320 --> 00:32:11.699
>> And we'll see you next time.

499
00:32:11.699 --> 00:32:18.010
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: A wireless network uses radio waves to send out information, which can be convenient in a lot of aspects, but lack on the security side of things. Viewers will hear about wireless networks and technologies, some of the tools used to test against wireless networks, and some misconfigurations with the wireless network.
episodes.title: Wireless Networks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.148 --> 00:00:10.148
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.155 --> 00:00:15.291
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.291 --> 00:00:16.800
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.800 --> 00:00:18.260
And with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

5
00:00:18.260 --> 00:00:19.380
How you doing, Sean?

6
00:00:19.380 --> 00:00:20.000
>> I'm doing pretty good.

7
00:00:20.000 --> 00:00:20.670
How are you doing?

8
00:00:20.670 --> 00:00:21.710
>> I'm doing fantastic!

9
00:00:21.710 --> 00:00:25.460
We've got another exciting episode coming
your way on our Kali Linux series.

10
00:00:25.460 --> 00:00:29.150
And in this episode in particular,
we're gonna be focusing in on wireless.

11
00:00:29.150 --> 00:00:32.690
So wireless networks, different
technologies and then as far as some of

12
00:00:32.690 --> 00:00:36.518
the tools that we can use to do tests
against these wireless networks.

13
00:00:36.518 --> 00:00:42.160
Wireless networks Sean, a very common
thing to find in most networks, also

14
00:00:42.160 --> 00:00:47.039
a very common source of vulnerabilities
I guess is a good way to put it.

15
00:00:47.039 --> 00:00:48.522
>> Yes indeed.

16
00:00:48.522 --> 00:00:51.410
[LAUGH] They absolutely are very, very,

17
00:00:51.410 --> 00:00:57.595
very common source of problems
of the security kind.

18
00:00:57.595 --> 00:01:04.210
So, when we think about it we used to
just have the wireless 80211 segment.

19
00:01:04.210 --> 00:01:05.720
Now, what do we have?

20
00:01:05.720 --> 00:01:08.700
We have bluetooth and
then we have RFID and

21
00:01:08.700 --> 00:01:13.390
then we even have other stuff out beyond
that with NFC and stuff like that.

22
00:01:13.390 --> 00:01:16.570
So, it's really wireless
appearing in different forms in so

23
00:01:16.570 --> 00:01:18.370
many different places.

24
00:01:18.370 --> 00:01:21.690
There is a big potential for
security problems.

25
00:01:21.690 --> 00:01:27.850
Security problems have been definitely
been realized in, across the board.

26
00:01:27.850 --> 00:01:31.750
So it's something that Kali
actually comes to bear and

27
00:01:31.750 --> 00:01:34.970
has a bunch of tools that
it can help you assess and

28
00:01:34.970 --> 00:01:39.930
see where you actually stand as
far as issues with wireless.

29
00:01:39.930 --> 00:01:41.378
>> Yeah it just opens up so

30
00:01:41.378 --> 00:01:46.891
many other avenues of attack as you say
because you're wireless, you're unbound.

31
00:01:46.891 --> 00:01:50.850
It's inherently more difficult to
secure because it is an unbound media.

32
00:01:50.850 --> 00:01:54.130
Your data is just floating out there and
anybody within range and

33
00:01:54.130 --> 00:01:58.130
an antenna could potentially
capture that information.

34
00:01:58.130 --> 00:02:01.110
And it's also the technology changes so
fast,

35
00:02:01.110 --> 00:02:04.750
there's problems within
the protocols themselves.

36
00:02:04.750 --> 00:02:10.120
Like, we remember 80211, early on,
80211 had WEP, which we know had issues.

37
00:02:10.120 --> 00:02:13.226
And we're seeing the same things in
some of these other technologies,

38
00:02:13.226 --> 00:02:14.167
bluetooth and RFID.

39
00:02:14.167 --> 00:02:16.760
I think,
because they're being pushed out so fast.

40
00:02:16.760 --> 00:02:18.130
Security's kind of an afterthought.

41
00:02:18.130 --> 00:02:20.890
And it's like, we're gonna get it out,
we're gonna get this cool technology made

42
00:02:20.890 --> 00:02:23.760
up and make it really easy and
convenient to use.

43
00:02:23.760 --> 00:02:25.597
Then figure out how to secure
it after the fact, and

44
00:02:25.597 --> 00:02:27.144
sometimes that's not the best strategy.

45
00:02:27.144 --> 00:02:31.450
So it does leave a lot of vulnerabilities,
as as you've said,

46
00:02:31.450 --> 00:02:35.060
there's tons of tools to
take advantage of those.

47
00:02:35.060 --> 00:02:37.330
>> Yeah,
there's a lot of tools on both sides.

48
00:02:37.330 --> 00:02:39.070
There's a lot of tools
on the defensive side.

49
00:02:39.070 --> 00:02:43.220
There's tools on the offensive side and,

50
00:02:43.220 --> 00:02:47.725
it's things that we have to use to protect
ourselves or see where we actually stand.

51
00:02:47.725 --> 00:02:52.810
And I definitely agree with the statement
you said about, with wireless

52
00:02:52.810 --> 00:02:57.030
being pushed out, I mean, put in so
many places, like, really any technology.

53
00:02:57.030 --> 00:02:59.320
They just keep pushing, and
pushing, and pushing it.

54
00:02:59.320 --> 00:03:02.460
And then after the fact they're like,
oh, now let's secure it.

55
00:03:02.460 --> 00:03:03.820
It's like, yeah,

56
00:03:03.820 --> 00:03:07.570
let's close the barn door after the horses
have eaten your children or whatever.

57
00:03:07.570 --> 00:03:10.200
I don't know how that saying goes,
but whatever.

58
00:03:10.200 --> 00:03:10.700
You'll work it.

59
00:03:12.303 --> 00:03:13.042
Gotcha on that one, didn't I?

60
00:03:13.042 --> 00:03:14.875
[LAUGH] I was like, wait, wait, what?

61
00:03:14.875 --> 00:03:18.244
[LAUGH]
>> Do you use any of the NFCs?

62
00:03:18.244 --> 00:03:21.450
Do you have your smartphone with
your credit card stored on there,

63
00:03:21.450 --> 00:03:25.860
where you can just walk up and touch your
phone to the device and pay for things?

64
00:03:25.860 --> 00:03:27.130
>> I don't use that no way.

65
00:03:27.130 --> 00:03:28.060
>> Yeah.

66
00:03:28.060 --> 00:03:29.385
>> I won't even touch that, so.

67
00:03:29.385 --> 00:03:32.720
>> [LAUGH] I mean that just seems
to me like a horrible thing.

68
00:03:32.720 --> 00:03:37.090
And it's a great concept, it's a great
idea, I'm sure it's very convenient.

69
00:03:37.090 --> 00:03:40.780
But, from a security perspective we've
talked about it in several shows right?

70
00:03:40.780 --> 00:03:41.700
Convenience and

71
00:03:41.700 --> 00:03:46.550
security typically are at opposite
ends of the spectrum, and some making

72
00:03:46.550 --> 00:03:50.180
something really easy to use usually
reduces the security on that thing.

73
00:03:50.180 --> 00:03:52.870
And I think that's a great example, so.

74
00:03:52.870 --> 00:03:54.770
>> Opposite ends of
the spectrum with wireless.

75
00:03:54.770 --> 00:03:55.675
Get it?

76
00:03:55.675 --> 00:04:02.115
>> [LAUGH] So, wireless networks just as
a quick refresher for folks out there.

77
00:04:02.115 --> 00:04:05.804
I know most of you are at this point if
you're watching this class you've gone

78
00:04:05.804 --> 00:04:06.609
through net+.

79
00:04:06.609 --> 00:04:07.818
You've done some of that basic stuff.

80
00:04:07.818 --> 00:04:10.965
You have an understanding of
what a wireless network is.

81
00:04:10.965 --> 00:04:16.515
But let's just do a quick recap, Sean,
about what we mean by a wireless network.

82
00:04:16.515 --> 00:04:19.605
>> Yeah, a wireless network is, really

83
00:04:19.605 --> 00:04:23.295
we could really take the kinda pathetic
answer of it's a network without wires.

84
00:04:23.295 --> 00:04:25.550
Next.
>> Check, done, yeah.

85
00:04:25.550 --> 00:04:29.340
>> This is like the abridged
version of the course.

86
00:04:29.340 --> 00:04:32.490
And well, that is what it is,

87
00:04:32.490 --> 00:04:36.325
but when you look at a wireless network,
it doesn't use wires.

88
00:04:36.325 --> 00:04:43.150
But uses radio waves to carry out that
information to wherever it needs to go.

89
00:04:43.150 --> 00:04:47.140
So that's the first concept we have there.

90
00:04:47.140 --> 00:04:51.630
Now, the thing is,
is that since it uses wireless or

91
00:04:51.630 --> 00:04:55.870
RF to carry those signals out wirelessly,
that's great.

92
00:04:55.870 --> 00:05:02.090
You can be wherever you need to be,
within reason, and get that signal.

93
00:05:02.090 --> 00:05:05.870
The downside of it is, is that you
can be wherever you need to be and

94
00:05:05.870 --> 00:05:07.620
still get that signal.

95
00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:10.048
So it's a plus and a minus there.

96
00:05:10.048 --> 00:05:15.870
So, why the user that's authorized and
legit to use that can get it

97
00:05:15.870 --> 00:05:20.830
from the next room, or on the other side
of the parking lot, so can the attacker.

98
00:05:20.830 --> 00:05:23.740
The attacker can get it from
those exact same places.

99
00:05:23.740 --> 00:05:28.318
And unlike wired networks, where they
physically have to gain access, and

100
00:05:28.318 --> 00:05:31.692
then that brings in all sorts
of ways we can pick that up.

101
00:05:31.692 --> 00:05:32.852
Wireless you can't do that.

102
00:05:32.852 --> 00:05:35.291
Wireless you can't just say well,

103
00:05:35.291 --> 00:05:41.020
there's someone sitting in this area
where they are tapping into the network.

104
00:05:41.020 --> 00:05:43.100
>> It's difficult to do a good,

105
00:05:43.100 --> 00:05:46.480
a lot of people don't do proper
wireless surveys on their network, so.

106
00:05:46.480 --> 00:05:49.180
They don't realize that their signal's
reaching outside of the building,

107
00:05:49.180 --> 00:05:53.700
possibly into the next office or into that
parking lot or something like that where

108
00:05:53.700 --> 00:05:57.110
somebody could sit unmonitored and
attempt to access that network.

109
00:05:57.110 --> 00:06:02.358
So it does, as you said, bring
a whole nother set of issues to bear.

110
00:06:02.358 --> 00:06:04.893
Also with wireless networks again,
quick recap for you,

111
00:06:04.893 --> 00:06:06.970
they can be set up in two
different modes right.

112
00:06:06.970 --> 00:06:11.650
You've got your peer-to-peer type,
or your ad hoc networks

113
00:06:11.650 --> 00:06:15.530
where you've got wireless clients that
are connecting to each other directly.

114
00:06:15.530 --> 00:06:19.266
So each wireless client talks to
another wireless client directly.

115
00:06:19.266 --> 00:06:23.640
They basically form a mesh if there's
more than a couple devices there.

116
00:06:23.640 --> 00:06:27.750
Doesn't give you any access to
the wired portion of the network,

117
00:06:27.750 --> 00:06:29.510
just to all the wireless clients.

118
00:06:29.510 --> 00:06:34.500
So, that's one that's the ad hoc, and
then you've got the access point,

119
00:06:34.500 --> 00:06:35.900
I forget the name we used for that one.

120
00:06:35.900 --> 00:06:36.670
What is that mode?

121
00:06:36.670 --> 00:06:37.260
>> Infrastructure.

122
00:06:37.260 --> 00:06:38.870
>> Infrastructure mode, thank you.

123
00:06:38.870 --> 00:06:40.880
Where you've got an access point and

124
00:06:40.880 --> 00:06:43.730
that access point is tied
into the wired network.

125
00:06:43.730 --> 00:06:46.157
All the wireless clients connect
to that access point, so

126
00:06:46.157 --> 00:06:47.800
it's a central connectivity device.

127
00:06:47.800 --> 00:06:50.875
And even if two wireless clients
wanna talk to each other,

128
00:06:50.875 --> 00:06:55.040
the traffic still flows back to that
access point and out to the other clients.

129
00:06:55.040 --> 00:06:56.090
So two different modes,

130
00:06:56.090 --> 00:06:59.460
something we might have to consider
when we're going our wireless surveys or

131
00:06:59.460 --> 00:07:03.220
doing our pin test against our
network is how they have that set up.

132
00:07:03.220 --> 00:07:06.130
And, another thing that just
popped into my head is,

133
00:07:06.130 --> 00:07:09.460
what if I find an ad hoc network that
maybe shouldn't be allowed, right?

134
00:07:09.460 --> 00:07:11.510
You've got two people
that have set one up.

135
00:07:11.510 --> 00:07:14.620
This is what happens, is you get two,

136
00:07:14.620 --> 00:07:17.460
say, C-level people that want
to share files real quick.

137
00:07:17.460 --> 00:07:18.640
They setup a little ad hoc network.

138
00:07:18.640 --> 00:07:21.170
They have no idea what they're doing,
how to secure it, and

139
00:07:21.170 --> 00:07:23.730
that opens up holes in
our security as well.

140
00:07:23.730 --> 00:07:28.080
>> Yeah,
there's a lot of stuff that happens

141
00:07:28.080 --> 00:07:31.730
with every technology
that can cause problems.

142
00:07:31.730 --> 00:07:33.390
And yeah the peer to peer ones.

143
00:07:33.390 --> 00:07:37.940
Yeah I could definitely see, someone
just said C level And they're C level,

144
00:07:37.940 --> 00:07:41.390
because they're not smart to be an A to
figure out that that's a bad idea.

145
00:07:41.390 --> 00:07:42.430
>> I was just gonna say that.

146
00:07:42.430 --> 00:07:43.130
>> I don't mean anything bad.

147
00:07:43.130 --> 00:07:46.810
>> If you're a C level, I don't mean
anything derogatory by that at all,

148
00:07:46.810 --> 00:07:48.050
but you probably have other,

149
00:07:48.050 --> 00:07:52.080
bigger things to worry about than
how to configure a wireless network.

150
00:07:52.080 --> 00:07:53.220
That's my disclaimer there.

151
00:07:53.220 --> 00:07:55.350
>> No you don't.
I mean that bad.

152
00:07:55.350 --> 00:07:58.970
I can say that because
I'm Captain America.

153
00:07:58.970 --> 00:08:01.670
I can say that.

154
00:08:01.670 --> 00:08:07.348
Yeah, it's the nature of the beast,
is that when they push new technology out,

155
00:08:07.348 --> 00:08:12.959
someone is gonna abuse it, so they can
find these little things like that to do.

156
00:08:12.959 --> 00:08:16.851
And I also think it's worthwhile, when
we're talking about this whole thing with

157
00:08:16.851 --> 00:08:20.762
wireless, make sure that we do bring in
the fact that we have different standards.

158
00:08:20.762 --> 00:08:25.119
The different standards, and you can
feel free to look these up on your own.

159
00:08:25.119 --> 00:08:30.137
But just to do a quick recap,
you have 802.11a,

160
00:08:30.137 --> 00:08:33.627
then you have 802.11b, g, n,

161
00:08:33.627 --> 00:08:38.445
and then we even have,
really just came out, is AC.

162
00:08:38.445 --> 00:08:40.349
And we've got DC coming out next year.

163
00:08:40.349 --> 00:08:45.521
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK]
>> We

164
00:08:45.521 --> 00:08:50.555
have those being the main
standards right now.

165
00:08:50.555 --> 00:08:54.301
AC, you're probably not going
to see a lot of right now,

166
00:08:54.301 --> 00:08:57.580
because if you go look at
the access points for it,

167
00:08:57.580 --> 00:09:01.657
the access points themselves are,
they're kind of pricey.

168
00:09:01.657 --> 00:09:06.187
They're not all, ridiculously, pricey,
but they're more than you're paying for

169
00:09:06.187 --> 00:09:08.308
your access points for the other stuff.

170
00:09:08.308 --> 00:09:11.225
I've seen access points just regular,

171
00:09:11.225 --> 00:09:17.073
supposed to be consumer grade access
points for AC running about 8, $900.

172
00:09:17.073 --> 00:09:18.873
They're cool and they're cool looking,

173
00:09:18.873 --> 00:09:21.627
I mean they've always got this
weird shapes and stuff like a bug.

174
00:09:21.627 --> 00:09:24.040
I'd probably hit it with
a newspaper [INAUDIBLE].

175
00:09:24.040 --> 00:09:28.280
But they have those, but they're gonna
come down in price like anything.

176
00:09:28.280 --> 00:09:32.060
You're probably not going to
see too many of those yet, but

177
00:09:32.060 --> 00:09:35.621
they are kind of making their
way into the marketplace.

178
00:09:35.621 --> 00:09:40.697
And what separates those
standards is mainly speed,

179
00:09:40.697 --> 00:09:44.655
as well as the frequency range it runs in.

180
00:09:44.655 --> 00:09:47.584
If you look at things like a and n,

181
00:09:47.584 --> 00:09:52.723
those ones both have the ability
to run at five gigahertz.

182
00:09:52.723 --> 00:09:55.336
And that tends to be less polluted.

183
00:09:55.336 --> 00:09:58.648
Meaning there's less devices
running in that spectrum.

184
00:09:58.648 --> 00:10:03.023
So, you're probably gonna
get better performance, and

185
00:10:03.023 --> 00:10:07.498
less issues as far as interference and
all that nastiness.

186
00:10:07.498 --> 00:10:12.378
Downside, because of the way that
signal's formatted and modulated,

187
00:10:12.378 --> 00:10:15.818
you get a situation where
it doesn't go that far and

188
00:10:15.818 --> 00:10:20.952
easily gets sported by just basic
construction of buildings or obstacles.

189
00:10:20.952 --> 00:10:22.995
It will stop.

190
00:10:22.995 --> 00:10:29.448
If you have 2.4,
2.4 will go a lot further than a will.

191
00:10:29.448 --> 00:10:34.924
However, there's a lot of things that run
at 2.4 because it's an unlicensed band,

192
00:10:34.924 --> 00:10:39.959
and since it's an unlicensed band, you
have all sorts of things running there.

193
00:10:39.959 --> 00:10:43.794
Everything from your wireless networks,
of course, your cordless phones,

194
00:10:43.794 --> 00:10:47.923
your Bluetooth devices, under the right
conditions a microwave can generate those

195
00:10:47.923 --> 00:10:50.849
types of signals, and
that's just the tip of the iceberg.

196
00:10:50.849 --> 00:10:54.201
We're not even bringing in the stuff,
like your various game controllers and

197
00:10:54.201 --> 00:10:54.979
stuff like that.

198
00:10:54.979 --> 00:10:58.018
So, there's a lot of stuff
that's crunched in and

199
00:10:58.018 --> 00:11:00.788
jammed into that 2.4 gigahertz spectrum.

200
00:11:00.788 --> 00:11:06.459
And so, it's still more popular than
five gigahertz because of the range and

201
00:11:06.459 --> 00:11:11.011
the ability to be compatible with so
many different devices.

202
00:11:11.011 --> 00:11:15.486
So, you're more likely gonna see
that than the five gigahertz.

203
00:11:15.486 --> 00:11:20.127
So, you really should have a good handle
at understanding when you're doing your

204
00:11:20.127 --> 00:11:22.354
attacks and using the tool for a while.

205
00:11:22.354 --> 00:11:26.683
You should really have a good
understanding of what the different

206
00:11:26.683 --> 00:11:31.416
standards mean to you, and that will
allow you to use the tools better.

207
00:11:31.416 --> 00:11:36.622
Because if you don't know the standards
at least at some basic level,

208
00:11:36.622 --> 00:11:38.475
or intermediate level,
