00:24:11.810 --> 00:24:15.010
But looking at our clock,
it's about time for us to take a break.

437
00:24:15.010 --> 00:24:19.190
So, why don't we wrap this one up, and
when we come back with another episode,

438
00:24:19.190 --> 00:24:23.150
maybe we can take a look at some of the
stuff that Kali's going to bring to bear

439
00:24:23.150 --> 00:24:26.790
that will allow us to do our penetration
tests against these wireless networks.

440
00:24:26.790 --> 00:24:27.670
Sound like a plan?

441
00:24:27.670 --> 00:24:28.490
>> Sounds good.

442
00:24:28.490 --> 00:24:30.270
After the break we're going back to Kali.

443
00:24:30.270 --> 00:24:31.520
>> Going back to Kali.

444
00:24:31.520 --> 00:24:32.530
I like it.

445
00:24:32.530 --> 00:24:33.585
Well, ladies and gentlemen.

446
00:24:33.585 --> 00:24:35.755
We hope you enjoyed watching this episode.

447
00:24:35.755 --> 00:24:37.985
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

448
00:24:37.985 --> 00:24:38.985
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

449
00:24:38.985 --> 00:24:40.103
>> And we'll see you next time.

450
00:24:40.103 --> 00:24:46.560
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: With wireless technology pushing more toward convenience rather than safety, the threat of wireless attacks becomes increasingly prevalent. Viewers will hear about wireless attacks, tools one can use to test a wireless network, and some vulnerabilities that can be caused by Bluetooth, RFID, and NFC.
episodes.title: Wireless Attacks and Tools
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.364 --> 00:00:15.340
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:15.340 --> 00:00:17.502
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and
with me today is Mr.

4
00:00:17.502 --> 00:00:19.360
Sean Oriyano, how you doing Sean?

5
00:00:19.360 --> 00:00:20.740
>> I'm going pretty good, how you doing?

6
00:00:20.740 --> 00:00:22.120
>> I'm doing fantastic,

7
00:00:22.120 --> 00:00:25.730
we've got another exciting episode
of IT Pro TV coming your way.

8
00:00:25.730 --> 00:00:29.050
We've got our Kali Linux
series going on right now, and

9
00:00:29.050 --> 00:00:32.180
in this episode Sean we're going
to take another look at wireless.

10
00:00:32.180 --> 00:00:35.830
If you've missed our previous episode,
go back into the library and check it out.

11
00:00:35.830 --> 00:00:39.680
We started talking about wireless networks
in general and some of the different

12
00:00:39.680 --> 00:00:44.530
standards and some of the vulnerabilities
that these wireless networks introduce.

13
00:00:44.530 --> 00:00:48.060
And now Sean, we want to take a look
at some of the tools we can use.

14
00:00:48.060 --> 00:00:52.380
If we're doing a pen test and
the company has a wireless network, what

15
00:00:52.380 --> 00:00:57.220
does Kali bring to us that we can use to
test their network and things like that.

16
00:00:57.220 --> 00:01:00.450
So, Sean,
let's talk about wireless again and

17
00:01:00.450 --> 00:01:02.690
what kind of tools we got
available here in Kali.

18
00:01:02.690 --> 00:01:06.950
>> Yeah, there's, when we look at
wireless, yeah, we talked about just sort

19
00:01:06.950 --> 00:01:10.140
of the different standards that
are out there in our previous segment,

20
00:01:10.140 --> 00:01:12.780
talked about Bluetooth,
we talked about RFID.

21
00:01:12.780 --> 00:01:17.430
And we mentioned a little bit NFC.

22
00:01:17.430 --> 00:01:21.610
But those are the main types of wireless
you're going to see out there, but

23
00:01:21.610 --> 00:01:26.500
then there's, when we look at wireless in
generally, typically we're talking 802.11,

24
00:01:26.500 --> 00:01:29.660
that's what most people associate with it.

25
00:01:29.660 --> 00:01:35.760
Now as far as Kali goes, Kali actually
has a lot of tools that can be used

26
00:01:35.760 --> 00:01:41.940
to assess and break into and
do other stuff to 802.11 networks.

27
00:01:41.940 --> 00:01:45.310
They really really came
prepared in this area.

28
00:01:45.310 --> 00:01:48.190
Something I'm going to
tell you about here makes,

29
00:01:48.190 --> 00:01:50.629
when you're using Kali in here is that.

30
00:01:52.180 --> 00:01:54.140
There are ways to do this.

31
00:01:54.140 --> 00:01:57.150
We haven't bothered doing it here, but

32
00:01:57.150 --> 00:02:02.030
be aware of the fact that if you're
running Kali in a virtualized environment,

33
00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:05.600
if you have a wireless card,
it's not going to pick that wireless card,

34
00:02:05.600 --> 00:02:08.970
typically it's not going pick that
wireless card up as a wireless card.

35
00:02:08.970 --> 00:02:13.040
We both have a wireless card
physically installed in these systems,

36
00:02:13.040 --> 00:02:15.550
like most computers do nowadays.

37
00:02:15.550 --> 00:02:18.970
And why the virtual assistant
will pick it up and

38
00:02:18.970 --> 00:02:22.080
Kali will pick it up because
the virtual system picked it up.

39
00:02:22.080 --> 00:02:24.410
It will be picked up as
a network connection,

40
00:02:24.410 --> 00:02:27.085
not a wireless, just a network connection.

41
00:02:27.085 --> 00:02:29.800
>> Mm-hm.
>> So that means that,

42
00:02:29.800 --> 00:02:34.956
as far as using really any of
these wireless tools, you can't.

43
00:02:34.956 --> 00:02:36.620
Because it's going to query it and
look for

44
00:02:36.620 --> 00:02:41.090
the capabilities of a wireless device and
since it's not showing up as that,

45
00:02:41.090 --> 00:02:46.330
it's going to say no wireless device
is found and it will shut right down.

46
00:02:46.330 --> 00:02:49.490
Doesn't mean we can't discuss and
talk about the different tools do and

47
00:02:49.490 --> 00:02:53.710
show some of the stuff in there, but
we're not going to be, you know,

48
00:02:53.710 --> 00:02:55.290
breaking into any of them.

49
00:02:55.290 --> 00:03:00.820
The other thing I would add into this is
that that means that you've got a choice.

50
00:03:00.820 --> 00:03:05.240
You can, in some cases,
get a USB wireless adapter and

51
00:03:05.240 --> 00:03:09.450
plug it in and do a pass-through on
some of the virtualization platforms.

52
00:03:09.450 --> 00:03:13.280
And if you do that, it will pick up
the wireless adapter you plug in

53
00:03:13.280 --> 00:03:15.289
as wireless in the virtual environment.

54
00:03:16.420 --> 00:03:21.580
Virtual Box will do that, and
VMWare is supposed to be able to do that.

55
00:03:21.580 --> 00:03:23.955
I never really got into
doing it in VMWare,

56
00:03:23.955 --> 00:03:26.530
because I don't really
use it all that often.

57
00:03:26.530 --> 00:03:31.260
So, Virtual Box, I never really
had any great luck with it, but

58
00:03:31.260 --> 00:03:32.600
it's supposed to be possible.

59
00:03:32.600 --> 00:03:34.360
I think you were saying Hyper-V does that?

60
00:03:34.360 --> 00:03:35.580
>> Yeah, Hyper-V seems to work right.

61
00:03:35.580 --> 00:03:40.350
But, then again, now that I think about
it, when I was using it with Hyper-V,

62
00:03:40.350 --> 00:03:42.910
I was just able to get network access and
talk to other machines.

63
00:03:42.910 --> 00:03:47.110
I don't know that Hyper-V represented
it as wireless network adapters,

64
00:03:47.110 --> 00:03:48.870
so it very well could be.

65
00:03:48.870 --> 00:03:54.030
So this might be one of the areas where if
you want to practice with the stuff and

66
00:03:54.030 --> 00:03:58.650
play with Kali Linux and that, this is one
of the areas where having it installed

67
00:03:58.650 --> 00:04:01.860
physically on a machine
might be the best way to go.

68
00:04:01.860 --> 00:04:06.330
Virtualization lets me do a whole lot,
but with the wireless adapters,

69
00:04:06.330 --> 00:04:10.040
the way they work,
it's difficult to get that virtualized,

70
00:04:10.040 --> 00:04:12.040
at least now with what we've got, so.

71
00:04:12.040 --> 00:04:13.840
Something to think about,
if you're setting up sandbox and

72
00:04:13.840 --> 00:04:17.680
you've got an old laptop that you want
a duel boot to or a blow away and

73
00:04:17.680 --> 00:04:18.860
put Kali on there and

74
00:04:18.860 --> 00:04:22.470
it's got a wireless adapter, then you can
take full advantage of all these tools.

75
00:04:22.470 --> 00:04:23.880
And the same thing's going
to go with the other ones.

76
00:04:23.880 --> 00:04:25.350
Right?
I mean like Bluetooth,

77
00:04:25.350 --> 00:04:29.340
I would need some type of Bluetooth
receiver on the machine that's running

78
00:04:29.340 --> 00:04:34.740
Kali, just take advantage of those tools
and the RFID and the NFC type tools.

79
00:04:34.740 --> 00:04:39.450
>> Yeah, Kali, in my case recognizes
that Bluetooth is there and

80
00:04:39.450 --> 00:04:42.840
let's me turn it on and off, but I don't
think it really is turning on and off.

81
00:04:42.840 --> 00:04:46.240
It thinks it is, but I think it's
just turning the service on and off.

82
00:04:46.240 --> 00:04:49.460
It's not actually doing anything
with the physical state

83
00:04:49.460 --> 00:04:52.150
of the adapter on
the actual machine itself.

84
00:04:52.150 --> 00:04:53.180
>> That's good.
Those device,

85
00:04:53.180 --> 00:04:54.590
they're just not virtualized, right?

86
00:04:54.590 --> 00:04:58.650
The hard drive I have in my computer might
support Bluetooth but It's not being

87
00:04:58.650 --> 00:05:04.030
virtualized by my virtualization platform
and exposing it to the virtual machines.

88
00:05:04.030 --> 00:05:09.090
>> Yeah, so definitely keep that in
mind and you know it's not uncommon for

89
00:05:09.090 --> 00:05:14.220
pen testers just to have this installed
on physical hardware anyway that they

90
00:05:14.220 --> 00:05:20.180
do just grab an old notebook or something
and put it on there and go from there.

91
00:05:20.180 --> 00:05:23.990
So, there are some limitations when
you use it in this environment.

92
00:05:23.990 --> 00:05:27.760
This is one of the ones
that is pretty much known,

93
00:05:27.760 --> 00:05:30.700
and there's always little
workarounds that people have,

94
00:05:30.700 --> 00:05:34.430
but they just seem to be
never really all that great.

95
00:05:34.430 --> 00:05:39.290
I spent some time trying
to get the wireless adapter

96
00:05:39.290 --> 00:05:43.090
recognized in the virtual machine and
did it.

97
00:05:43.090 --> 00:05:47.760
I was like,
"oh great!" It was then when I realized

98
00:05:47.760 --> 00:05:51.470
it was only recognizing it as a network
adapter the first time I did it.

99
00:05:51.470 --> 00:05:52.710
That's not helping me.

100
00:05:52.710 --> 00:05:54.770
So I was still stuck.

101
00:05:54.770 --> 00:06:01.300
But, if any of you guys find a way,
go ahead and and go for it.

102
00:06:01.300 --> 00:06:05.300
Hey, share it with the rest [LAUGH] of
us too, if you get it to work reliably.

103
00:06:05.300 --> 00:06:09.920
But with that being said,
we're going to talk about

104
00:06:09.920 --> 00:06:14.630
the tools that are here for
you to do your wireless audits.

105
00:06:14.630 --> 00:06:21.070
And there's just so many of them and
we'll take a look at a handful of these.

106
00:06:21.070 --> 00:06:26.532
So, what I'm going to do is I have Kali
sitting right up here on my screen again.

107
00:06:26.532 --> 00:06:31.250
And I'm under the wireless
attacks section of that menu.

108
00:06:31.250 --> 00:06:36.250
And you can see that we have our own
menu dedicated to, specifically,

109
00:06:36.250 --> 00:06:38.990
to wireless attacks itself.

110
00:06:38.990 --> 00:06:40.500
So if we take a look, and

111
00:06:40.500 --> 00:06:45.100
I'll just scroll right on down here,
To give you the whole look at it.

112
00:06:45.100 --> 00:06:46.200
So you can see, yeah,

113
00:06:46.200 --> 00:06:49.210
it definitely does have a lot
of things it comes to play with.

114
00:06:49.210 --> 00:06:52.210
And while we won't spend
time on all of these,

115
00:06:52.210 --> 00:06:58.210
you can see that there are a heck of a lot
of them there for you to do stuff with.

116
00:06:58.210 --> 00:07:01.540
It looks like some of those then
are designed to, like Aircrack,

117
00:07:01.540 --> 00:07:07.660
I recognized as a tool I can use to crack
passwords on, wireless access points.

118
00:07:07.660 --> 00:07:08.970
>> Exactly.
>> Other ones in there look

119
00:07:08.970 --> 00:07:12.360
like they might be more geared
towards just capturing data or

120
00:07:12.360 --> 00:07:13.790
finding wireless access points.

121
00:07:13.790 --> 00:07:16.110
So it looks like we got a whole
range of tools available.

122
00:07:16.110 --> 00:07:17.270
>> Yeah.
You really do.

123
00:07:17.270 --> 00:07:21.200
You really have a broad
range of tools in here.

124
00:07:21.200 --> 00:07:24.750
The Aircrack one, that's one that
was even mentioned in the CEH.

125
00:07:24.750 --> 00:07:30.824
That one is a command line tool that's
specifically designed to go through and

126
00:07:30.824 --> 00:07:35.520
analyze traffic and go over and
retrieve the keys out of it.

127
00:07:35.520 --> 00:07:38.700
By the way,
the whole Aircrack NG suite is there.

128
00:07:38.700 --> 00:07:43.420
If you recall from the CEH,
they call the whole thing Aircrack NG and

129
00:07:43.420 --> 00:07:45.030
there's a bunch of stuff within it.

130
00:07:45.030 --> 00:07:47.340
Well this is just one component of it.

131
00:07:47.340 --> 00:07:48.471
The whole thing is there.

132
00:07:48.471 --> 00:07:52.083
So that's just kind of one
you can use to retrieve,

133
00:07:52.083 --> 00:07:57.291
especially you see WEP keys down there,
it's got a section right there,

134
00:07:57.291 --> 00:08:00.402
right in the bottom of
the The screen there.

135
00:08:00.402 --> 00:08:01.517
I will just move it up.

136
00:08:01.517 --> 00:08:06.660
This is just showing you stuff that
you can do to retrieve web keys.

137
00:08:06.660 --> 00:08:08.745
So that's kind of a really good thing.

138
00:08:08.745 --> 00:08:11.790
There's WPA stuff you can do.

139
00:08:11.790 --> 00:08:16.680
And so, it's got stuff in here
that can definitely help you out.

140
00:08:16.680 --> 00:08:18.750
So that's Aircrack.

141
00:08:18.750 --> 00:08:23.550
That's one that is still very popular
because it does work very well.

142
00:08:23.550 --> 00:08:27.236
In fact, a lot of those tests
where you see people break and

143
00:08:27.236 --> 00:08:30.997
retrieve web keys, and
maybe 10 to 15 to 30 seconds,

144
00:08:30.997 --> 00:08:35.910
this is what they're using to do it to
actually retrieve that out of the data.

145
00:08:35.910 --> 00:08:38.981
But, again, they're not
the only ones that can do this,

146
00:08:38.981 --> 00:08:43.780
there are other tools that can do
the same thing, retrieve keys, for you.

147
00:08:43.780 --> 00:08:50.060
So if I go to my applications again,
as we pick through it.

148
00:08:50.060 --> 00:08:53.550
So there's my 80211 stuff again.

149
00:08:53.550 --> 00:08:57.835
Other ones we have in there, I like
some of these names, bully and cowpatty.

150
00:08:57.835 --> 00:09:00.797
>> [LAUGH]
>> You've got to love anything called

151
00:09:00.797 --> 00:09:02.390
cowpatty when you click on it.

152
00:09:02.390 --> 00:09:04.300
Hey look it's cowpatty!

153
00:09:04.300 --> 00:09:08.660
So look out for cow patties.

154
00:09:08.660 --> 00:09:14.065
So this is what you can use
to actually go through again,

155
00:09:14.065 --> 00:09:17.750
and retrieve stuff out of a PCAT file.

156
00:09:17.750 --> 00:09:20.120
I wonder if they made a second
version's called meadow muffins?

157
00:09:20.120 --> 00:09:22.960
>> [LAUGH].

158
00:09:22.960 --> 00:09:24.170
>> I've got way too much time on my hands.

159
00:09:24.170 --> 00:09:27.543
We figured out during the break that
I'm eating too much sugar back here, so

160
00:09:27.543 --> 00:09:28.500
I'm getting hyper.

161
00:09:28.500 --> 00:09:32.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we've got that, but

162
00:09:32.540 --> 00:09:36.210
let me point out some of
these other ones we got.

163
00:09:36.210 --> 00:09:40.130
This is one that they're starting
to give more attention to,

164
00:09:40.130 --> 00:09:42.350
is this Fern Wifi Cracker.

165
00:09:42.350 --> 00:09:46.840
It is a GUI based tool.

166
00:09:46.840 --> 00:09:48.600
I'm not gonna worry about updating it.

167
00:09:48.600 --> 00:09:53.130
But what this one can do is, it's not
finding a wireless adaptor on this system.

168
00:09:53.130 --> 00:09:55.270
But we already been down that road.

169
00:09:55.270 --> 00:09:58.210
If we did have a wireless adaptor
on the system what would happen

170
00:09:58.210 --> 00:10:00.730
is we would just select it off the list.

171
00:10:00.730 --> 00:10:04.810
And we could go through and
tell it to start scanning for

172
00:10:04.810 --> 00:10:09.440
wireless access points, and it would scan,
and return a list back to us, and

173
00:10:09.440 --> 00:10:13.880
then once we're done we could actually
use this program to target it, and

174
00:10:13.880 --> 00:10:16.720
help collect traffic and crack the key.

175
00:10:18.010 --> 00:10:22.138
This one is actually,
when it's working at its optimal,

176
00:10:22.138 --> 00:10:26.110
it will retrieve keys pretty quickly,
and break them.

177
00:10:26.110 --> 00:10:28.680
So it will treat the traffic and
break those keys very, very quickly.

178
00:10:28.680 --> 00:10:32.400
So very, very neat utility to have.

179
00:10:32.400 --> 00:10:37.890
It may not be as fast and robust as
using something like Aircrack is,

180
00:10:37.890 --> 00:10:40.330
but it has gained some popularity.

181
00:10:40.330 --> 00:10:44.590
If you don't want to learn a command line,
you just don't feel comfortable with it,

182
00:10:44.590 --> 00:10:45.660
this could be an alternative.

183
00:10:45.660 --> 00:10:49.490
But do remember there are some
limitations with that.

184
00:10:49.490 --> 00:10:55.740
So that is just the Fern Wifi deal or
utility.

185
00:10:55.740 --> 00:11:02.820
And then just browsing through this, just
a couple other things to throw out here.

186
00:11:02.820 --> 00:11:05.090
Kismet, I won't worry about
starting that one up.

187
00:11:05.090 --> 00:11:11.350
Kismet is a utility used to
detect wireless access points.

188
00:11:11.350 --> 00:11:16.080
But what really sets this on apart
is that it has the ability to pick

189
00:11:16.080 --> 00:11:20.540
them up even if someone has cloaked them,
turned off the broadcast SSID.

190
00:11:20.540 --> 00:11:24.555
It can still pick that up by just
sitting there and listening for

191
00:11:24.555 --> 00:11:26.080
traffic as it flows by.

192
00:11:26.080 --> 00:11:29.172
You can sit there and read the frames
that are floating through the air and

193
00:11:29.172 --> 00:11:31.070
figure out where they're going.

194
00:11:31.070 --> 00:11:33.980
And tell you, hey,
there's an access point there.

195
00:11:33.980 --> 00:11:35.770
That's not why you can't see it.

196
00:11:35.770 --> 00:11:39.540
I can see stuff going to it,
so I know it's there.

197
00:11:39.540 --> 00:11:40.815
It has the ability to do that,

198
00:11:40.815 --> 00:11:43.780
also has the ability to do
something else that's really cool.

199
00:11:43.780 --> 00:11:46.200
It can also read probe requests.

200
00:11:46.200 --> 00:11:50.025
So when your system is sitting there and
has Kismet running,

201
00:11:50.025 --> 00:11:54.450
if I had running on this system
right now I would be any wireless

202
00:11:54.450 --> 00:11:59.175
device within range of this notebook
when it, it would start popping up and

203
00:11:59.175 --> 00:12:03.840
saying, as it starts to that probe
request, is the wireless card was on.

204
00:12:03.840 --> 00:12:08.004
We start sending out probe requests, this
guy would pick up the probe request and

205
00:12:08.004 --> 00:12:10.060
say, yep, there you go.

206
00:12:10.060 --> 00:12:12.920
And you could usually tell
it's a client pretty quickly,

207
00:12:12.920 --> 00:12:16.590
because of if you don't look at any
other stuff, you can see that it starts,

208
00:12:16.590 --> 00:12:19.480
as it keeps going through

So that's unfortunate, but hey, that's
just another reason to convince the spouse

435
00:25:12.636 --> 00:25:14.830
that you've gotta buy another machine and

436
00:25:14.830 --> 00:25:17.410
you've gotta install Kali on it and
all that good stuff.

437
00:25:17.410 --> 00:25:18.010
Right?

438
00:25:18.010 --> 00:25:20.438
>> Of course, if you're a real hacker,
you don't pay for it anyway.

439
00:25:20.438 --> 00:25:21.975
>> Yeah, exactly.

440
00:25:21.975 --> 00:25:24.780
[LAUGH] Hacker, thief, I don't know.

441
00:25:24.780 --> 00:25:26.490
>> But, you know, it's a fine line.

442
00:25:26.490 --> 00:25:28.410
>> It is. [LAUGH] >> I'm testing
to see if you're paying attention.

443
00:25:28.410 --> 00:25:31.650
If you don't, it's mine now.

444
00:25:31.650 --> 00:25:36.760
And by the way, do remember when you're,
if you do need to purchase a piece

445
00:25:36.760 --> 00:25:42.510
of hardware to run Kali on,
you don't need to go out there and

446
00:25:42.510 --> 00:25:48.420
buy one of these really top-of-the-line
notebooks or whatever to do that.

447
00:25:48.420 --> 00:25:53.120
You could actually buy a fairly
mid-range or even low-range one.

448
00:25:53.120 --> 00:25:54.690
That will work perfectly fine.

449
00:25:54.690 --> 00:25:58.850
This thing does not
consume tons of resources.

450
00:25:58.850 --> 00:26:02.020
So, you can run it on very little.

451
00:26:02.020 --> 00:26:07.250
I also believe just, FYI, I'm looking

452
00:26:07.250 --> 00:26:12.340
on the Kali website I believe they also

453
00:26:12.340 --> 00:26:17.205
have a version that works
on was it tablets now?

454
00:26:17.205 --> 00:26:20.380
>> Mm-hm, on their Arm stuff?

455
00:26:20.380 --> 00:26:23.460
>> Yeah, it's, no that's for
Raspberry Pie.

456
00:26:23.460 --> 00:26:24.350
They've got [CROSSTALK]
>> Oh, okay.

457
00:26:24.350 --> 00:26:29.770
>> This one the NetHunter
runs on Nexus devices.

458
00:26:29.770 --> 00:26:32.570
So you've got even other options.

459
00:26:32.570 --> 00:26:36.340
And I will tell you to look at that,
a 10, a 7, and a 5.

460
00:26:36.340 --> 00:26:39.880
>> And you know your phone has wireless
and bluetooth and near field and

461
00:26:39.880 --> 00:26:41.230
all that good stuff.

462
00:26:41.230 --> 00:26:46.810
>> And you can get the Nexus 5,
that's a generation old, I believe.

463
00:26:46.810 --> 00:26:48.180
Or maybe it is current generation.

464
00:26:48.180 --> 00:26:49.060
I don't know.

465
00:26:49.060 --> 00:26:53.630
But you can get those things off eBay for
a couple hundred bucks and

466
00:26:53.630 --> 00:26:56.250
just go ahead and do your thing with it.

467
00:26:56.250 --> 00:26:57.690
And same thing with a Nexus 7.

468
00:26:57.690 --> 00:27:01.630
You can get those things for
pretty cheap and Kali Linux is free.

469
00:27:01.630 --> 00:27:05.480
The thing I would remember with any
of these devices, as opposed to using

470
00:27:05.480 --> 00:27:11.630
a notebook like we've been using here is,
carrying around a tablet,

471
00:27:11.630 --> 00:27:17.900
or on the other side a mobile phone,
that's not conspicuous nowadays.

472
00:27:17.900 --> 00:27:22.270
If someone's sitting in the corner
going tap tap tap on their phone,

473
00:27:22.270 --> 00:27:27.030
they think you're either browsing
the Internet or checking text messages.

474
00:27:27.030 --> 00:27:29.230
Meanwhile you're just
sweeping their network and

475
00:27:29.230 --> 00:27:31.450
doing a bunch of nastiness with it.

476
00:27:31.450 --> 00:27:35.191
So, these things can be
very easily concealed, so

477
00:27:35.191 --> 00:27:40.681
that's an extra advantage if you're
going to be doing this sort of thing.

478
00:27:40.681 --> 00:27:41.366
>> Nice!

479
00:27:41.366 --> 00:27:44.180
All right, well I'm on my way to
eBay to find my Nexus right now.

480
00:27:45.680 --> 00:27:49.130
Ladies and gentlemen, that is going
to do it for this particular episode!

481
00:27:49.130 --> 00:27:50.970
We hope you enjoyed watching.

482
00:27:50.970 --> 00:27:53.240
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

483
00:27:53.240 --> 00:27:54.280
>> And I'm Shawn Oriyano.

484
00:27:54.280 --> 00:27:55.964
>> And we'll see you next time.

485
00:27:55.964 --> 00:28:01.730
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Honeypots, firewalls, and Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) are all security mechanisms that protect information on a network that penetration testers will need to be aware of, be able to detect them, and even evade them. Viewers will hear discussions about what honeypots, firewalls, and Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) are, what they do, and some tools used to help detect them.
episodes.title: Honeypots, IDSs and Firewalls
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.054 --> 00:00:14.561
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:14.561 --> 00:00:18.070
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and
with today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:18.070 --> 00:00:19.080
How you doing, Sean?

5
00:00:19.080 --> 00:00:20.020
>> I'm doing pretty good.

6
00:00:20.020 --> 00:00:20.700
How you doing?

7
00:00:20.700 --> 00:00:22.360
>> It's a great day to be here.

8
00:00:22.360 --> 00:00:25.050
We got our Kali Linux
series continuing on.

9
00:00:25.050 --> 00:00:30.420
And in this episode, Sean, we're going to
talk about IDSs, firewalls and honeypots.

10
00:00:30.420 --> 00:00:33.370
A whole slew of things
we need to talk about.

11
00:00:33.370 --> 00:00:34.720
So where do we start?

12
00:00:34.720 --> 00:00:38.740
I guess the first thing we need to talk
about is, what the heck is a IDS and

13
00:00:38.740 --> 00:00:39.460
a firewall and a honeypot?

14
00:00:39.460 --> 00:00:42.060
And I know a lot of our viewers out
there at this level already have

15
00:00:42.060 --> 00:00:43.170
a good idea of it.

16
00:00:43.170 --> 00:00:47.150
I'm gonna give you just a quick
recap of what we're talking about

17
00:00:47.150 --> 00:00:50.510
when we talk about firewalls,
and honeypots, and IDSs.

18
00:00:50.510 --> 00:00:54.900
>> Yeah, it's always a good thing to do
a little quick review when you're talking

19
00:00:54.900 --> 00:00:59.740
about stuff like this because it
can help you get an idea of how to

20
00:00:59.740 --> 00:01:03.550
potentially evade these
guys if they are present.

21
00:01:03.550 --> 00:01:05.100
Well, what they are,

22
00:01:05.100 --> 00:01:08.230
just kinda look at it,
we have IDS as firewalls and honeypots.

23
00:01:08.230 --> 00:01:12.685
And when we look at things like
a firewall, a firewall is a hardware,

24
00:01:12.685 --> 00:01:17.975
software device that acts as
a border between your world and

25
00:01:17.975 --> 00:01:22.255
the outside world or
a couple different zones that

26
00:01:22.255 --> 00:01:26.165
aren't trusted the same way as
they would on the other side.

27
00:01:26.165 --> 00:01:29.585
That's a firewall's gonna fulfill that
purpose where it's going say okay,

28
00:01:29.585 --> 00:01:32.445
these aren't trusted the same, well I'm
going to put a line right here in the sand

29
00:01:32.445 --> 00:01:36.300
to make sure stuff just can't walk
from here to over here and vice versa.

30
00:01:36.300 --> 00:01:37.020
That's what they do.

31
00:01:37.020 --> 00:01:40.810
And of course there's many
different generations of firewalls.

32
00:01:40.810 --> 00:01:44.750
We don't really need to worry
about that here too much, but

33
00:01:44.750 --> 00:01:46.000
there are different generations.

34
00:01:46.000 --> 00:01:50.810
Those different generations could
require different forms of testing.

35
00:01:50.810 --> 00:01:53.210
So, there is that.

36
00:01:53.210 --> 00:01:55.700
But then we also have
some of our other things.

37
00:01:55.700 --> 00:02:00.800
We have IDSs, and
really IPSs fit in that same category.

38
00:02:00.800 --> 00:02:05.500
IDSes are a detection mechanism and they
are something that works at the host or

39
00:02:05.500 --> 00:02:09.780
the network level, and they will
pick up anything that deviates or

40
00:02:09.780 --> 00:02:11.690
just doesn't look like it should be there.

41
00:02:11.690 --> 00:02:14.740
And it's going to happen with stuff
flowing across the network or

42
00:02:14.740 --> 00:02:18.110
it's going to be something that's
done on a local system and say hey,

43
00:02:18.110 --> 00:02:21.135
that's not supposed to be happening,
or someone's misusing something there.

44
00:02:21.135 --> 00:02:23.760
>> Mm-hm.
>> It's gonna send up the red flag and

45
00:02:23.760 --> 00:02:27.880
you will go ahead, hopefully,
and at least examine it or

46
00:02:27.880 --> 00:02:30.630
take some sort of action if necessary.

47
00:02:30.630 --> 00:02:34.150
Where an IPS will actually
take action on its own.

48
00:02:34.150 --> 00:02:37.430
Once it attacks it will alert you, but
then it will also take that action.

49
00:02:37.430 --> 00:02:40.910
And the last one of that trio,
the honeypots.

50
00:02:40.910 --> 00:02:44.750
A honeypot is a decoy mechanism.

51
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:47.500
It's used specifically to
attract traffic to it or

52
00:02:47.500 --> 00:02:53.000
an attacker to it with the intention
that we attract them there.

53
00:02:53.000 --> 00:02:57.360
Once we attract them there, they spend
their time and spin their wheels trying to

54
00:02:57.360 --> 00:03:01.980
get someplace where they're not gonna get
any place and we can pick that up and

55
00:03:01.980 --> 00:03:07.260
use that as time to move more
valuable resources out of the way.

56
00:03:07.260 --> 00:03:10.030
Or perhaps track them back
to wherever they came from.

57
00:03:10.030 --> 00:03:14.440
Or even use them to get evidence that they
were up to no good and prosecute them.

58
00:03:14.440 --> 00:03:15.457
That can happen as well.

59
00:03:15.457 --> 00:03:16.515
>> Nice, nice.

60
00:03:16.515 --> 00:03:19.830
So as a penetration tester I have
to be aware of these things,

61
00:03:19.830 --> 00:03:22.625
because I've got to know
one that they're there,

62
00:03:22.625 --> 00:03:26.655
be able to detect that they're there and
then possibly try to evade them so

63
00:03:26.655 --> 00:03:30.180
I can continue my test on and
go past these guys.

64
00:03:30.180 --> 00:03:32.510
So, firewalls.

65
00:03:32.510 --> 00:03:35.650
How do we even go around
getting around a firewall?

66
00:03:35.650 --> 00:03:37.350
If a firewall is blocking ports,

67
00:03:37.350 --> 00:03:41.090
is there anything I can do
to work my way around that?

68
00:03:41.090 --> 00:03:43.790
>> Yeah,
there's a couple things you can do to

69
00:03:43.790 --> 00:03:47.580
really kind of get an idea
of what you're dealing with.

70
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:50.220
One of them is a technique that

71
00:03:50.220 --> 00:03:54.950
we didn't directly address it here in
this course but it was in the CEH and

72
00:03:54.950 --> 00:03:58.390
we'll mention it here since we're
talking about firewalls again.

73
00:03:58.390 --> 00:04:02.610
You can use really any
type of packet crafter or

74
00:04:02.610 --> 00:04:08.180
you could use just plain old NMAP or
a port scanner to fire off a single

75
00:04:08.180 --> 00:04:13.490
packet towards the firewall and
with an app response on it.

76
00:04:13.490 --> 00:04:18.730
And depending on whether or not with
that app we get a reset response back or

77
00:04:18.730 --> 00:04:23.210
not tells us whether or not there's
a firewall in place filtering in anyway.

78
00:04:23.210 --> 00:04:26.882
And that will tell you the presence
of a stateful firewall, whether or

79
00:04:26.882 --> 00:04:29.381
not there's a response
coming back from that.

80
00:04:29.381 --> 00:04:33.340
So that's one thing you can do,

81
00:04:33.340 --> 00:04:37.610
to send that one ping over to that.

82
00:04:37.610 --> 00:04:39.500
Sounds like Red October, one ping only!

83
00:04:39.500 --> 00:04:41.690
I wish I could do Sean Connery's
access right now!

84
00:04:41.690 --> 00:04:44.350
Just one ping only, lad.

85
00:04:44.350 --> 00:04:45.880
Okay, you could do that.

86
00:04:45.880 --> 00:04:47.810
Now, the other one you could do and so

87
00:04:47.810 --> 00:04:50.150
you really kind of flush out
what's going with the firewall.

88
00:04:50.150 --> 00:04:54.130
There is a tool in Kaley called firewalk,
and it is a script.

89
00:04:54.130 --> 00:04:56.980
And what you will do with that
is you do some configuration and

90
00:04:56.980 --> 00:05:01.700
tell it where the firewall is, and
tell it how aggressive you want it to be,

91
00:05:01.700 --> 00:05:03.210
and a couple other things.

92
00:05:03.210 --> 00:05:06.450
And what it will do is it will
send a series of scans and

93
00:05:06.450 --> 00:05:11.970
packets at that firewall and
watch to see what the responses are and

94
00:05:11.970 --> 00:05:16.800
what it gets back and how things react
overall and say, yeah, I know there's

95
00:05:16.800 --> 00:05:20.850
a firewall there already cuz I knew
that coming into the whole thing.

96
00:05:20.850 --> 00:05:26.770
Now firewalking actually reverse
engineered its whole rule set and

97
00:05:26.770 --> 00:05:29.900
said yeah,
here's how that thing's configured.

98
00:05:29.900 --> 00:05:31.740
I can see it right now.

99
00:05:31.740 --> 00:05:33.900
So another really great tool in there.

100
00:05:33.900 --> 00:05:36.860
>> Trying to determine what
ports are being allowed, or

101
00:05:36.860 --> 00:05:38.300
allowing traffic to go through?

102
00:05:38.300 --> 00:05:39.750
That kind of thing?
>> Exactly.

103
00:05:39.750 --> 00:05:46.056
By firing specially crafted packets and
doing Systematic sweeps of that firewall,

104
00:05:46.056 --> 00:05:50.315
it can tell by what it gets back and
what it doesn't.

105
00:05:50.315 --> 00:05:54.864
It can start building the rule set based
on that and say, okay this is what

106
00:05:54.864 --> 00:05:59.711
the rule set looks like and now once you
have that rule set you can say yeah I know

107
00:05:59.711 --> 00:06:04.889
precisely how to strike at that firewall,
so it has little chance of stopping me.

108
00:06:04.889 --> 00:06:05.913
>> Yeah, that's right.

109
00:06:05.913 --> 00:06:09.709
And then when it comes to firewalls,
we can use tools like firewalking, and

110
00:06:09.709 --> 00:06:11.990
that's the other thing Kali Linux, right?

111
00:06:11.990 --> 00:06:13.390
Firewalk or firewalking?

112
00:06:13.390 --> 00:06:17.060
>> Yes, we do have that built right in and
ready to go.

113
00:06:17.060 --> 00:06:21.741
You just have to give it the address to
the firewall and some other things, and

114
00:06:21.741 --> 00:06:25.428
fine tune it, and it will give
you what you need to have done.

115
00:06:25.428 --> 00:06:28.278
>> Nice, nice.

116
00:06:28.278 --> 00:06:31.410
So we also got to worry about
intrusion detection systems and

117
00:06:31.410 --> 00:06:33.380
intrusion prevention systems.

118
00:06:33.380 --> 00:06:37.790
And they can be host based or
they can be network based.

119
00:06:37.790 --> 00:06:40.330
Do you give us any special
tools to deal with those?

120
00:06:40.330 --> 00:06:43.680
>> Yeah we do have a special
series of tools that deals with

121
00:06:43.680 --> 00:06:46.840
that which I have just
brought up the menu for.

122
00:06:46.840 --> 00:06:50.350
These IDS and IPS deals, what they have,

123
00:06:50.350 --> 00:06:53.460
is you can see they have
ways of fragmenting traffic.

124
00:06:53.460 --> 00:06:56.880
As well as a couple other tools that

125
00:06:56.880 --> 00:07:02.120
can do testing against an IDS-IPS
to see what the reaction is.

126
00:07:02.120 --> 00:07:06.449
And in the fragmenty ones are fairly
straight forward, but they have ones like

127
00:07:06.449 --> 00:07:10.842
this one, like F test that actually sends
you know, different forms of packets

128
00:07:10.842 --> 00:07:14.597
against it and with different flags
set on it to see how it responds.

129
00:07:14.597 --> 00:07:18.915
So we've got you know that one and then,

130
00:07:18.915 --> 00:07:24.122
just to go through some of
the other ones we have,

131
00:07:24.122 --> 00:07:29.340
or at least to mention
them within this segment.

132
00:07:29.340 --> 00:07:33.180
We have the load balancing one,
to kind of give you an idea.

133
00:07:33.180 --> 00:07:33.796
>> Load balance detector.

134
00:07:33.796 --> 00:07:36.880
>> Yeah.
To see what the environment looks like.

135
00:07:36.880 --> 00:07:42.405
Then, werewolf I kind of like that.

136
00:07:42.405 --> 00:07:47.958
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, all right what this is,

137
00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.751
is this one you can see
web application firewall,

138
00:07:51.751 --> 00:07:54.590
well that's our [INAUDIBLE] sorry.

139
00:07:54.590 --> 00:07:55.830
Still sounds cool.

140
00:07:55.830 --> 00:07:57.355
I'm going with mine.

141
00:07:57.355 --> 00:07:59.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm not wearing my glasses.

142
00:07:59.560 --> 00:08:00.800
It's Friday.

143
00:08:00.800 --> 00:08:02.684
I don't care.

144
00:08:02.684 --> 00:08:04.878
Guys [INAUDIBLE] coming here for
a three day weekend.

145
00:08:04.878 --> 00:08:08.279
What's wrong with you?

146
00:08:08.279 --> 00:08:10.253
All this talk about freedom and
I'm working.

147
00:08:10.253 --> 00:08:10.810
>> All right.

148
00:08:10.810 --> 00:08:11.947
>> All right.

149
00:08:11.947 --> 00:08:12.865
>> We got to pay for our freedom.

150
00:08:12.865 --> 00:08:17.530
>> [LAUGH] All right.

151
00:08:17.530 --> 00:08:21.890
What this does is this
will literally also do

152
00:08:21.890 --> 00:08:26.340
special checks against these web
application firewalls to see

153
00:08:27.530 --> 00:08:30.150
what specifically that
configuration looks like too.

154
00:08:30.150 --> 00:08:34.560
So it's got a lot of stuff
to really kind of figure

155
00:08:34.560 --> 00:08:38.660
out what's going on and
report that information back to you.

156
00:08:39.880 --> 00:08:42.750
You kinda gotta like this kind of stuff,
cause it tells you

157
00:08:42.750 --> 00:08:45.690
what you're dealing with, and
they're pretty stealthy about it.

158
00:08:45.690 --> 00:08:48.310
The only reason they wouldn't be
stealthy is if you decide to really be

159
00:08:48.310 --> 00:08:51.920
aggressive and turn all the options on and
did all that crazy stuff.

160
00:08:51.920 --> 00:08:58.222
Then it's gonna know specifically,
what you're trying to do.

161
00:08:58.222 --> 00:09:00.730
>> All right and then the other one
that we were going to talk about is

162
00:09:00.730 --> 00:09:02.670
the honeypots.

163
00:09:02.670 --> 00:09:07.370
Again, a honeypot, we talked about is
a system that is set up that's a couple

164
00:09:07.370 --> 00:09:08.810
of different ways they can do it.

165
00:09:08.810 --> 00:09:11.400
But they set it up
intentionally vulnerable or

166
00:09:11.400 --> 00:09:15.280
with some obvious vulnerabilities and
hopefully the attacker attacks

167
00:09:15.280 --> 00:09:20.350
that instead of a system that has
actual confidential information on it.

168
00:09:20.350 --> 00:09:24.040
We can detect that and maybe stop them or
track what they're doing,

169
00:09:24.040 --> 00:09:27.300
trying to learn more about
their attack method.

170
00:09:27.300 --> 00:09:30.530
What does Kali bring to us for
working with honeypots?

171
00:09:30.530 --> 00:09:33.430
Give us the ability to setup honeypots or

172
00:09:33.430 --> 00:09:36.680
more about trying to determine
we're dealing with a honeypot.

173
00:09:36.680 --> 00:09:39.750
Because probably one of the things we
wanna do as a pen tester is the same

174
00:09:39.750 --> 00:09:40.250
thing as the bad guy.

175
00:09:40.250 --> 00:09:43.620
I don't wanna waste all my time trying
to work on this honeypot, right?

176
00:09:43.620 --> 00:09:47.760
>> Yeah, and that's the thing with
honeypots as far as Kali's concerned,

177
00:09:47.760 --> 00:09:54.060
you really have the tools
already to detect honeypots.

178
00:09:54.060 --> 00:09:57.850
You just haven't really
employed them as that yet.

179
00:09:57.850 --> 00:10:02.410
To detect a honeypot, the most
common methods you would have are,

180
00:10:03.780 --> 00:10:09.390
doing targeted scans, using something
like N Map, to use things like

181
00:10:09.390 --> 00:10:14.180
H Ping 3, which is a packet crafter to
fire specially designed packets at,

182
00:10:14.180 --> 00:10:16.630
to see how those are responded to.

183
00:10:16.630 --> 00:10:21.400
With the goal that once you do these
things, you can start reading the results,

184
00:10:21.400 --> 00:10:26.330
maybe do banner grabs against open ports,
and start seeing what's being returned.

185
00:10:26.330 --> 00:10:29.300
And hopefully if you're
experienced enough and

186
00:10:29.300 --> 00:10:33.880
maybe if you're just lucky enough to
hit pay dirt, you will see that, yeah,

187
00:10:33.880 --> 00:10:37.770
it's identifying itself outright as
a honeypot if you look in the right spot.

188
00:10:37.770 --> 00:10:41.060
Or it might be that there
is just not enough there.

189
00:10:41.060 --> 00:10:44.700
Sometimes you will poke around and you
will find out that there's the look and

190
00:10:44.700 --> 00:10:46.800
feel of a real system there, but

191
00:10:46.800 --> 00:10:49.800
once you start digging behind it,
nothing really exists.

192
00:10:49.800 --> 00:10:52.790
You can have something that
looks like a mail server and

193
00:10:52.790 --> 00:10:56.020
you start digging into those services and
trying to enumerate things,

194
00:10:56.020 --> 00:10:59.470
and you find out that it's not
returning any users, at all.

195
00:10:59.470 --> 00:11:00.650
There's no mailboxes there.

196
00:11:00.650 --> 00:11:03.750
Cuz you're doing your whole thing where
you're crawling through an open SMTP

197
00:11:03.750 --> 00:11:05.770
relay, and you're doing all your stuff and

198
00:11:05.770 --> 00:11:10.460
you find out there's either no users or
there's a very small number.

199
00:11:10.460 --> 00:11:12.760
Maybe there's 5, 6 users on there.

200
00:11:12.760 --> 00:11:15.790
Makes sense that someone set up
an enterprise mail system for five or

201
00:11:15.790 --> 00:11:16.640
six users.

202
00:11:16.640 --> 00:11:18.720
It happens, but probably not.

203
00:11:18.720 --> 00:11:19.970
>> Probably not all that often.

204
00:11:19.970 --> 00:11:24.230
>> So you would take that and
file it with other stuff that you find and

205
00:11:24.230 --> 00:11:28.080
once you've collected all that, pull them
all out and look at it collectively and

206
00:11:28.080 --> 00:11:32.280
say, yeah, this is definitely a honeypot,

207
00:11:32.280 --> 00:11:36.940
because there's too many questions here
and too many things that don't add up.

208
00:11:36.940 --> 00:11:40.420
>> So, it's not so much we have
a tool to detect a honeypot, but

209
00:11:40.420 --> 00:11:41.690
using our normal tools and

210
00:11:41.690 --> 00:11:45.950
then our common sense or experience can
kind of lead us to that conclusion.

211
00:11:45.950 --> 00:11:49.970
Here is an exchange server
that it has two users on it.

212
00:11:49.970 --> 00:11:51.910
Or here's a web server, but

213
00:11:51.910 --> 00:11:55.330
there's no actual websites being
hosted by it, things like that.

214
00:11:55.330 --> 00:11:57.490
It is just the default
configuration of IIS.

215
00:11:57.490 --> 00:12:01.790
>> Yeah, that would indeed be what it
is is that there's something missing

216
00:12:01.790 --> 00:12:03.340
when you get into it.

217
00:12:03.340 --> 00:12:08.620
Now, that's not to say that that's just
because it doesn't have anything in it,

218
00:12:08.620 --> 00:12:09.240
it's a honeypot.

219
00:12:09.240 --> 00:12:14.200
You could have systems that have, they're
fully populated with everything and

220
00:12:14.200 --> 00:12:15.490
it's a honeypot.

221
00:12:15.490 --> 00:12:17.800
Because they've gotten wise to this.

222
00:12:17.800 --> 00:12:20.940
So they have low interaction and
high interaction honeypots.

223
00:12:20.940 --> 00:12:24.520
The high interaction ones emulate
a whole network inside of them and

224
00:12:24.520 --> 00:12:29.620
then they even have systems on
it that have full accounts and

225
00:12:29.620 --> 00:12:32.000
mailboxes and everything else all set up.

226
00:12:32.000 --> 00:12:36.233
So when you start poking around in
there like oh, everything is here.

227
00:12:36.233 --> 00:12:41.156
But still, if you poke around enough and
maybe you start sniffing traffic and

228
00:12:41.156 --> 00:12:45.550
really examine anything's closer,
you'll find out that there's

229
00:12:45.550 --> 00:12:51.220
the appearance of movement and life there,
but there really isn't life there.

230
00:12:51.220 --> 00:12:52.750
Kind of like the government.

231
00:12:52.750 --> 00:12:55.620
So you'll find out that that's the way,
that's what it is,

232
00:12:55.620 --> 00:12:58.580
there's nothing really happening there.

233
00:12:58.580 --> 00:13:02.960
It's just using your common sense when
you're digging through that to say,

234
00:13:02.960 --> 00:13:09.030
yeah my experience tells me that
there's something just not here.

235
00:13:09.030 --> 00:13:11.720
I also want to emphasize
that some vendors and

236
00:13:11.720 --> 00:13:16.480
some best practices have been put
out there saying, if you do a scan

237
00:13:16.480 --> 00:13:21.000
of something that you suspect is
a honeypot, they've set it up so

238
00:13:21.000 --> 00:13:25.390
there's a specific port always open
that's reserved for that honeypot.

239
00:13:25.390 --> 00:13:27.300
And they want you to do a banner,
it's put up there so

240
00:13:27.300 --> 00:13:30.470
you can not only find it open, but
you do a banner grab against it, and

241
00:13:30.470 --> 00:13:33.980
it will identify itself right
from the get go as a honeypot.

242
00:13:33.980 --> 00:13:38.900
They're doing that just to say,
hey you're staring at one.

243
00:13:38.900 --> 00:13:42.780
And they're hoping that if you see
that it'll act as a deterrent saying

244
00:13:42.780 --> 00:13:43.890
go someplace else.

245
00:13:44.910 --> 00:13:47.523
This person has deployed stuff and
is ready for you.

246
00:13:47.523 --> 00:13:48.232
>> Right.

247
00:13:48.232 --> 00:13:49.172
Okay.

248
00:13:49.172 --> 00:13:51.950
You know, Sean, I was having trouble,
and I know you did that earlier.

249
00:13:51.950 --> 00:13:55.450
Where was, I didn't find firewalk on here.

250
00:13:55.450 --> 00:13:58.000
You know where that one was buried at?

251
00:13:58.000 --> 00:14:00.960
>> It is, where'd they put it?

252
00:14:02.330 --> 00:14:08.170
This is probably the problems with some
of these things is that they really

253
00:14:08.170 --> 00:14:10.420
get kinda buried down in there.

254
00:14:10.420 --> 00:14:12.442
>> I just seen it too myself.

255
00:14:12.442 --> 00:14:15.260
>> All right so
far we have firewalk and HPing 3.

256
00:14:15.260 --> 00:14:19.460
We've got a lot of tools we can
use to discover firewalls and

257
00:14:19.460 --> 00:14:23.500
IDS's and
honeypots is another interesting one.

258
00:14:23.500 --> 00:14:25.470
As a penetration tester,

259
00:14:25.470 --> 00:14:29.030
these are things I've gotta worry about
when I'm doing a penetration test?

260
00:14:29.030 --> 00:14:30.890
>> Yeah,
you are gonna have to worry about them,

261
00:14:30.890 --> 00:14:35.750
because they are always deployed,
really, when you get down to it.

262
00:14:35.750 --> 00:14:38.080
Well, maybe except for
the case of honey pots.

263
00:14:38.080 --> 00:14:41.940
They're pretty much always in
these larger environments.

264
00:14:41.940 --> 00:14:47.480
Firewalls, we're gonna see all
over the place, IDSes and IPSes.

265
00:14:47.480 --> 00:14:51.510
Common devices in the medium
to large scale businesses,

266
00:14:51.510 --> 00:14:53.090
because of what they can do.

267
00:14:53.090 --> 00:14:57.580
They can give you that first
indication that an attack is happening.

268
00:14:57.580 --> 00:15:01.610
Instead of just a firewall that is
stopping it right there at the outer edge,

269
00:15:01.610 --> 00:15:05.320
or limiting traffic there,
now we have something that can say,

270
00:15:05.320 --> 00:15:08.760
well something got over the firewall and
got into a certain point.

271
00:15:08.760 --> 00:15:12.390
And we can see it, and detect it and
respond to it before it goes any further.

272
00:15:13.810 --> 00:15:17.620
Now with the last one, with the honeypot,

273
00:15:17.620 --> 00:15:23.700
it's not something you would expect to see
all the time because of their very nature.

274
00:15:23.700 --> 00:15:26.050
They have to be maintained a certain way.

275
00:15:26.050 --> 00:15:29.150
You have to be careful with them
because they can be used as launching

276
00:15:29.150 --> 00:15:31.770
platforms for
further strikes into your network.

277
00:15:34.330 --> 00:15:36.870
Not every company's just
going to see a need for that.

278
00:15:36.870 --> 00:15:41.490
I mean, yeah, their main purpose is to
be a decoy to attract someone away from

279
00:15:41.490 --> 00:15:43.270
your valuable assets.

280
00:15:43.270 --> 00:15:48.470
But companies may decide, instead of
saying we're gonna spend money on this

281
00:15:48.470 --> 00:15:53.750
asset, I'm gonna spend more money on
hardening these assets over here to make

282
00:15:53.750 --> 00:15:58.719
sure that that becomes a reality where
I have to decoy them away, anyway.

283
00:15:58.719 --> 00:16:00.506
But they all are in play.

284
00:16:00.506 --> 00:16:03.095
They absolutely are all in play 100%.

285
00:16:03.095 --> 00:16:05.069
So definitely firewalls,

286
00:16:05.069 --> 00:16:09.543
more like you've gonna see an IDS,
if not IPS then Honeypot.

287
00:16:09.543 --> 00:16:14.080
It depends, but do expect to see them
out there at least some of the time.

288
00:16:14.080 --> 00:16:16.100
>> And as a penetration tester
we've got to find them and

289
00:16:16.100 --> 00:16:18.270
then test them to see if
we can get around them.

290
00:16:18.270 --> 00:16:21.200
Because we've got to know if
the bad guy is going to be able to

291
00:16:21.200 --> 00:16:24.630
Get around those devices or
evade those types of devices.

292
00:16:24.630 --> 00:16:28.530
>> Yeah it's either gonna be in the case
of something like firewalk to see if they

293
00:16:28.530 --> 00:16:35.610
can determine what the rule set looks like
reliably and be able to get through it.

294
00:16:35.610 --> 00:16:40.180
Once they're able to reliably determine
what that rule set looks like then it's

295
00:16:40.180 --> 00:16:45.080
just a matter of getting things
moving the right way and

296
00:16:45.080 --> 00:16:47.530
crafting your tact the right
way to get around it.

297
00:16:47.530 --> 00:16:49.230
In the case of an IDS or

298
00:16:49.230 --> 00:16:54.010
IPS once you detect something like
that now you know that you have to be

299
00:16:54.010 --> 00:16:58.290
even more cautious about your attack
to make sure you don't trigger it.

300
00:16:58.290 --> 00:17:02.230
And then the final one with a honeypot,

301
00:17:02.230 --> 00:17:05.640
as far as you're concerned you want to
be able find out if you can get in.

302
00:17:06.680 --> 00:17:08.300
Is there, using your methods,

303
00:17:08.300 --> 00:17:12.440
is there a way for you to detect that
you're even dealing with a honeypot?

304
00:17:12.440 --> 00:17:16.880
Because remember,
while you maybe have been given

305
00:17:16.880 --> 00:17:19.140
privy to the fact that you
do have a honeypot there and

306
00:17:19.140 --> 00:17:22.960
it's a decoy, the attacker's not going
to have that same level of knowledge.

307
00:17:22.960 --> 00:17:27.030
They're going to say there's
a system there, a system there,

308
00:17:27.030 --> 00:17:30.280
a system there, and
they're all on the same footing.

309
00:17:30.280 --> 00:17:32.580
It's like no,
these two are actual production systems,

310
00:17:32.580 --> 00:17:36.590
this one's a honeypot, and
even though they all look the same,

311
00:17:36.590 --> 00:17:39.940
and that one is indeed different,
this one won't take you anywhere.

312
00:17:39.940 --> 00:17:42.340
This one is a padded cell.

313
00:17:42.340 --> 00:17:43.580
That one's gonna get you in there,

314
00:17:43.580 --> 00:17:47.190
and you're gonna beat your head against
the wall trying to get out, you're stuck.

315
00:17:47.190 --> 00:17:51.030
And so we want to make sure that
the attacker can't pick that up.

316
00:17:51.030 --> 00:17:55.090
That it is safe and sound enough that it
will keep them occupied and there is no

317
00:17:55.090 --> 00:17:59.050
real obvious way for them to pick up that
that is what that thing's purpose is.

318
00:17:59.050 --> 00:18:00.040
>> I didn't even think about that.

319
00:18:00.040 --> 00:18:02.940
We were trying to figure out if we
could detect if it was a honeypot

320
00:18:02.940 --> 00:18:05.860
because we need to see how easy it is
to figure out that it's a honeypot.

321
00:18:05.860 --> 00:18:08.520
If it's too easy then it's not
gonna do it's job as a honeypot.

322
00:18:08.520 --> 00:18:11.380
It's not gonna attract the bad guys for
very long, they're gonna be moving off to

323
00:18:11.380 --> 00:18:14.292
other servers and
now hitting my actual resources.

324
00:18:14.292 --> 00:18:18.710
>> Yeah you wanna be able to
think in those terms that, yeah,

325
00:18:18.710 --> 00:18:23.980
it may not be a case of can I break it or
get around it?

326
00:18:23.980 --> 00:18:29.640
It may be a case of, can you,
in this case, can you even detect it?

327
00:18:29.640 --> 00:18:34.340
If you dig a big hole in the ground and
expect something to fall into it, yeah,

328
00:18:34.340 --> 00:18:35.960
someone is eventually gonna fall into it.

329
00:18:35.960 --> 00:18:39.640
But if you're trying to trap someone or
I'll go and yeah, I'll walk around it.

330
00:18:39.640 --> 00:18:41.270
Am I going to fall into that?

331
00:18:41.270 --> 00:18:43.450
What are you thinking?

332
00:18:43.450 --> 00:18:45.270
So-
>> This with some m and m s in there.

333
00:18:45.270 --> 00:18:47.160
>> Yeah, give us some m and
ms or something like that.

334
00:18:47.160 --> 00:18:48.570
>> Or
a new case of Reese's peanut butter cups.

335
00:18:48.570 --> 00:18:49.476
>> Yeah, maybe something like that.

336
00:18:49.476 --> 00:18:53.775
>> [LAUGH]
>> So it's just being smart about these

337
00:18:53.775 --> 00:18:57.640
things is that,
think about what that device is used for.

338
00:18:59.180 --> 00:19:01.570
>> All right, well Sean,
a lot of great information there about,

339
00:19:01.570 --> 00:19:06.030
if I can even say it,
firewalls and honeypots and

340
00:19:06.030 --> 00:19:09.170
intrusion detection systems,
intrusion prevention systems.

341
00:19:09.170 --> 00:19:11.480
These are things we are going to
run into as penetration testers.

342
00:19:11.480 --> 00:19:12.910
We have to be aware
that they're out there.

343
00:19:12.910 --> 00:19:15.180
We have to be able to
detect that they're there.

344
00:19:15.180 --> 00:19:19.520
And in some cases try to evade them,
get around them or get through them, so

345
00:19:19.520 --> 00:19:22.430
we can see what those bad
guys can do to the never.

346
00:19:22.430 --> 00:19:25.430
So anything else we want to go over
before we wrap up this episode?

347
00:19:25.430 --> 00:19:30.200
>> Well, do remember you
are going to see devices like this

348
00:19:30.200 --> 00:19:32.110
in environments you test.

349
00:19:32.110 --> 00:19:36.450
It's very easy to go through something
like the CEH or play with any of the tools

350
00:19:36.450 --> 00:19:40.190
that we've talked about during the week
and just assume that you can just

351
00:19:40.190 --> 00:19:44.310
readily deploy those and throw caution
to the wind and go and do whatever.

352
00:19:44.310 --> 00:19:46.700
No.
If you do that, you're gonna get caught.

353
00:19:46.700 --> 00:19:48.784
You will get caught.

354
00:19:48.784 --> 00:19:52.480
So what you need to do is first of
all learn how to use the tools and

355
00:19:52.480 --> 00:19:55.380
learn how to them effectively and
become a master at that.

356
00:19:55.380 --> 00:19:59.320
And then once you've done that,
learn how you can be more conservative and

357
00:19:59.320 --> 00:20:03.410
what techniques will lower your
chances of being detected versus which

358
00:20:03.410 --> 00:20:06.270
ones will increase your
chances of being detected.

359
00:20:06.270 --> 00:20:09.040
You don't necessarily want to be detected.

360
00:20:09.040 --> 00:20:14.000
So you need to be thinking ahead,
but first plan what they are, or

361
00:20:14.000 --> 00:20:19.040
figure out, I should say figure out
what the tools do and how they work.

362
00:20:19.040 --> 00:20:22.860
Once you got how they work, then start
saying okay well I do know there's

363
00:20:22.860 --> 00:20:28.420
detected devices on here, and
by the way, you can get IDSs, and IPSs,

364
00:20:28.420 --> 00:20:34.050
and honey pots, and firewalls,
you can get all of those for free online.

365
00:20:34.050 --> 00:20:36.510
You have Linux distros that
do that specifically, and

366
00:20:36.510 --> 00:20:40.120
in some cases they have stuff like Snork
that takes care of the IDS function.

367
00:20:40.120 --> 00:20:44.410
So you can build these things from scratch
and then test actively against those.

368
00:20:44.410 --> 00:20:46.125
And once you have that information,

369
00:20:46.125 --> 00:20:50.165
you could start planning out your
attack to be much much better and

370
00:20:50.165 --> 00:20:52.765
much much more effective than
it would have been otherwise.

371
00:20:52.765 --> 00:20:56.015
So those are the types of
things you should be doing.

372
00:20:56.015 --> 00:21:01.097
Go ahead and practice, without concern
yourself those devices are there,

373
00:21:01.097 --> 00:21:06.197
then once you get better start figuring
out those devices will be there.

374
00:21:06.197 --> 00:21:10.477
How can I get around them and tiptoe and
crawl around without them picking me up?

375
00:21:11.960 --> 00:21:15.060
>> Well, ladies and gentlemen,
I hope you enjoyed watching this show.

376
00:21:15.060 --> 00:21:18.670
For now, signing off ITProTV,
I'm Mike Rodrick.

377
00:21:18.670 --> 00:21:19.430
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

378
00:21:19.430 --> 00:21:20.445
>> And we'll see you next time.

379

episodes.description: Many penetration testers have access to the same tools and skills that others within the industry can have, so one might want to try and differentiate themselves by the way they format and construct their findings on a report. Viewers will hear about some basic reporting tools within Kali that will help one with the documentation process to manage evidence, capture media, and show theyve done a test.

00:24:47.700 --> 00:24:51.575

00:25:02.109 --> 00:25:03.328

00:25:03.328 --> 00:25:06.650
Because you don't wanna write above them,

00:25:06.650 --> 00:25:11.550
And so, try to make something

00:25:11.550 --> 00:25:14.280

00:25:14.280 --> 00:25:18.570

00:25:26.940 --> 00:25:30.490

00:25:30.490 --> 00:25:32.190

00:25:32.190 --> 00:25:34.140

00:25:34.140 --> 00:25:35.480
We're not playing Scrabble.

431
00:25:37.849 --> 00:25:41.298
>> [LAUGH]
>> What you wanna do is you wanna use

432
00:25:41.298 --> 00:25:47.550

00:25:47.550 --> 00:25:50.580
In fact, one of the things they say for

00:25:50.580 --> 00:25:52.435

00:25:52.435 --> 00:25:54.040

00:25:54.040 --> 00:25:59.160
>> And it makes it so
people aren't getting confused or

437
00:25:59.160 --> 00:26:00.870

00:26:00.870 --> 00:26:03.850
Don't use slang,
don't use anything like that.

439
00:26:03.850 --> 00:26:09.700
As much as you may be wanting to do that,
avoid the temptation to do it.

440
00:26:09.700 --> 00:26:12.830
It's amazing that you should have
to say that, to avoid slang, but

441
00:26:12.830 --> 00:26:15.930
people seem to be using it more and
more and more.

442
00:26:15.930 --> 00:26:20.447
Stuff I've seen over the years people

00:26:20.447 --> 00:26:25.000

someone told you that was okay?

444
00:26:25.000 --> 00:26:26.360

it's in the urban dictionary.

00:26:26.360 --> 00:26:28.190
It's gotta be a real word.

446
00:26:28.190 --> 00:26:29.151
>> Yeah, totally.

00:26:29.151 --> 00:26:31.344
>> Yeah, I saw it on Wikipedia.

00:26:31.344 --> 00:26:33.460

When I think about this stuff, I got

00:26:37.760 --> 00:26:40.230
So I don't wanna hear
any garbage like that.

00:26:40.230 --> 00:26:43.980
But somebody,
I had a friend of mine show me,

452
00:26:43.980 --> 00:26:47.730

00:26:49.380 --> 00:26:51.630
And it kind of shows you the type
of thought process that goes in,

455
00:26:51.630 --> 00:26:53.860

456
00:26:53.860 --> 00:26:58.380
Don't just do crazy stuff,

00:26:58.380 --> 00:27:00.650

458
00:27:00.650 --> 00:27:04.630

00:27:04.630 --> 00:27:08.380
Don't go crazy with it because

00:27:19.260 --> 00:27:20.960
The person actually had

00:27:33.610 --> 00:27:36.680
